hebrew_text: מֵאֵימָתַי קוֹרִין אֶת שְׁמַע בָּעֲרָבִין? מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים נִכְנָסִים לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. עַד סוֹף הָאַשְׁמוּרָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: From when, one recite Shema in the evening? From the time when the priests enter to partake of their teruma. Until the end of the first watch. That is the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: From when do we recite the Shema in the evenings? From the time when the priests enter to eat their terumah until the end of the first watch. These are the words of Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: עַד חֲצוֹת.
human_translation: The Rabbis say: until midnight.
llm_translation: The Sages say: Until midnight.

hebrew_text: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר עַד שֶׁיַּעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר.
human_translation: Rabban Gamliel says: until dawn,
llm_translation: Rabban Gamliel says, "Until the pillar of dawn ascends."

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה וּבָאוּ בָנָיו מִבֵּית הַמִּשְׁתֶּה, אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא קָרִינוּ אֶת שְׁמַע, אָמַר לָהֶם: אִם לֹא עָלָה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר חַיָּיבִין אַתֶּם לִקְרוֹת. וְלֹא זוֹ בִּלְבַד אָמְרוּ, אֶלָּא כָּל מַה שֶּׁאָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים ״עַד חֲצוֹת״, מִצְוָתָן עַד שֶׁיַּעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר.
human_translation: incident sons returned from a wedding hall. They said to him, We did not recite Shema. He said to them: If the dawn has not arrived, you are obligated to recite and not only but rather, wherever the Sages say until midnight, the mitzva until dawn.
llm_translation: The incident: And his sons came from the house of feasting, they said to him: "We did not recite the Shema." He said to them: "If the morning light has not yet risen, you are obligated to recite. And not only this did they say, but anything that the sages said 'until midnight,' their obligation is until the morning light rises."

hebrew_text: הֶקְטֵר חֲלָבִים וְאֵבָרִים, מִצְוָתָן עַד שֶׁיַּעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר וְכָל הַנֶּאֱכָלִים לְיוֹם אֶחָד, מִצְוָתָן עַד שֶׁיַּעֲלֶה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר. אִם כֵּן, לָמָה אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים ״עַד חֲצוֹת״ — כְּדֵי לְהַרְחִיק אָדָם מִן הָעֲבֵירָה:
human_translation: the burning of fats and limbs And, all that are eaten for one day until dawn. If so, why did the Sages say until midnight? in order to distance a person from transgression,
llm_translation: The burning of fats and limbs, their commandment until the pillar of dawn rises, and all that are eaten in one day, their commandment until the pillar of dawn rises. If so, why did the sages say "until midnight" - in order to distance a person from transgression.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנָּא הֵיכָא קָאֵי דְּקָתָנֵי ״מֵאֵימָתַי״?
human_translation: On the basis of what does tanna From when?
llm_translation: Gemara: "Tanna, where is it standing that it teaches 'from when'?"

hebrew_text: וְתוּ: מַאי שְׁנָא דְּתָנֵי בְּעַרְבִית בְּרֵישָׁא? לִתְנֵי דְּשַׁחֲרִית בְּרֵישָׁא!
human_translation: And furthermore, what distinguishes the evening first? Let teach the morning first.
llm_translation: And come and learn: What is the difference that it teaches in Aramaic at the beginning? Let it teach in Hebrew at the beginning!

hebrew_text: תַּנָּא אַקְּרָא קָאֵי, דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּשָׁכְבְּךָ וּבְקוּמֶךָ״. וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: זְמַן קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע דִּשְׁכִיבָה אֵימַת? — מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים נִכְנָסִין לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן.
human_translation: The tanna bases himself on the verse as it is written: when you lie down, and when you arise” And the tanna teaches When is the time for the recitation of Shema of lying down From when the priests enter to partake of their teruma .
llm_translation: We learned in a Baraita: The reading stands, as it is written: "When you lie down and when you rise up." And thus it was taught: At what time is the reading of the Shema in the evening? — From the time the priests enter to eat their Terumah.

hebrew_text: וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: יָלֵיף מִבְּרִיָּיתוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי עֶרֶב וַיְהִי בֹקֶר יוֹם אֶחָד״.
human_translation: If you wish, say derives from the creation of the world. As it is written “And there was evening, and there was morning, one day”
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: He should learn from the creation of the world, as it is written: "And there was evening and there was morning, one day."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, סֵיפָא דְּקָתָנֵי ״בַּשַּׁחַר מְבָרֵךְ שְׁתַּיִם לְפָנֶיהָ וְאַחַת לְאַחֲרֶיהָ, בָּעֶרֶב מְבָרֵךְ שְׁתַּיִם לְפָנֶיהָ וּשְׁתַּיִם לְאַחֲרֶיהָ״, לִתְנֵי דְּעַרְבִית בְּרֵישָׁא!
human_translation: If so, latter clause teach: In the morning one recites two before and one afterward, and in the evening one recites two before and two afterward? should have taught evening first.
llm_translation: If so, the end of the teaching states, "In the morning, one recites two blessings before it and one after it; in the evening, one recites two blessings before it and two after it." Let it teach about the evening first!

hebrew_text: תַּנָּא פָּתַח בְּעַרְבִית, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי בְּשַׁחֲרִית, עַד דְּקָאֵי בְּשַׁחֲרִית, פָּרֵישׁ מִילֵּי דְשַׁחֲרִית, וַהֲדַר פָּרֵישׁ מִילֵּי דְעַרְבִית.
human_translation: tanna began the evening and then taught the morning Once was already dealing with the morning he explained the matters of the morning and then explained the matters of the evening
llm_translation: It was taught: He began in the evening, and then he repeated it in the morning, until he reached the morning. He separated the matters of the morning, and then he separated the matters of the evening.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים נִכְנָסִים לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. מִכְּדִי כֹּהֲנִים אֵימַת קָא אָכְלִי תְּרוּמָה? — מִשְּׁעַת צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים, לִתְנֵי: ״מִשְּׁעַת צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים״!
human_translation: The Master said when the priests enter to partake of their teruma . When do the priests enter to partake of their teruma ? From the time of the emergence of the stars. let teach from the time of the emergence of the stars.
llm_translation: Master said: From the time that the priests enter to eat their terumah. When do the priests usually eat terumah? — From the time of the emergence of the stars, as it is taught: "From the time of the emergence of the stars"!

hebrew_text: מִלְּתָא אַגַּב אוֹרְחֵיהּ קָמַשְׁמַע לַן — כֹּהֲנִים אֵימַת קָא אָכְלִי בִּתְרוּמָה — מִשְּׁעַת צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים. וְהָא קָמַשְׁמַע לַן דְּכַפָּרָה לָא מְעַכְּבָא. כִּדְתַנְיָא: ״וּבָא הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ וְטָהֵר״ — בִּיאַת שִׁמְשׁוֹ מְעַכַּבְתּוֹ מִלֶּאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָה, וְאֵין כַּפָּרָתוֹ מְעַכַּבְתּוֹ מִלֶּאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָה.
human_translation: teaches us matter in passing: When do priests partake of their teruma ? From the time of the emergence of the stars. And teaches us atonement does not prevent As it was taught “And the sun sets and it is purified,” the setting of his sun prevents him from partaking of teruma , but the atonement does not prevent him from partaking of teruma ,
llm_translation: The matter regarding his journey we heard - when do priests eat from the terumah? From the time of the emergence of the stars. And we heard that atonement does not delay. As it was taught: "And the sun shall set and he shall be pure" - the setting of the sun delays him from eating terumah, but his atonement does not delay him from eating terumah.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּהַאי ״וּבָא הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ״ בִּיאַת הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ, וְהַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר יוֹמָא.
human_translation: From where that the “And the sun sets” the setting of the sun, “and it is purified” the day is pure,
llm_translation: And from what is derived this "and the sun shall come" referring to the coming of the sun, and this "and he shall be pure" — it means he shall be pure that day.

hebrew_text: דִּילְמָא בִּיאַת אוֹרוֹ הוּא, וּמַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר גַּבְרָא?!
human_translation: Perhaps the setting of light. what does and it is purified mean? the person will become purified.
llm_translation: Perhaps it is the coming of his light, and what is "and he shall be clean" - he shall be clean, a man?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּהּ בַּר רַב שֵׁילָא: אִם כֵּן, לֵימָא קְרָא: ״וְיִטְהָר״, מַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר יוֹמָא, כִּדְאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: ״אִיעֲרַב שִׁמְשָׁא וְאִדַּכִּי יוֹמָא״.
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Sheila said: If so, let the verse say And he will become purified. What is And it is purified? the day is pure, as people say The sun has set and the day is purified.
llm_translation: Rabbah bar Rav Sheilah said: If so, let us say the verse: "And he shall be clean." What is "and he shall be clean"? — He shall be clean for that day, as people say: "Mix the sun and the day."

hebrew_text: בְּמַעֲרָבָא, הָא דְּרַבָּהּ בַּר רַב שֵׁילָא לָא שְׁמִיעַ לְהוּ, וּבְעוֹ לַהּ מִיבַּעְיָא: הַאי ״וּבָא הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ״ בִּיאַת שִׁמְשׁוֹ הוּא, וּמַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר יוֹמָא, אוֹ דִילְמָא בִּיאַת אוֹרוֹ הוּא, וּמַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר גַּבְרָא.
human_translation: In the West, they did not hear this by Rabba bar Rav Sheila. They raised the dilemma: Does the expression: And the sun sets, refer to the setting of the sun, and does: And it is purified, mean the day clears away? Or perhaps it refers to the setting of its light what is And it is purified? the purification of the person.
llm_translation: In the west, this that Rabba bar Rav Sheila did not hear from them, and he asked them: this "and the sun comes" - is the coming of its light, and what "and he shall be pure" - he shall be pure for the day, or perhaps it is the coming of its warmth, and what "and he shall be pure" - he shall be pure as a man.

hebrew_text: וַהֲדַר פָּשְׁטוּ לַהּ מִבָּרַיְיתָא. מִדְּקָתָנֵי בְּבָרַיְיתָא, סִימָן לַדָּבָר — צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ — בִּיאַת שִׁמְשׁוֹ הוּא, וּמַאי ״וְטָהֵר״ — טְהַר יוֹמָא.
human_translation: Ultimately they resolved from a baraita . It was taught in a baraita a sign for which is the emergence of the stars. derive from here the complete sunset, and the expression “and it is purified” the day clears away,
llm_translation: And they subsequently interpreted it from the Baraita. As it is taught in the Baraita, a sign for the matter - the emergence of the stars. Learn from it - it is the coming of the sun, and what is "and he shall be pure" - he shall be pure that day.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים נִכְנָסִין לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. וּרְמִינְהוּ: מֵאֵימָתַי קוֹרִין אֶת שְׁמַע בָּעֲרָבִין — מִשֶּׁהֶעָנִי נִכְנָס לֶאֱכוֹל פִּתּוֹ בְּמֶלַח, עַד שָׁעָה שֶׁעוֹמֵד לִיפָּטֵר מִתּוֹךְ סְעוּדָּתוֹ.
human_translation: the Master said: From the time when the priests enter to partake of their teruma . raises a contradiction From when a poor person enters to eat his bread with salt until he rises from his meal.
llm_translation: Master said: From the time that the priests enter to eat their portion. And they raised a dilemma: From when do we recite the Shema in the evenings? - From when the poor person enters to eat his bread with salt, until the time he stands to take leave from his meal.

hebrew_text: סֵיפָא, וַדַּאי פְּלִיגָא אַמַּתְנִיתִין. רֵישָׁא, מִי לֵימָא פְּלִיגִי אַמַּתְנִיתִין?
human_translation: The latter clause certainly disagrees with our mishna. the first clause shall we say that it disagrees with our mishna?
llm_translation: The latter part, and indeed it is a dispute of the Tannaim. The former part, who should we say the Tannaim are disputing?

hebrew_text: לָא, עָנִי וְכֹהֵן חַד שִׁיעוּרָא הוּא.
human_translation: No, the poor person and the priest are one time.
llm_translation: Not, poor and priest one measure he is.

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהוּ: מֵאֵימָתַי מַתְחִילִין לִקְרוֹת קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע בְּעַרְבִית — מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁבְּנֵי אָדָם נִכְנָסִין לֶאֱכוֹל פִּתָּן בְּעַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים זַכָּאִין לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. סִימָן לַדָּבָר: צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים. וְאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רְאָיָה לַדָּבָר, זֵכֶר לַדָּבָר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַאֲנַחְנוּ עֹשִׂים בַּמְּלָאכָה וְחֶצְיָם מַחֲזִיקִים בָּרְמָחִים מֵעֲלוֹת הַשַּׁחַר עַד צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״וְהָיוּ לָנוּ הַלַּיְלָה מִשְׁמָר וְהַיּוֹם מְלָאכָה״.
human_translation: raises a contradiction From when does one begin to recite in the evening? From the time when people enter to eat their bread on Shabbat eve. the statement of Rabbi Meir. the Rabbis say: From the time when the priests are eligible to partake of their teruma , a sign for which is the emergence of the stars. And although there is no proof there is an allusion it is stated “And we perform the work, and half of them grasp their spears from dawn until the emergence of the stars” And it says: “That in the night they may be a guard to us, and may labor in the day”
llm_translation: And they asked: From when do we begin to recite the Shema in the evening? - From the time that people enter to eat their bread in the evenings of Shabbat, the words of Rabbi Meir. And the sages say: From the time that the priests become permitted to eat their terumah. A sign for the matter: the emergence of the stars. And even though there is no actual sighting, there is a remembrance of the matter, as it is said: "And we were doing the work, and half of them were holding the spears from the break of dawn until the emergence of the stars," and it says: "And the night shall be for us to guard, and the day for work."

hebrew_text: מַאי ״וְאוֹמֵר״?
human_translation: What And it says?
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "ve'omer"?

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא מִכִּי עָרְבָא שִׁמְשָׁא, לֵילְיָא הוּא, וְאִינְהוּ דְּמַחְשְׁכִי וּמַקְדְּמִי, תָּא שְׁמַע ״וְהָיוּ לָנוּ הַלַּיְלָה מִשְׁמָר וְהַיּוֹם מְלָאכָה״.
human_translation: As, if you say that night begins when the sun sets, but stayed late and arrived early; Come and hear, “That in the night they may be a guard to us, and may labor in the day,”
llm_translation: And if you say, "Since it is evening, it is night, and they are dark and precede," come and hear: "And it shall be for us a watch at night and labor by day."

hebrew_text: קָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ דְּעָנִי וּבְנֵי אָדָם חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ עָנִי וְכֹהֵן חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא, חֲכָמִים הַיְינוּ רַבִּי מֵאִיר?
human_translation: It might enter your mind poor person people are one time, if you say the poor person’s and the priest are one time, the Rabbis is Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: Your request is to translate the following Talmudic text into English word-for-word, maintaining the original style and format of Talmudic discourse. Here is the translation: Talmudic text: "Ka sakla da'atach de'ani u'venei adam chad shiura hu. Ve'ei amratch ani ve'kohen chad shiura hu, chachamim hayinu Rabbi Meir?" English translation: "The measure of a poor person and the measure of a priest is one. And if you say the measure of a poor person and the measure of a priest is one, are the Sages Rabbi Meir?"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ עָנִי שִׁעוּרָא לְחוּד וְכֹהֵן שִׁעוּרָא לְחוּד. לָא, עָנִי וְכֹהֵן חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא, וְעָנִי וּבְנֵי אָדָם לָאו חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא.
human_translation: Rather, learn from this a separate time poor person and a separate time priest. no, poor person and the priest are one time, the poor person and people are not the same.
llm_translation: Rather, hear from it that a poor person has a separate measure and a priest has a separate measure. No, a poor person and a priest have one measure, and a poor person and other people do not have one measure.

hebrew_text: וְעָנִי וְכֹהֵן חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא? וּרְמִינְהוּ: מֵאֵימָתַי מַתְחִילִין לִקְרוֹת שְׁמַע בָּעֲרָבִין — מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁקָּדַשׁ הַיּוֹם בְּעַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים מְטוֹהָרִים לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר, מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁהַכֹּהֲנִים טוֹבְלִין לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָתָן. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: וַהֲלֹא כֹּהֲנִים מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם הֵם טוֹבְלִים? רַבִּי חֲנִינָא אוֹמֵר מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁעָנִי נִכְנָס לֶאֱכוֹל פִּתּוֹ בְּמֶלַח. רַבִּי אַחַאי וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַבִּי אַחָא אוֹמֵר: מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁרוֹב בְּנֵי אָדָם נִכְנָסִין לְהָסֵב.
human_translation: And is the time of the poor person and the priest the same? raises a contradiction From when does one begin to recite evening From the time when the day becomes sanctified on the eve of Shabbat, this is the statement of Rabbi Eliezer, Rabbi Yehoshua, says: From the time when the priests are eligible to partake of their teruma . Rabbi Meir says: from when the priests immerse themselves in order to partake of their teruma . Rabbi Yehuda said to Do the priests not immerse themselves during the day, Rabbi Ḥanina says when the poor person enters to eat his bread with salt. Rabbi Aḥai, and some say Rabbi Aḥa, says: From the time when most people enter to recline
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And a poor person and a priest, is it one measure? And they raised a dilemma: From when do we begin to recite the Shema in the evenings? - From the time that the day has sanctified the eve of Sabbaths, the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says: From the time that the priests purify themselves to eat their terumah. Rabbi Meir says, from the time that the priests immerse themselves to eat their terumah. Rabbi Yehuda said to him: But aren't the priests already immersed during the day? Rabbi Chanina says: From the time that a poor person enters to eat his bread with salt. Rabbi Ahai, and some say it was Rabbi Acha, says: From the time that most people enter to dine." English translation:

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ עָנִי וְכֹהֵן חַד שִׁעוּרָא הוּא, רַבִּי חֲנִינָא הַיְינוּ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ!
human_translation: if you say the time of the poor person and the priest are one time, Rabbi Ḥanina is Rabbi Yehoshua.
llm_translation: "If you say 'poor' and 'priest' are of equal measure, Rabbi Chanina is the same as Rabbi Yehoshua!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ שִׁעוּרָא דְּעָנִי לְחוּד וְשִׁעוּרָא דְּכֹהֵן לְחוּד, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rather, must not conclude from this the time for poor person is separate and the time for priest is separate? conclude from this.
llm_translation: Rather, not hear from it, measure of poor separately and measure of priest separately, hear from it.

hebrew_text: הֵי מִינַּיְיהוּ מְאוּחָר? מִסְתַּבְּרָא דְּעָנִי מְאוּחָר דְּאִי אָמְרַתְּ דְּעָנִי מוּקְדָּם רַבִּי חֲנִינָא הַיְינוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ דְּעָנִי מְאוּחָר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: which one is later? it is reasonable the poor person is later. As if you say the poor person is earlier, Rabbi Ḥanina is Rabbi Eliezer. Rather, must not conclude from this that the poor person is later? conclude from this.
llm_translation: Be his arguments late? It is reasonable that the poor are late, for if you say that the poor are early, Rabbi Chanina, that is Rabbi Eliezer. Rather, it is not heard from him that the poor are late. It is heard from him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: וַהֲלֹא כֹּהֲנִים מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם הֵם טוֹבְלִים!
human_translation: the Master said Rabbi Yehuda said Do the priests not immerse themselves during the day?
llm_translation: Master said: Rabbi Yehuda said to him: Aren't the priests immersing from the break of day?

hebrew_text: שַׁפִּיר קָאָמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר?
human_translation: What Rabbi Yehuda said to Rabbi Meir seems correct,
llm_translation: "Shapir ka'amar leih Rabbi Yehudah le'Rabbi Meir?"

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר הָכִי קָאָמַר לֵיהּ: מִי סָבְרַתְּ דַּאֲנָא אַבֵּין הַשְּׁמָשׁוֹת דִּידָךְ קָא אָמֵינָא? אֲנָא אַבֵּין הַשְּׁמָשׁוֹת דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי קָא אָמֵינָא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בֵּין הַשְּׁמָשׁוֹת כְּהֶרֶף עַיִן, זֶה — נִכְנָס, וְזֶה — יוֹצֵא, וְאִי אֶפְשָׁר לַעֲמוֹד עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir said as follows Do you maintain that I am speaking of your twilight? I am speaking of Rabbi Yosei’s twilight, as Rabbi Yosei said: Twilight is like the blink of an eye; begins and ends and it is impossible to quantify.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir thus said to him: Do you think that I hold that I understand the movements of the sun? I understand the movements of Rabbi Yosei, for Rabbi Yosei said: "Between the suns is like the blink of an eye, this one enters, and this one exits, and it is impossible to stand on it."

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַדְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר! תְּרֵי תַּנָּאֵי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir contradict Rabbi Meir Two tanna’im , in accordance with Rabbi Meir’s
llm_translation: The difficulty of Rabbi Meir, according to Rabbi Meir! Two Tannaim in the school of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אַדְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר!
human_translation: of Rabbi Eliezer contradicts of Rabbi Eliezer
llm_translation: The difficulty of Rabbi Eliezer is according to Rabbi Eliezer!

hebrew_text: תְּרֵי תַּנָּאֵי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: רֵישָׁא לָאו רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הִיא.
human_translation: two in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer’s or if you wish, say the first clause is not Rabbi Eliezer’s
llm_translation: Two Tannaim in the school of Rabbi Eliezer, and if you wish, say: The beginning is not according to Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: עַד סוֹף הָאַשְׁמוּרָה.
human_translation: until the end of the first watch.
llm_translation: Until the end of the watch.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָסָבַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? אִי קָסָבַר שָׁלֹשׁ מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, לֵימָא ״עַד אַרְבַּע שָׁעוֹת״. וְאִי קָסָבַר אַרְבַּע מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, לֵימָא ״עַד שָׁלֹשׁ שָׁעוֹת״!
human_translation: What does Rabbi Eliezer hold? If he holds that the night consists of three watches, let him say until the fourth hour. If he holds that the night consists of four watches, let him say until the third hour.
llm_translation: What does Rabbi Eliezer hold? If he holds that there are three watches in the night, let him say "until four hours." And if he holds that there are four watches in the night, let him say "until three hours!"

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם קָסָבַר שָׁלֹשׁ מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, וְהָא קָמַשְׁמַע לָן: דְּאִיכָּא מִשְׁמָרוֹת בָּרָקִיעַ וְאִיכָּא מִשְׁמָרוֹת בְּאַרְעָא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: שָׁלֹשׁ מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, וְעַל כָּל מִשְׁמָר וּמִשְׁמָר יוֹשֵׁב הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וְשׁוֹאֵג כָּאֲרִי, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״ה׳ מִמָּרוֹם יִשְׁאָג, וּמִמְּעוֹן קָדְשׁוֹ יִתֵּן קוֹלוֹ שָׁאֹג יִשְׁאַג עַל נָוֵהוּ״.
human_translation: Actually, holds that the night consists of three watches, in order to teach us: There are watches in heaven and there are watches on earth; As it was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: The night consists of three watches, and over each and every watch, the Holy One, Blessed be He, sits and roars like a lion as it is stated: “The Lord roars [ yishag ] from on high, from His holy dwelling He makes His voice heard. He roars mightily shaog yishag over His dwelling place,
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Forever he holds that there are three watches in the night, and this is what he heard: that there are watches in the sky and there are watches on the earth. As it was taught, Rabbi Eliezer says: There are three watches in the night, and in each watch, the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and roars like a lion, as it is said: 'The Lord from on high will roar, and from His holy habitation He will give forth His voice; He will roar mightily over His dwelling place.'"

hebrew_text: וְסִימָן לַדָּבָר: מִשְׁמָרָה רִאשׁוֹנָה חֲמוֹר נוֹעֵר, שְׁנִיָּה כְּלָבִים צוֹעֲקִים, שְׁלִישִׁית, תִּינוֹק יוֹנֵק מִשְּׁדֵי אִמּוֹ, וְאִשָּׁה מְסַפֶּרֶת עִם בַּעֲלָהּ.
human_translation: And signs of these the first watch, the donkey brays; the second, dogs bark; the third a baby nurses from its mother’s breast and a wife converses with her husband.
llm_translation: And a sign for the matter: the first watch is a braying donkey, the second are barking dogs, the third is a suckling babe from his mother's breast, and a woman conversing with her husband.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָא חָשֵׁיב רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, אִי תְּחִלַּת מִשְׁמָרוֹת קָא חָשֵׁיב — תְּחִלַּת מִשְׁמָרָה רִאשׁוֹנָה סִימָנָא לְמָה לִי? אוּרְתָּא הוּא! אִי סוֹף מִשְׁמָרוֹת קָא חָשֵׁיב, סוֹף מִשְׁמָרָה אַחֲרוֹנָה לְמָה לִי סִימָנָא? יְמָמָא הוּא!
human_translation: What did Rabbi Eliezer enumerate? If enumerated the beginning of the watch, why do I need a sign for the beginning of the first watch? It is evening If he enumerated the end of the watches, why do I need a sign for the end of the last watch? It is day
llm_translation: What is Rabbi Eliezer considering? If he is considering the beginning of the watches - why is the beginning of the first watch significant to me? It is a sign! If he is considering the end of the watches, why is the end of the last watch a sign to me? It is a proverb!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: חָשֵׁיב סוֹף מִשְׁמָרָה רִאשׁוֹנָה, וּתְחִלַּת מִשְׁמָרָה אַחֲרוֹנָה, וְאֶמְצָעִית דְּאֶמְצָעִיתָא. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כּוּלְּהוּ סוֹף מִשְׁמָרוֹת קָא חָשֵׁיב, וְכִי תֵּימָא אַחֲרוֹנָה לָא צְרִיךְ.
human_translation: Rather, he enumerated the end of the first watch and the beginning of the last watch, the middle of the middle And if you wish, say He enumerated the ends of all And if you say final is unnecessary
llm_translation: Rather: considered end of first watch, and beginning of last watch, and middle of middle. And if you want to say: all end of watches are considered, and if you say last is not necessary.

hebrew_text: לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ — לְמִיקְרֵי קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע לְמַאן דְּגָנֵי בְּבַיִת אָפֵל וְלָא יָדַע זְמַן קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע אֵימַת. כֵּיוָן דְּאִשָּׁה מְסַפֶּרֶת עִם בַּעֲלָהּ וְתִינוֹק יוֹנֵק מִשְּׁדֵי אִמּוֹ, לִיקוּם וְלִיקְרֵי.
human_translation: What is the practical ramification to one who recites while lying in a dark house, who does not know when the time for reciting Shema when a woman speaks with her husband and a baby nurses from its mother’s breast, he must rise and recite
llm_translation: Regarding what does it come out? — For the purpose of reciting the Shema. For one who sleeps in a house and does not know the time for reciting the Shema. Once a woman is speaking with her husband and a baby is nursing from its mother's breast, he should get up and recite.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: שָׁלֹשׁ מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, וְעַל כָּל מִשְׁמָר וּמִשְׁמָר יוֹשֵׁב הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וְשׁוֹאֵג כַּאֲרִי, וְאוֹמֵר: ״אוֹי שֶׁהֶחֱרַבְתִּי אֶת בֵּיתִי וְשָׂרַפְתִּי אֶת הֵיכָלִי וְהִגְלֵיתִי אֶת בָּנַי לְבֵין אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם״.
human_translation: Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel said in the name of Rav: The night consists of three watches, and over each and every watch the Holy One, Blessed be He sits and roars like a lion, and says: “Woe to Me, that due to their sins I destroyed My house, burned My Temple and exiled them among the nations of the world.”
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak bar Shmuel said in the name of Rav: There are three watches in the night, and during each watch, the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and roars like a lion, saying: "Woe is Me for having destroyed My House, burnt My Temple, and exiled My children among the nations of the world."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: פַּעַם אַחַת הָיִיתִי מְהַלֵּךְ בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְנִכְנַסְתִּי לְחוּרְבָּה אַחַת מֵחוּרְבוֹת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם לְהִתְפַּלֵּל. בָּא אֵלִיָּהוּ זָכוּר לַטּוֹב וְשָׁמַר לִי עַל הַפֶּתַח, (וְהִמְתִּין לִי) עַד שֶׁסִּייַּמְתִּי תְּפִלָּתִי. לְאַחַר שֶׁסִּייַּמְתִּי תְּפִלָּתִי אָמַר לִי: ״שָׁלוֹם עָלֶיךָ, רַבִּי״. וְאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: ״שָׁלוֹם עָלֶיךָ, רַבִּי וּמוֹרִי״. וְאָמַר לִי: בְּנִי, מִפְּנֵי מָה נִכְנַסְתָּ לְחוּרְבָּה זוֹ? אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: לְהִתְפַּלֵּל. וְאָמַר לִי: הָיָה לְךָ לְהִתְפַּלֵּל בַּדֶּרֶךְ. וְאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: מִתְיָרֵא הָיִיתִי שֶׁמָּא יַפְסִיקוּ בִּי עוֹבְרֵי דְּרָכִים, וְאָמַר לִי הָיָה לְךָ לְהִתְפַּלֵּל תְּפִלָּה קְצָרָה.
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Yosei said: I was once walking along the road when I entered ruins among the ruins of Jerusalem to pray. Elijah, of blessed memory, came and guarded the entrance for me and waited at the entrance until I finished my prayer. When I finished praying said to me, Greetings to you, my rabbi. I answered him: Greetings to you, my rabbi, my teacher. And said to me: My son, why did you enter this ruin? I said to him: to pray. And said to me: You should have prayed on the road. And I said to him: I was afraid that I might be interrupted by travelers said to me: You should have recited the abbreviated prayer
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei said: Once I was walking on the road and I entered a ruin of the ruins of Jerusalem to pray. Elijah came and stood at the entrance for me, (and waited for me) until I finished my prayer. After I finished my prayer, he said to me: "Peace be upon you, Rabbi." And I said to him: "Peace be upon you, Rabbi and my teacher." And he said to me: "My son, why did you enter this ruin?" I said to him: "To pray." And he said to me: "You should have prayed on the road." And I said to him: "I was afraid lest passersby disturb me, and he said to me: You should have prayed a short prayer."

hebrew_text: בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה לָמַדְתִּי מִמֶּנּוּ שְׁלֹשָׁה דְּבָרִים: לָמַדְתִּי שֶׁאֵין נִכְנָסִין לְחוּרְבָּה, וְלָמַדְתִּי שֶׁמִּתְפַּלְּלִין בַּדֶּרֶךְ, וְלָמַדְתִּי שֶׁהַמִּתְפַּלֵּל בְּדֶרֶךְ מִתְפַּלֵּל תְּפִלָּה קְצָרָה.
human_translation: At that time, I learned from him three things: I learned that one may not enter a ruin; and I learned he may pray along the road; and I learned that one who prays along the road recites an abbreviated prayer,
llm_translation: At that moment, I learned three things from him: I learned that one does not enter a ruin, and I learned that one prays on the way, and I learned that one who prays on the way recites a brief prayer.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר לִי: בְּנִי, מָה קוֹל שָׁמַעְתָּ בְּחוּרְבָּה זוֹ? וְאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: שָׁמַעְתִּי בַּת קוֹל שֶׁמְּנַהֶמֶת כְּיוֹנָה וְאוֹמֶרֶת: ״אוֹי שֶׁהֶחֱרַבְתִּי אֶת בֵּיתִי וְשָׂרַפְתִּי אֶת הֵיכָלִי וְהִגְלֵיתִי אֶת בָּנַי לְבֵין אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם״. וְאָמַר לִי: חַיֶּיךָ וְחַיֵּי רֹאשְׁךָ, לֹא שָׁעָה זוֹ בִּלְבַד אוֹמֶרֶת כָּךְ, אֶלָּא בְּכָל יוֹם וָיוֹם, שָׁלֹשׁ פְּעָמִים אוֹמֶרֶת כָּךְ. וְלֹא זוֹ בִּלְבַד אֶלָּא, בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל נִכְנָסִין לְבָתֵּי כְּנֵסִיּוֹת וּלְבָתֵּי מִדְרָשׁוֹת וְעוֹנִין ״יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ הַגָּדוֹל מְבֹורָךְ״, הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מְנַעְנֵעַ רֹאשׁוֹ, וְאוֹמֵר: אַשְׁרֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ שֶׁמְּקַלְּסִין אוֹתוֹ בְּבֵיתוֹ כָּךְ, מַה לּוֹ לָאָב שֶׁהִגְלָה אֶת בָּנָיו, וְאוֹי לָהֶם לַבָּנִים שֶׁגָּלוּ מֵעַל שׁוּלְחַן אֲבִיהֶם.
human_translation: And said to me: What voice did you hear in that ruin? I responded: I heard a Heavenly voice, cooing like a dove and saying: Woe to the children, due to whose sins I destroyed My house, burned My Temple, and exiled them among the nations of the world. And said to me: your life and by your head, not only cry out in that moment, but it cries out three times each and every day. Moreover, when Israel enters synagogues and study halls and answers May His great name be blessed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, shakes His head and says: Happy is the king who is thus praised in his house. How the father who exiled his children, and woe to the children who were exiled from their father’s table,
llm_translation: He said to me: My son, what sound did you hear in this ruin? And I said to him: I heard a voice like a dove cooing and saying, "Woe that I destroyed my house, burnt my temple, and exiled my children among the nations of the world." And he said to me: By your life and the life of your head, this hour not only says this, but every day, three times it says this. And not only this, but at the time when Israel enters synagogues and study halls and say, "May His great name be blessed," the Holy One, blessed be He, nods His head and says: "Blessed is the king who is thus insulted in his own house. What is the father's pain who exiled his children, and woe to the children who were exiled from their father's table."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנָן, מִפְּנֵי שְׁלֹשָׁה דְּבָרִים אֵין נִכְנָסִין לְחוּרְבָּה: מִפְּנֵי חֲשָׁד, מִפְּנֵי הַמַּפּוֹלֶת, וּמִפְּנֵי הַמַּזִּיקִין. ״מִפְּנֵי חֲשָׁד״, וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ ״מִשּׁוּם מַפּוֹלֶת״?
human_translation: The Sages taught, for three reasons one may not enter a ruin: Because of suspicion because collapse, because of demons. because of suspicion Let this be derived because of collapse.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: For three things, one does not enter the Temple Mount: because of suspicion, because of collapse, and because of harmful creatures. "Because of suspicion" - and let him go out because of "collapse"?

hebrew_text: בְּחַדְתִּי.
human_translation: in new,
llm_translation: In my newness.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם מַזִּיקִין? בִּתְרֵי.
human_translation: And let this be derived because of demons? where two
llm_translation: And should he pay because of damages? In two.

hebrew_text: אִי בִּתְרֵי — חֲשָׁד נָמֵי לֵיכָּא! בִּתְרֵי וּפְרִיצִי.
human_translation: if there are two there is no suspicion either. two individuals immoral
llm_translation: If in two - there is a suspicion, there is none! In two and a half.

hebrew_text: ״מִפְּנֵי הַמַּפּוֹלֶת״, וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם חֲשָׁד וּמַזִּיקִין!
human_translation: because of collapse Let be derived from suspicion and demons.
llm_translation: "Because of the pitfall," and let it emerge for suspicion and damages!

hebrew_text: בִּתְרֵי וּכְשֵׁרֵי.
human_translation: two upstanding individuals
llm_translation: Between two and like two.

hebrew_text: ״מִפְּנֵי הַמַּזִּיקִין״, וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִפְּנֵי חֲשָׁד וּמַפּוֹלֶת!
human_translation: because of demons. Let be derived from suspicion and collapse.
llm_translation: "Because of the harmful spirits," and she should push him away because of suspicion and stumbling!

hebrew_text: בְּחוּרְבָּה חַדְתִּי, וּבִתְרֵי וּכְשֵׁרֵי.
human_translation: new two upstanding
llm_translation: In the sword I trust, and in the arrows and the bow.

hebrew_text: אִי בִּתְרֵי, מַזִּיקִין נָמֵי לֵיכָּא!
human_translation: if there are two people, there is also no demons.
llm_translation: If in between, we cause damage to it!

hebrew_text: בִּמְקוֹמָן חָיְישִׁינַן. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְעוֹלָם בְּחַד, וּבְחוּרְבָּה חַדְתִּי דְּקָאֵי בְּדַבְרָא, דְּהָתָם מִשּׁוּם חֲשָׁד לֵיכָּא דְּהָא אִשָּׁה בְּדַבְרָא לָא שְׁכִיחָא, וּמִשּׁוּם מַזִּיקִין אִיכָּא.
human_translation: in their place, we are concerned And if you wish, say Actually, to an individual a new ruin located in a field. There, there is no suspicion, as a woman in the field is uncommon; However, there is demons.
llm_translation: In their place we are concerned. And if you wish, say: Always with one, and with a new sword that stands in the matter, for there, due to suspicion, it is not common for a woman to be in the matter, and due to harmful spirits, there is.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אַרְבַּע מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי. רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: The Sages taught The night is comprised of four watches; the statement of Rabbi Rabbi Natan says: three
llm_translation: The Sages taught: There are four watches in the night, according to Rabbi. Rabbi Natan says: three.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי נָתָן — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּבֹא גִדְעוֹן וּמֵאָה אִישׁ אֲשֶׁר אִתּוֹ בִּקְצֵה הַמַּחֲנֶה רֹאשׁ הָאַשְׁמֹרֶת הַתִּיכוֹנָה״, תָּנָא: אֵין ״תִּיכוֹנָה״ אֶלָּא שֶׁיֵּשׁ לְפָנֶיהָ וּלְאַחֲרֶיהָ.
human_translation: What is Rabbi Natan’s reasoning? As it is written: “And Gideon, and the one hundred men who were with him, came to the edge of camp at the beginning of the middle watch” It was taught Middle means nothing other than there is one before it and one after it.
llm_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Natan? As it is written: "And Gideon came, and the hundred men that were with him, unto the outermost part of the camp in the beginning of the middle watch." It was taught: "The 'middle' is only that which has before it and after it."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי, מַאי ״תִּיכוֹנָה״ — אַחַת מִן הַתִּיכוֹנָה שֶׁבַּתִּיכוֹנוֹת.
human_translation: And Rabbi what middle one of the middle
llm_translation: Rabbi, what is "Tichonah" - one of the Tichonot in the Tichonot.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי נָתָן מִי כְּתִיב ״תִּיכוֹנָה שֶׁבַּתִּיכוֹנוֹת״? ״תִּיכוֹנָה״ כְּתִיב!
human_translation: And Rabbi Natan is: One of the middle written The middle is written.
llm_translation: Rabbi Natan: Who is it written "Tikunah shebitikunot"? "Tikunah" is written!

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי? אָמַר רַבִּי זְרִיקָא, אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: כָּתוּב אֶחָד אוֹמֵר: ״חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה אָקוּם לְהוֹדוֹת לָךְ עַל מִשְׁפְּטֵי צִדְקֶךָ״, וְכָתוּב אֶחָד אוֹמֵר: ״קִדְּמוּ עֵינַי אַשְׁמוּרוֹת״ הָא כֵּיצַד, אַרְבַּע מִשְׁמָרוֹת הָוֵי הַלַּיְלָה.
human_translation: What is Rabbi reasoning? Rabbi Zerika said Rabbi Ami said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Rabbi One verse says: “At midnight I rise to give thanks for Your righteous laws” and the other verse says: “My eyes forestall the watches, How is it there are four watches in the night
llm_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi's opinion? Rabbi Zerika said, Rabbi Ammi said, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: It is written, one verse says, "At midnight I rise to give thanks to You for Your righteous ordinances," and another verse says, "I anticipate the watches." How so? The night consists of four watches.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי נָתָן, סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: עַד שָׁלֹשׁ שָׁעוֹת, שֶׁכֵּן דֶּרֶךְ מְלָכִים לַעֲמֹוד בְּשָׁלֹשׁ שָׁעוֹת. שֵׁית דְּלֵילְיָא, וְתַרְתֵּי דִּימָמָא, הָווּ לְהוּ שְׁתֵּי מִשְׁמָרוֹת.
human_translation: And Rabbi Natan holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua, for we learned Rabbi Yehoshua says: until the third hour as it is the custom of kings to rise during the third hour. six hours of the night and two hours of the day, two watches.
llm_translation: Rabbi Natan thought like Rabbi Yehoshua. As we learned, Rabbi Yehoshua says: Until three hours, for it is the way of kings to stand for three hours. Six hours of the night and two of the day, they had two shifts.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: מִשְׁמָרָה וּפַלְגָא נָמֵי ״מִשְׁמָרוֹת״ קָרוּ לְהוּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said One and one-half watches are still called watches
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Mishmarah and Palga are indeed called "mishmarot."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי זְרִיקָא, אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: אֵין אוֹמְרִין בִּפְנֵי הַמֵּת אֶלָּא דְּבָרָיו שֶׁל מֵת.
human_translation: Rabbi Zerika said Rabbi Ami said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said Before the dead, one may speak only of matters relating to the dead,
llm_translation: And Rabbi Zerika said, Rabbi Ammi said, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One may only speak in the presence of the deceased the words of the deceased.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כָּהֲנָא: לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה, אֲבָל מִילֵּי דְעָלְמָא לֵית לָן בַּהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: was only said with regard to matters of Torah. other matters, however, is not
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: We only said this regarding matters of Torah, but we do not have it in worldly matters.

hebrew_text: וְאִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כָּהֲנָא לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא [אֲפִילּוּ] בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה וְכָל שֶׁכֵּן מִילֵּי דְעָלְמָא.
human_translation: Others say was said even with regard to matters of Torah, and all the more so with regard to other matters.
llm_translation: And there are those who say: Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said, we only said even in matters of Torah, and all the more so worldly matters.

hebrew_text: וְדָוִד בְּפַלְגָא דְלֵילְיָא הֲוָה קָאֵי? מֵאוּרְתָּא הֲוָה קָאֵי! דִּכְתִיב: ״קִדַּמְתִּי בַנֶּשֶׁף וָאֲשַׁוֵּעָה״, וּמִמַּאי דְּהַאי ״נֶשֶׁף״ אוּרְתָּא הוּא? — דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּנֶשֶׁף בְּעֶרֶב יוֹם בְּאִישׁוֹן לַיְלָה וַאֲפֵלָה״!
human_translation: Did David rise at midnight? He rose in the evening. As it is written: “I rose with the neshef and cried, And how that this neshef is the evening? As it is written: “In the neshef , in the evening of the day, in the blackness of night and the darkness”
llm_translation: And David in the morning was standing in the division of the night? In the morning he was standing! As it is written: "I anticipated the dawn and cried out." And from where do we know that this "dawn" refers to the morning? — As it is written: "At dawn, at the approach of day, in the middle of the night and darkness."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אוֹשַׁעְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי אַחָא: הָכִי קָאָמַר (דָּוִד): מֵעוֹלָם לֹא עָבַר עָלַי חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה בְּשֵׁינָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Oshaya said Rabbi Aḥa said: David said as follows: Midnight never passed me by in my sleep.
llm_translation: Rav Oshaya said, Rabbi Acha said: Thus said (David): "I have never passed midnight in sleep."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר: עַד חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה הָיָה מִתְנַמְנֵם כְּסוּס, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ הָיָה מִתְגַּבֵּר כַּאֲרִי. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: עַד חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה הָיָה עוֹסֵק בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ בְּשִׁירוֹת וְתִשְׁבָּחוֹת.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Until midnight, would doze like a horse, From on, he would gain the strength of a lion. Rav Ashi said: Until midnight, he would study Torah, and from on, songs and praise,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Until midnight, he would doze like a horse, from here and onwards he would be as strong as a lion. Rav Ashi said: Until midnight, he would engage in words of Torah, from here and onwards in songs and praises.

hebrew_text: וְ״נֶשֶׁף״ אוּרְתָּא הוּא? הָא ״נֶשֶׁף״ צַפְרָא הוּא! דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּכֵּם דָּוִד מֵהַנֶּשֶׁף וְעַד הָעֶרֶב לְמָחֳרָתָם״. מַאי לָאו — מִצַּפְרָא וְעַד לֵילְיָא?
human_translation: Does neshef mean evening? Doesn’t neshef mean morning? As it is written: “And David slew them from the neshef until the evening of the next day” Doesn’t from the morning until the night,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And 'neshef' is a species of bird? But 'neshef' is a type of horn! As it is written: 'And David struck them from the neshef until the evening of the next day.' Why not from the morning until the night?" English translation: "And is 'neshef' a bird? But 'neshef' is a horn! As it is written: 'And David struck them from the neshef until the evening of the next day.' Why not from the morning until the night?"

hebrew_text: לָא, מֵאוּרְתָּא וְעַד אוּרְתָּא.
human_translation: No, from evening until evening.
llm_translation: Not from light to light.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, לִכְתּוֹב ״מֵהַנֶּשֶׁף וְעַד הַנֶּשֶׁף״ אוֹ ״מֵהָעֶרֶב וְעַד הָעֶרֶב״!
human_translation: If so, let be written: From the neshef until the neshef , or from the evening until the evening.
llm_translation: If so, to write "from dawn until dawn" or "from evening until evening"!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: תְּרֵי נִשְׁפֵי הָווּ — נְשַׁף לֵילְיָא וְאָתֵי יְמָמָא, נְשַׁף יְמָמָא וְאָתֵי לֵילְיָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: There are two neshef , The night moves [ and the day arrives, and the day moves and the night arrives.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: There were two pairs of twilight periods - the evening twilight comes and the day arrives, the day comes and the evening twilight arrives.

hebrew_text: וְדָוִד מִי הֲוָה יָדַע פַּלְגָא דְּלֵילְיָא אֵימַת? הַשְׁתָּא מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ לָא הֲוָה יָדַע, דִּכְתִיב ״כַּחֲצוֹת הַלַּיְלָה אֲנִי יוֹצֵא בְּתוֹךְ מִצְרָיִם״.
human_translation: Did David know when it was midnight? Even Moses our teacher did not know As it is written About midnight, I will go out into the midst of Egypt”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And David who was knowing the division of the night when? Now Moses our teacher did not know, as it is written, "About midnight I will go out in the midst of Egypt." English translation:

hebrew_text: מַאי ״כַּחֲצוֹת״. אִילֵימָא דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ קוּדְשָׁא בְּרִיךְ הוּא ״כַּחֲצוֹת״ — מִי אִיכָּא סְפֵיקָא קַמֵּי שְׁמַיָּא?! אֶלָּא: דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ (לִמְחַר) ״בַּחֲצוֹת״ (כִּי הַשְׁתָּא), וַאֲתָא אִיהוּ וַאֲמַר ״כַּחֲצוֹת״, אַלְמָא: מְסַפְּקָא לֵיהּ, וְדָוִד הֲוָה יָדַע?!
human_translation: What About midnight? If we say the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself, said: About midnight, to is there doubt before heaven? Rather, God told At midnight, but when came he said: About midnight; apparently was uncertain David knew?
llm_translation: What is "like midnight"? If you say that the Holy One, blessed be He, said "like midnight" - is there any doubt before the heavens?! Rather, he said to him (for the next day) "at midnight" (as it is now), and he came and said "like midnight." This implies that he was uncertain, and David knew?!

hebrew_text: דָּוִד, סִימָנָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר בִּיזְנָא, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא: כִּנּוֹר הָיָה תָּלוּי לְמַעְלָה מִמִּטָּתוֹ שֶׁל דָּוִד, וְכֵיוָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה, בָּא רוּחַ צְפוֹנִית וְנוֹשֶׁבֶת בּוֹ וּמְנַגֵּן מֵאֵלָיו, מִיָּד הָיָה עוֹמֵד וְעוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה עַד שֶׁעָלָה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר. כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָלָה עַמּוּד הַשַּׁחַר נִכְנְסוּ חַכְמֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶצְלוֹ. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אֲדוֹנֵינוּ הַמֶּלֶךְ, עַמְּךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל צְרִיכִין פַּרְנָסָה. אָמַר לָהֶם: לְכוּ וְהִתְפַּרְנְסוּ זֶה מִזֶּה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אֵין הַקּוֹמֶץ מַשְׂבִּיעַ אֶת הָאֲרִי, וְאֵין הַבּוֹר מִתְמַלֵּא מֵחוּלְיָתוֹ. אָמַר לָהֶם: לְכוּ וּפִשְׁטוּ יְדֵיכֶם בִּגְדוּד.
human_translation: David had a sign it was midnight. Rav Aḥa bar Bizna said Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida said: A lyre hung over David’s bed, and once midnight arrived, the northern wind would come and the lyre to play on its own. would immediately rise and study Torah until the first rays of dawn. Once dawn the Sages of Israel entered him They said to him: Our master, the king, your nation requires sustenance. He said: Go and sustain one another, responded to him A single handful does not satisfy a lion, and a pit not filled from its mouth, told them: Go and take up arms with the troops
llm_translation: David had a sign, as Rav Acha bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida: A harp was suspended above David's bed, and when midnight arrived, a northern wind would come and play upon it, causing David to rise and engage in Torah study until the break of dawn. When dawn broke, the sages of Israel would enter to see him. They said to him: "Our lord the king, your people Israel require sustenance." He said to them: "Go and sustain one another." They said to him: "The thorn does not satisfy the lion, and the pit does not fill itself from its own destruction." He said to them: "Go and arm yourselves with weapons."

hebrew_text: מִיָּד יוֹעֲצִים בַּאֲחִיתוֹפֶל, וְנִמְלָכִין בְּסַנְהֶדְרִין, וְשׁוֹאֲלִין בְּאוּרִים וְתוּמִּים.
human_translation: immediately seek advice from Ahitophel and they consult the Sanhedrin And they ask the Urim VeTummim
llm_translation: Immediately they consult with Ahithophel, and they are crowned in the Sanhedrin, and they inquire with Urim and Thummim.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מַאי קְרָא? דִּכְתִיב ״וְאַחֲרֵי אֲחִיתֹפֶל בְּנָיָהוּ בֶּן יְהוֹיָדָע וְאֶבְיָתָר וְשַׂר צָבָא לַמֶּלֶךְ יוֹאָב״.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: what verse As it is written: “And after Ahitophel was Benayahu son of Yehoyada and Evyatar, and the general of the king’s army, Yoav”
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: What is the verse? As it is written, "And after Ahithophel was Benaiah son of Jehoiada and Abiathar, and the general Joab to the king."

hebrew_text: אֲחִיתוֹפֶל — זֶה יוֹעֵץ, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וַעֲצַת אֲחִיתֹפֶל אֲשֶׁר יָעַץ בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם כַּאֲשֶׁר יִשְׁאַל אִישׁ בִּדְבַר הָאֱלֹהִים״.
human_translation: Ahitophel is the adviser and so it says: “Now the counsel of Ahitophel, which he counseled in those days, was as a man who inquires of the word of God;
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Ahithophel - this is a counselor, and so it says: "And the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counseled in those days, was as if a man inquired of the word of God."

hebrew_text: ״בְּנָיָהוּ בֶּן יְהוֹיָדָע״ זֶה סַנְהֶדְרִין, ״וְאֶבְיָתָר״ אֵלּוּ אוּרִים וְתוּמִּים.
human_translation: Benayahu ben Yehoyada the Sanhedrin, Evyatar the Urim VeTummim ,
llm_translation: "Benayahu ben Yehoyada" - this is Sanhedrin, "veAviyatar" - these are Urim and Tumim.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וּבְנָיָהוּ בֶּן יְהוֹיָדָע עַל הַכְּרֵתִי וְעַל הַפְּלֵתִי״. וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָם ״כְּרֵתִי״ וּ״פְלֵתִי״? ״כְּרֵתִי״ שֶׁכּוֹרְתִים דִּבְרֵיהֶם, ״פְּלֵתִי״ שֶׁמּוּפְלָאִים בְּדִבְרֵיהֶם. וְאַחַר כָּךְ ״שַׂר צָבָא לַמֶּלֶךְ יוֹאָב״.
human_translation: And so it says “And Benayahu ben Yehoyada was over the Kereti and over the Peleti ” And why was called Kereti UPeleti ? Kereti they were decisive [ koretim ] in their pronouncements. Peleti their pronouncements were wondrous [ mufla’im ] and thereafter the general of the king’s army, Yoav,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And so he says: "And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and over the Pelethites." And why are they called "Kerethites" and "Pelethites"? "Kerethites" because they cut off their words, "Pelethites" because they are wondrous in their words. And afterwards, "Joab was the commander of the army for the king."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַדָּא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: מַאי קְרָא ״עוּרָה כְבוֹדִי עוּרָה הַנֵּבֶל וְכִנּוֹר אָעִירָה שָּׁחַר״.
human_translation: Rav Yitzḥak bar Adda, and some say Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Idi, said: what verse “Awake, my glory; awake, harp and lyre; I will wake the dawn”
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak bar Adda said, and some say he said in the name of Rav Yitzchak son of Rav Idi: What is the verse "Awake, my glory; awake, harp and lyre, I will awaken the dawn" (Psalms 57:9) referring to?

hebrew_text: רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר: מֹשֶׁה לְעוֹלָם הֲוָה יָדַע, וְדָוִד נָמֵי הֲוָה יָדַע.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: certainly knew and David also knew.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Moses always knew, and David also always knew.

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן דְּדָוִד הֲוָה יָדַע, כִּנּוֹר לְמָה לֵיהּ? לְאִתְּעוֹרֵי מִשִּׁנְתֵּיהּ.
human_translation: If David knew, why did he need the lyre? to wake him from his sleep.
llm_translation: And since David knew, why did he need a lyre? To awaken from his sleep.

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן דְּמֹשֶׁה הֲוָה יָדַע, לְמָה לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר ״כַּחֲצוֹת״? — מֹשֶׁה קָסָבַר: שֶׁמָּא יִטְעוּ אִצְטַגְנִינֵי פַּרְעֹה, וְיֹאמְרוּ ״מֹשֶׁה בַּדַּאי הוּא״. דְּאָמַר מָר: לַמֵּד לְשׁוֹנְךָ לוֹמַר ״אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ״, שֶׁמָּא תִּתְבַּדֶּה וְתֵאָחֵז.
human_translation: since Moses knew why did he say: About midnight, maintained: Lest Pharaoh’s astrologers err they would say: Moses is a liar. articulated by the Master: Accustom your tongue to say: I do not know, lest you become entangled in deceit.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And since Moses knew, why did he need to say "at midnight"? — Moses thought: Perhaps the astrologers of Pharaoh will err, and say, "Moses is an ordinary person." As the Master said: Teach your tongue to say "I do not know," lest you become arrogant and stumble.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: בְּפַלְגָא אוּרְתָּא דִתְלֵיסַר נָגְהֵי אַרְבֵּסַר הֲוָה קָאֵי, וְהָכִי קָאָמַר מֹשֶׁה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: לְמָחָר כַּחֲצוֹת הַלַּיְלָה כִּי הָאִידָּנָא אֲנִי יוֹצֵא בְּתוֹךְ מִצְרָיִם.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: was standing at midnight of the thirteenth, leading into the fourteenth, and Moses told Israel the Holy One, Blessed be He, said tomorrow, like midnight tonight, I will go out into the midst of Egypt.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: In the middle of the fourteenth night, at midnight, was standing, and so Moses said to Israel, "Thus says the Holy One, blessed be He: 'At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt tomorrow.'"

hebrew_text: ״לְדָוִד, שָׁמְרָה נַפְשִׁי כִּי חָסִיד אָנִי״. לֵוִי וְרַבִּי יִצְחָק. חַד אָמַר: כָּךְ אָמַר דָּוִד לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, לֹא חָסִיד אֲנִי? שֶׁכָּל מַלְכֵי מִזְרָח וּמַעֲרָב יְשֵׁנִים עַד שָׁלֹשׁ שָׁעוֹת, וַאֲנִי ״חֲצוֹת לַיְלָה אָקוּם לְהוֹדוֹת לְךָ״.
human_translation: of David…Keep my soul, for I am pious” One said: so said David before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, am I not pious? As all of the kings of the East and the West sleep until the third hour but “At midnight I rise to give thanks”
llm_translation: "To David, 'Guard my soul, for I am a pious one.' Levi and Rabbi Yitzchak. One said: Thus David said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Master of the universe, am I not pious? For all the kings of the east and the west sleep until the third hour, and I, 'At midnight I rise to give thanks to You.'"

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ, כָּךְ אָמַר דָּוִד לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, לֹא חָסִיד אֲנִי? שֶׁכָּל מַלְכֵי מִזְרָח וּמַעֲרָב יוֹשְׁבִים אֲגוּדּוֹת אֲגוּדּוֹת בִּכְבוֹדָם, וַאֲנִי יָדַי מְלוּכְלָכוֹת בְּדָם וּבְשָׁפִיר וּבְשִׁלְיָא כְּדֵי לְטַהֵר אִשָּׁה לְבַעֲלָהּ. וְלֹא עוֹד, אֶלָּא כָּל מָה שֶׁאֲנִי עוֹשֶׂה, אֲנִי נִמְלָךְ בִּמְפִיבֹשֶׁת רַבִּי, וְאוֹמֵר לוֹ: ״מְפִיבֹשֶׁת רַבִּי, יָפֶה דַּנְתִּי? יָפֶה חִייַּבְתִּי? יָפֶה זִכִּיתִי? יָפֶה טִהַרְתִּי? יָפֶה טִמֵּאתִי?״, וְלֹא בּוֹשְׁתִּי.
human_translation: And the other David said the following before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, am I not pious? For all of the kings of the East and the West sit in groups their honored my hands become soiled with blood and a fetus that miscarried and placenta, in order to render a woman ritually pure to her husband. And not only but I consult my teacher, Mefivoshet, everything that I do. I say to him: Mefivoshet, my teacher, did I decide properly? Did I convict properly? Did I acquit properly? Did I rule pure properly? Did I rule impure properly? And I was not embarrassed.
llm_translation: The other opinion is as follows: So said David before the Holy One, blessed be He: Master of the Universe, am I not a pious person? For all the kings of the east and the west sit in their glory, each in their honor, and I am engaged in blood, and in feathers, and in entrails, in order to purify a woman for her husband. And not only that, but everything that I do, I am judged by Mephibosheth the son of Rabbah, and I say to him: "Mephibosheth, son of Rabbah, have I judged well? Have I obligated well? Have I acquitted well? Have I purified well? Have I defiled well?" And I am not ashamed.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: מַאי קְרָא — ״וַאֲדַבְּרָה בְעֵדֹתֶיךָ נֶגֶד מְלָכִים וְלֹא אֵבוֹשׁ״.
human_translation: Rav Yehoshua, son of Rav Idi, said: What verse “And I speak Your testimonies before kings and I will not be ashamed”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua, son of Rav Idi, said: What is the verse? "And I will speak of Your testimonies before kings, and I will not be ashamed."

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: לֹא ״מְפִיבֹשֶׁת״ שְׁמוֹ, אֶלָּא ״אִישׁ בּשֶׁת״ שְׁמוֹ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ מְפִיבֹשֶׁת? שֶׁהָיָה מְבַיֵּישׁ פְּנֵי דָּוִד בַּהֲלָכָה, לְפִיכָךְ זָכָה דָּוִד וְיָצָא מִמֶּנּוּ כִּלְאָב.
human_translation: It was taught His name was not Mefivoshet, but rather Ish Boshet was his name. Why was referred to as Mefivoshet? Because he would embarrass [ mevayesh ] David in matters of halakha Because he merited that Kilav, would descend from him.
llm_translation: Mishna: His name is not "Mephibosheth," rather "Ish Bosheth" is his name. And why is he called Mephibosheth? Because he embarrassed the face of David in a halachic matter. Therefore, David merited and emerged from him like a father.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא ״כִּלְאָב״ שְׁמוֹ אֶלָּא ״דָּנִיאֵל״ שְׁמוֹ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ ״כִּלְאָב״ — שֶׁהָיָה מַכְלִים פְּנֵי מְפִיבֹשֶׁת בַּהֲלָכָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: His name was not Kilav; rather, his name was Daniel, Why was he called Kilav? Because he would embarrass [ makhlim ] Mefivoshet, in matters of halakha.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said: Not "Kilav" is his name, rather "Daniel" is his name, and why was he called by the name "Kilav" - because he would silence the face of Mephibosheth in halacha.

hebrew_text: וְעָלָיו אָמַר שְׁלֹמֹה בְּחָכְמָתוֹ ״בְּנִי אִם חָכַם לִבֶּךָ יִשְׂמַח לִבִּי גַם אָנִי״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״חֲכַם בְּנִי וְשַׂמַּח לִבִּי וְאָשִׁיבָה חֹרְפִי דָבָר״.
human_translation: In his wisdom, Solomon said “My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will be glad, even mine” And says “Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad, that I may respond to those who taunt me”
llm_translation: And upon it, Solomon said in his wisdom, "My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will rejoice too." And he also said, "My son is wise, and my heart will rejoice, and I will return a taunt's word."

hebrew_text: וְדָוִד מִי קָרֵי לְנַפְשֵׁיהּ ״חָסִיד״? וְהָכְתִיב ״לוּלֵא הֶאֱמַנְתִּי לִרְאוֹת בְּטוּב ה׳ בְּאֶרֶץ חַיִּים״, וְתָנָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי: לָמָּה נָקוּד עַל ״לוּלֵא״? — אָמַר דָּוִד לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, מוּבְטָח אֲנִי בְּךָ שֶׁאַתָּה מְשַׁלֵּם שָׂכָר טוֹב לַצַּדִּיקִים לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ אִם יֵשׁ לִי חֵלֶק בֵּינֵיהֶם אִם לָאו?!
human_translation: Did David call himself pious? Isn’t it written: “If I had not [ luleh believed to look upon the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living” In the name of Rabbi Yosei, it was taught Why dots over the word luleh , David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe. I confidence in You that You grant an excellent reward to the righteous in the World-to-Come but I do not know whether or not I have a portion among them.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And David, who calls himself "חָסִיד"? And it is written, "Had I not believed to see the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living." And a Tanna taught in the name of Rabbi Yosei: Why is a dot placed over "לוּלֵא"? — David said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Master of the Universe, I am confident in You that You will reward the righteous in the future, but I do not know if I have a share among them or not?!

hebrew_text: שֶׁמָּא יִגְרוֹם הַחֵטְא.
human_translation: lest a transgression will cause
llm_translation: Perhaps will cause the sin.

hebrew_text: כִּדְרַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בַּר אִידִי, דְּרַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בַּר אִידִי רָמֵי, כְּתִיב: ״וְהִנֵּה אָנֹכִי עִמָּךְ וּשְׁמַרְתִּיךָ בְּכָל אֲשֶׁר תֵּלֵךְ״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּירָא יַעֲקֹב מְאֹד״ אָמַר: שֶׁמָּא יִגְרוֹם הַחֵטְא.
human_translation: in accordance with Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi, as Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi raised a contradiction It is written “Behold, I am with you and I guard you wherever you go” it is written: “And Jacob became very afraid, said Lest a transgression will cause
llm_translation: As Rabbi Yaakov bar Idi said, Rabbi Yaakov bar Idi raised a contradiction: It is written, "Behold, I am with you and will keep you wherever you go," and it is written, "And Yaakov was very afraid." He said: Perhaps sin will cause harm.

hebrew_text: כִּדְתַנְיָא ״עַד יַעֲבֹר עַמְּךָ ה׳, עַד יַעֲבֹר עַם זוּ קָנִיתָ״.
human_translation: as it was taught “Until Your people will cross, Lord, until the people You have acquired will cross.
llm_translation: As it was taught: "Until your people pass, O Lord, until this people whom You have acquired pass."

hebrew_text: ״עַד יַעֲבֹר עַמְּךָ ה׳״ — זוֹ בִּיאָה רִאשׁוֹנָה, ״עַד יַעֲבֹר עַם זוּ קָנִיתָ״ — זוֹ בִּיאָה שְׁנִיָּה. מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים: רְאוּיִם הָיוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל לֵיעָשׂוֹת לָהֶם נֵס בִּימֵי עֶזְרָא כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה לָהֶם בִּימֵי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בִּן נוּן. אֶלָּא שֶׁגָּרַם הַחֵטְא.
human_translation: until Your people will cross first entry until the people You have acquired pass over second entry Based on the Sages said: Israel was worthy of having a miracle performed on its in the time of Ezra as was performed on their in the time of Joshua bin Nun. However, transgression caused
llm_translation: "Until your people, Hashem, pass" — this is first intercourse, "Until this people pass, you have acquired" — this is second intercourse. From here the sages said: The Israelites were deserving to have a miracle performed for them in the days of Ezra, as was done for them in the days of Joshua son of Nun. However, sin caused it not to happen.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים עַד חֲצוֹת: חֲכָמִים כְּמַאן סְבִירָא לְהוּ, אִי כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר סְבִירָא לְהוּ — לֵימְרוּ כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: until midnight. In accordance with whose do they hold If in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer, let say in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer,
llm_translation: The sages say until midnight: The sages, according to whom do they hold? If according to Rabbi Eliezer they hold — let them say according to Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל סְבִירָא לְהוּ — לֵימְרוּ כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל.
human_translation: And if in accordance with Rabban Gamliel let say in accordance with Rabban Gamliel.
llm_translation: And if like Rabban Gamliel, they hold - let them say like Rabban Gamliel.

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל סְבִירָא לְהוּ, וְהָא דְּקָא אָמְרִי ״עַד חֲצוֹת״, כְּדֵי לְהַרְחִיק אֶת הָאָדָם מִן הָעֲבֵירָה. כִּדְתַנְיָא, חֲכָמִים עָשׂוּ סְיָיג לְדִבְרֵיהֶם, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא אָדָם בָּא מִן הַשָּׂדֶה בָּעֶרֶב, וְאוֹמֵר: ״אֵלֵךְ לְבֵיתִי וְאוֹכַל קִימְעָא וְאֶשְׁתֶּה קִימְעָא, וְאִישַׁן קִימְעָא, וְאַחַר כָּךְ אֶקְרָא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וְאֶתְפַּלֵּל״, וְחוֹטַפְתּוֹ שֵׁינָה וְנִמְצָא יָשֵׁן כָּל הַלַּיְלָה. אֲבָל אָדָם בָּא מִן הַשָּׂדֶה בָּעֶרֶב, נִכְנָס לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת, אִם רָגִיל לִקְרוֹת — קוֹרֵא. וְאִם רָגִיל לִשְׁנוֹת — שׁוֹנֶה, וְקוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִתְפַּלֵּל, וְאוֹכֵל פִּתּוֹ וּמְבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: Actually, hold in accordance with Rabban Gamliel, that they say until midnight is to distance a person from transgression. As it was taught the Rabbis created a “fence” for their pronouncements in order to prevent a person comes home from the field in the evening, says I will go home, eat a little, drink a little, sleep a little and then I will recite and recite he is overcome by sleep and ends up sleeping all night. However, he will come from the field in the evening, enter the synagogue, If he is accustomed to reading the Bible, he reads. If he is accustomed to learning he learns. And he recites and prays he eats his meal and recites a blessing.
llm_translation: Always like Rabban Gamliel opinion to him, and this that they said "until midnight," in order to distance the person from transgression. As it was taught, the sages made a protective measure for their words, so that a person should not come from the field in the evening and say, "I will go to my house, eat a loaf and drink a cup, sleep a little, and afterwards I will recite the Shema and pray," and sleep overtakes him and he ends up sleeping all night. But if a person comes from the field in the evening, enters the synagogue, if he is accustomed to read - he reads. And if he is accustomed to repeat - he repeats, and he recites the Shema and prays, and eats his bread and blesses.

hebrew_text: וְכָל הָעוֹבֵר עַל דִּבְרֵי חֲכָמִים חַיָּיב מִיתָה.
human_translation: Anyone who transgresses the pronouncements of the Sages is liable to death
llm_translation: And all who transgress the words of the sages is liable to death.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא בְּכָל דּוּכְתָּא דְּלָא קָתָנֵי ״חַיָּיב מִיתָה״, וּמַאי שְׁנָא הָכָא דְּקָתָנֵי ״חַיָּיב מִיתָה״?
human_translation: What is different in all places that it is not taught that one is liable the death penalty and what is different here that it is taught that he is liable to death penalty?
llm_translation: What is different in every place where it does not teach "liable to death," and what is different here where it does teach "liable to death"?

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיכָּא אוֹנֶס שֵׁינָה. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְאַפּוֹקֵי מִמַּאן דְּאָמַר ״תְּפִלַּת עַרְבִית רְשׁוּת״, קָא מַשְׁמַע לָן דְּחוֹבָה.
human_translation: If you wish, say overcome by sleep, And if you wish, say to exclude he who says that the evening prayer is optional. it teaches us is mandatory,
llm_translation: If you will say the reason for reciting the evening prayer is because there is a possibility of falling asleep. And if you will say: to fulfill the opinion of the one who said, "The evening prayer is optional," it implies to us that it is obligatory.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר, קוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִתְפַּלֵּל. מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֵיזֶהוּ בֶּן הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא — זֶה הַסּוֹמֵךְ גְּאוּלָּה לִתְפִלָּה שֶׁל עַרְבִית. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי אוֹמֵר: תְּפִלּוֹת בָּאֶמְצַע תִּקְּנוּם.
human_translation: the Master said recites Shema , and prays. supports Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who of the World-to-Come? It is who juxtaposes redemption, to the evening prayer. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: The prayers were instituted between
llm_translation: Master said, one reads the Shema and prays. He assists Rabbi Yochanan. For Rabbi Yochanan said: Who is the son of the world to come? — This is one who connects redemption to the evening prayer. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: They established the prayers in the middle.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי קָא מִפַּלְּגִי?
human_translation: With regard to what do they disagree?
llm_translation: With what does he divide?

hebrew_text: אִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא קְרָא, אִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא סְבָרָא.
human_translation: If you wish, say a verse; if you wish, say logic.
llm_translation: If you wish, say Scripture; if you wish, say reasoning.

hebrew_text: אִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא סְבָרָא.
human_translation: If you say logic,
llm_translation: If you wish, say a reason.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר גְּאוּלָּה מֵאוּרְתָּא נָמֵי הָוֵי, אֶלָּא גְּאוּלָּה מְעַלַּיְיתָא לָא הָוְיָא אֶלָּא עַד צַפְרָא. וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי סָבַר כֵּיוָן דְּלָא הָוְיָא אֶלָּא מִצַּפְרָא — לָא הָוְיָא גְּאוּלָּה מְעַלַּיְיתָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan holds: Redemption occurred in the evening as well; the full-fledged redemption was only in the morning. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, holds: Since only occurred in the morning, was not a full-fledged redemption,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan holds that redemption from Urtah is effective, but redemption from Me'alyata is not effective until Zafra. And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi holds that since it is not effective until Zafra, redemption from Me'alyata is not effective.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא קְרָא, וּשְׁנֵיהֶם מִקְרָא אֶחָד דָּרְשׁוּ, דִּכְתִיב ״בְּשָׁכְבְּךָ וּבְקוּמֶךָ״.
human_translation: And if you wish, say a verse. Both derived their opinions from the same verse: “When you lie down, and when you rise.”
llm_translation: And if you will say, let us look at the verse, and both of them interpreted one verse, as it is written, "when you lie down and when you rise up."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר: מַקִּישׁ שְׁכִיבָה לְקִימָה, מָה קִימָה — קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וְאַחַר כָּךְ תְּפִלָּה, אַף שְׁכִיבָה נָמֵי — קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וְאַחַר כָּךְ תְּפִלָּה. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי סָבַר: מַקִּישׁ שְׁכִיבָה לְקִימָה: מָה קִימָה — קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע סָמוּךְ לְמִטָּתוֹ, אַף שְׁכִיבָה נָמֵי — קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע סָמוּךְ לְמִטָּתוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan holds: juxtaposes lying down and rising. Just as when one rises, the recitation of is followed by prayer, so too, when one lies down, the recitation of is followed by prayer. And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi maintains: juxtaposes lying down and rising Just as when one rises, adjacent to his bed, so too when one lies down, he recites adjacent to his bed.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan holds: He compares lying down to standing. Just as standing is followed by the Shema and afterwards the Amidah, so too lying down is followed by the Shema and afterwards the Amidah. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi holds: He compares lying down to standing. Just as standing is followed by the Shema close to his bed, so too lying down is followed by the Shema close to his bed.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב מָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא, בָּעֶרֶב מְבָרֵךְ שְׁתַּיִם לְפָנֶיהָ וּשְׁתַּיִם לְאַחֲרֶיהָ. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ בָּעֵי לִסְמוֹךְ, הָא לָא קָא סָמֵךְ גְּאוּלָּה לִתְפִלָּה, דְּהָא בָּעֵי לְמֵימַר ״הַשְׁכִּיבֵנוּ״!
human_translation: Mar, son of Ravina, raises an objection In the evening, one recites two prior to and two afterward. And if you say one must juxtapose doesn’t he fail to juxtapose redemption to prayer, as he must recite: Help us lie down [ hashkivenu ],
llm_translation: The Master, son of Ravina, raises an objection: In the evening, one recites two blessings before it and two blessings after it. And if you say that he wants to connect them, behold, he is not connecting redemption to prayer, for he should have said "lay us down"!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: כֵּיוָן דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן ״הַשְׁכִּיבֵנוּ״ — כִּגְאוּלָּה אֲרִיכְתָּא דָּמְיָא. דְּאִי לָא תֵּימָא הָכִי, שַׁחֲרִית הֵיכִי מָצֵי סָמֵיךְ? וְהָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בַּתְּחִלָּה אוֹמֵר: ״ה׳ שְׂפָתַי תִּפְתָּח״, וּלְבַסּוֹף הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״יִהְיוּ לְרָצוֹן אִמְרֵי פִי״.
human_translation: They say Since the Sages instituted Help us lie down, it is considered one extended blessing of redemption, As if you fail to say then can one juxtapose redemption to prayer in the morning? Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Before one recites “Lord, open my lips, that my mouth may declare Your glory” Afterward, one recites “May the words of my mouth and the meditations of my heart be acceptable before You”
llm_translation: They said: Since the Rabbis instituted "Hashkiveinu" - it is like the length of redemption. For if you don't say so, how can you find a close connection in the morning? And Rabbi Yochanan said: At the beginning one says, "O Lord, open my lips," and in the end, he says, "May the sayings of my mouth be acceptable."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָתָם כֵּיוָן דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן לְמֵימַר ״ה׳ שְׂפָתַי תִּפְתָּח״ — כִּתְפִלָּה אֲרִיכְתָּא דָּמְיָא. הָכָא נָמֵי, כֵּיוָן דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן לְמֵימַר ״הַשְׁכִּיבֵנוּ״ — כִּגְאוּלָּה אֲרִיכְתָּא דָּמְיָא.
human_translation: Rather, there, since the Sages instituted recite: Lord, open my lips, it is considered as an extended prayer Here, too, since the Sages instituted to recite Help us lie down, it is considered as one extended redemption.
llm_translation: Rather, there, since the Rabbis established to say "O Lord, open my lips" — it is like a lengthy prayer. Here, too, since the Rabbis established to say "Cause us to lie down" — it is like a lengthy redemption.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבִינָא: כָּל הָאוֹמֵר ״תְּהִלָּה לְדָוִד״ בְּכָל יוֹם שָׁלֹשׁ פְּעָמִים — מוּבְטָח לוֹ שֶׁהוּא בֶּן הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said Rabbi Avina said: Anyone who recites: “A Psalm of David” three times every day is assured of the World-to-Come.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Elazar, said Rabbi Avina: Anyone who says "Praise for David" three times every day is guaranteed that he is a son of the World to Come.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא?
human_translation: What is the reason
llm_translation: What is the reason?

hebrew_text: אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאָתְיָא בְּאָלֶף בֵּית, נֵימָא ״אַשְׁרֵי תְמִימֵי דָרֶךְ״ דְּאָתְיָא בִּתְמָנְיָא אַפִּין.
human_translation: If you say that it is because it is arranged alphabetically, let us say: “Happy are they who are upright in the way” where appears eight times
llm_translation: The text reads: "Ileima mishum de'ateya be'alef beit, neima 'ashrei temimei derech' de'ateya bitmanya appin." Translation: Perhaps because it comes with an aleph bet, it should be said "fortunate are those of a blameless way" which comes with eight faces.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִית בֵּיהּ ״פּוֹתֵחַ אֶת יָדֶךָ״, נֵימָא ״הַלֵּל הַגָּדוֹל״ דִּכְתִיב בֵּיהּ ״נֹתֵן לֶחֶם לְכָל בָּשָׂר״.
human_translation: Rather, because it contains “You open Your hand let him recite the great hallel in which written, “Who provides food to all flesh,
llm_translation: Rather, because it contains the phrase "you open your hand," let us say it is referring to "Hillel the Elder," as it is written about him, "He gives bread to all flesh."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִית בֵּיהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: Rather, is because it contains both
llm_translation: Rather, because there are two in it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִפְּנֵי מָה לֹא נֶאֱמַר נוּן בְּ״אַשְׁרֵי״ — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ מַפַּלְתָּן שֶׁל שׂוֹנְאֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, דִּכְתִיב: ״נָפְלָה לֹא תוֹסִיף קוּם בְּתוּלַת יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Why is there no nun in ashrei ? Because it contains the downfall of the enemies of Israel, As it is written: “The virgin of Israel has fallen and she will rise no more;
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Why is the letter "nun" not mentioned in the word "ashrei"? Because it contains the downfall of those who hate Israel, as it is written: "She has fallen, she will not rise again, the virgin of Israel."

hebrew_text: בְּמַעְרְבָא מְתָרְצִי לַהּ הָכִי: ״נָפְלָה וְלֹא תּוֹסִיף לִנְפּוֹל עוֹד, קוּם בְּתוּלַת יִשְׂרָאֵל״. אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי, חָזַר דָּוִד וּסְמָכָן בְּרוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״סוֹמֵךְ ה׳ לְכָל הַנֹּפְלִים״.
human_translation: in the West, they interpreted it “She has fallen but she shall fall no more; rise, virgin of Israel.” Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak Even so, David went and support, through divine inspiration. “The Lord upholds the fallen
llm_translation: In the west, they interpreted it thus: "She fell and will not continue to fall further, rise up, O virgin of Israel." Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: Even so, David reconsidered and relied on the Holy Spirit, as it is said, "The Lord supports all who fall."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בַּר אֲבִינָא: גָּדוֹל מַה שֶּׁנֶּאֱמַר בְּמִיכָאֵל יוֹתֵר מִמַּה שֶּׁנֶּאֱמַר בְּגַבְרִיאֵל, דְּאִילּוּ בְּמִיכָאֵל כְּתִיב: ״וַיָּעׇף אֵלַי אֶחָד מִן הַשְּׂרָפִים״. וְאִילּוּ גַּבֵּי גַבְרִיאֵל כְּתִיב: ״וְהָאִישׁ גַּבְרִיאֵל אֲשֶׁר רָאִיתִי בֶחָזוֹן בַּתְּחִלָּה מֻעָף בִּיעָף וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar bar Avina said: What was said about Michael is greater than what was said about Gabriel. As about Michael, it is written: “And one of the seraphim flew to me” regarding Gabriel, it is written: “The man, Gabriel, whom I had seen at the beginning, in a vision, being caused to fly swiftly,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar son of Avina said: Great is what is said about Michael more than what is said about Gabriel, for in the case of Michael it is written: "And one of the seraphim flew to me." Whereas in the case of Gabriel it is written: "And the man Gabriel, whom I saw in the vision at the beginning, being caused to fly swiftly."

hebrew_text: מַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״אֶחָד״ מִיכָאֵל הוּא?
human_translation: From where is it inferred that the one is Michael?
llm_translation: What is the implication that this "one" is Michael?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אַתְיָא ״אֶחָד״ ״אֶחָד״. כְּתִיב הָכָא ״וַיָּעׇף אֵלַי אֶחָד מִן הַשְּׂרָפִים״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״וְהִנֵּה מִיכָאֵל אֶחָד (מִן) הַשָּׂרִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים בָּא לְעָזְרֵנִי״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This is derived one and one. Here, it is written: “And one of the seraphim flew to me” and there, it is written: “And behold, Michael, one of the chief ministers of the king, came to my aid”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: It is written "one" "one" here. It is written here "and one of the seraphim flew to me," and it is written there: "And behold, Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me."

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: מִיכָאֵל — בְּאַחַת, גַּבְרִיאֵל — בִּשְׁתַּיִם, אֵלִיָּהוּ — בְּאַרְבַּע, וּמַלְאַךְ הַמָּוֶת — בִּשְׁמֹנֶה. וּבִשְׁעַת הַמַּגֵּפָה, בְּאֶחָת.
human_translation: It was taught Michael, in one Gabriel, in two Elijah in four and the Angel of Death, in eight During a time of plague, in one
llm_translation: The text states: "It was taught: Michael - in one, Gabriel - in two, Elijah - in four, and the Angel of Death - in eight. And during a plague, in one."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁקָּרָא אָדָם קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת — מִצְוָה לִקְרוֹתוֹ עַל מִטָּתוֹ. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: מַאי קְרָא — ״רִגְזוּ וְאַל תֶּחֱטָאוּ אִמְרוּ בִלְבַבְכֶם עַל מִשְׁכַּבְכֶם וְדֹמּוּ סֶלָה״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Even though one recited Shema in the synagogue, it is a mitzva to recite it upon his bed Rabbi Yosei said: What verse “Tremble, and do not sin; say to your heart upon your bed and be still, Selah”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Even though a person recites the Shema in the synagogue, it is a mitzvah to recite it upon his bed. Rabbi Yosei said: What is the verse? "Tremble and do not sin; say in your hearts upon your beds, and be silent. Selah."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן:
human_translation: Rabbi Naḥman said:
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said:

hebrew_text: אִם תַּלְמִיד חָכָם הוּא — אֵין צָרִיךְ. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אַף תַּלְמִיד חָכָם מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר חַד פְּסוּקָא דְרַחֲמֵי, כְּגוֹן: ״בְּיָדְךָ אַפְקִיד רוּחִי, פָּדִיתָה אוֹתִי ה׳ אֵל אֱמֶת״.
human_translation: If one is a Torah scholar, he need not Abaye said: Even a Torah scholar must recite at least one verse of prayer, such as: “Into Your hand I trust my spirit; You have redeemed me, Lord, God of truth”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If a scholar he is — not needed. Said Abbaye: Also a scholar requires to him to say one verse of mercy, such as: "Into Your hand I commit my spirit; You have redeemed me, O Lord, God of truth."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי בַּר חָמָא, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ: לְעוֹלָם יַרְגִּיז אָדָם יֵצֶר טוֹב עַל יֵצֶר הָרַע, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״רִגְזוּ וְאַל תֶּחֱטָאוּ״ אִם נִצְּחוֹ — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — יַעֲסוֹק בַּתּוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִמְרוּ בִלְבַבְכֶם״. אִם נִצְּחוֹ — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — יִקְרָא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״עַל מִשְׁכַּבְכֶם״. אִם נִצְּחוֹ — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — יִזְכּוֹר לוֹ יוֹם הַמִּיתָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְדֹמּוּ סֶלָה״.
human_translation: Rabbi Levi bar Ḥama said Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One should always incite his good inclination against his evil inclination, as it is stated: "Tremble, and do not sin." If subdues excellent, if not study Torah, the verse: “Say to your heart.” If subdues excellent; if not, he should recite Shema , as it is stated “Upon your bed,” If subdues excellent; if not, he should remind himself of the day of death, the verse: “And be still, Selah.”
llm_translation: Rabbi Levi bar Ḥama said, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: A person should always provoke his good inclination against his evil inclination, as it is stated: "Tremble, and do not sin." If he overcomes it—good; but if not, let him engage in Torah study, as it is stated: "Say in your hearts." If he overcomes it—good; but if not, let him recite the Shema, as it is stated: "Upon your beds." If he overcomes it—good; but if not, let him remember the day of death, as it is stated: "And be still."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי בַּר חָמָא, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ, מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וְאֶתְּנָה לְךָ אֶת לֻחֹת הָאֶבֶן וְהַתּוֹרָה וְהַמִּצְוָה אֲשֶׁר כָּתַבְתִּי לְהוֹרֹתָם״. ״לֻחֹת״ — אֵלּוּ עֲשֶׂרֶת הַדִּבְּרוֹת, ״תּוֹרָה״ — זֶה מִקְרָא, ״וְהַמִּצְוָה״ — זוֹ מִשְׁנָה, ״אֲשֶׁר כָּתַבְתִּי״ — אֵלּוּ נְבִיאִים וּכְתוּבִים, ״לְהוֹרוֹתָם״ — זֶה תַּלְמוּד, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁכּוּלָּם נִתְּנוּ לְמֹשֶׁה מִסִּינַי.
human_translation: And Rabbi Levi bar Ḥama said Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: and I will give you the stone tablets and the Torah and the mitzva that I have written that you may teach them” The “tablets” are the ten commandments the “Torah” is the five books of Moses. The “mitzva” is the Mishna, “That I have written” refers to the Prophets and Writings, “That you may teach them” refers to the Talmud, teaches all were given to from Sinai.
