llm_translation: "The one who reads for the one who is negligent has not fulfilled his obligation, and so on."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַמֵּי וְרַבִּי אַסִּי הֲווֹ קָא קָטְרִין לֵיהּ גְּנָנָא לְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר. אֲמַר לְהוּ: אַדְּהָכִי וְהָכִי אֵיזִיל וְאֶשְׁמַע מִלְּתָא דְבֵי מִדְרְשָׁא, וְאֵיתֵי וְאֵימָא לְכוּ. אֲזַל אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְתַנָּא דְּקָתָנֵי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן:
human_translation: Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi were once tying a wedding canopy for Rabbi Elazar. He said to them: In the meantime, I will go and hear something in the study hall, and I will come and say it to you. He went and found the tanna who was reciting before Rabbi Yoḥanan:
llm_translation: Rabbi Ammi and Rabbi Assi were offering incense to Rabbi Elazar. He said to them: "Until now, I would go and hear a matter from the study hall, and then come and tell you." He went and found it written in a Mishnah before Rabbi Yochanan.

hebrew_text: קָרָא וְטָעָה וְאֵינוֹ יוֹדֵעַ לְהֵיכָן טָעָה, בְּאֶמְצַע הַפֶּרֶק — יַחְזוֹר לָרֹאשׁ. בֵּין פֶּרֶק לְפֶרֶק — יַחְזוֹר לְפֶרֶק רִאשׁוֹן. בֵּין כְּתִיבָה לִכְתִיבָה — יַחְזוֹר לִכְתִיבָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: One who recited and erred, and does not know where he erred; in the middle of a paragraph he must return to the beginning if between one paragraph and another he must return to the first paragraphs. if one erred between writing and writing, he must return to the first writing.
llm_translation: He read and erred and does not know where he erred, in the middle of the chapter — he should go back to the beginning. Between one chapter and another — he should go back to the first chapter. Between one writing and another — he should go back to the first writing.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁלֹּא פָּתַח בִּ״לְמַעַן יִרְבּוּ יְמֵיכֶם״, אֲבָל פָּתַח בִּ״לְמַעַן יִרְבּוּ יְמֵיכֶם״ — סִרְכֵיהּ נָקֵט וְאָתֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: They only taught where one did not begin: “In order to lengthen your days” However, if he began In order to lengthen your days, he assumed his routine and continued
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yochanan: They only taught that one should not begin with "in order that your days may be multiplied," but if one begins with "in order that your days may be multiplied" — his efforts are cut off and he comes.

hebrew_text: אֲתָא וַאֲמַר לְהוּ. אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: אִלּוּ לֹא בָּאנוּ אֶלָּא לִשְׁמוֹעַ דָּבָר זֶה — דַּיֵּינוּ.
human_translation: came and told They said to him: Had we come only to hear this, it would have been sufficient.
llm_translation: He came and said to them. They said to him: If we had only come to hear this matter - it would have been enough for us.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוּמָּנִין — קוֹרִין בְּרֹאשׁ הָאִילָן וּבְרֹאשׁ הַנִּדְבָּךְ. מַה שֶּׁאֵינָן רַשָּׁאִין לַעֲשׂוֹת כֵּן בַּתְּפִלָּה.
human_translation: Laborers recite atop the tree or atop the course of stones which they are not permitted to do for prayer,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Craftsmen - they read at the top of the tree and at the top of the altar. Just as they are not permitted to do so in prayer."

hebrew_text: חָתָן פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה וְעַד מוֹצָאֵי שַׁבָּת אִם לֹא עָשָׂה מַעֲשֶׂה. וּמַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל שֶׁנָּשָׂא אִשָּׁה וְקָרָא לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ תַּלְמִידָיו: לִמַּדְתָּנוּ רַבֵּינוּ שֶׁחָתָן פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע? אָמַר לָהֶם אֵינִי שׁוֹמֵעַ לָכֶם לְבַטֵּל הֵימֶנִי מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם אֲפִילּוּ שָׁעָה אַחַת.
human_translation: A groom is exempt from the recitation of Shema on the first night until Saturday night, if he has not taken action there was an incident where Rabban Gamliel married a woman and recited the first night. His students said to him: Didn’t our teacher teach us that a groom is exempt from the recitation of Shema ? He answered them: I am not listening to you preclude myself from the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven, for even one moment.
llm_translation: The groom is exempt from reciting the Shema on the first night until the end of Shabbat if he has not consummated the marriage. And it happened with Rabban Gamliel that he married a woman and recited on the first night. His disciples said to him: Did you teach us, our master, that a groom is exempt from reciting the Shema? He said to them: I do not listen to you to nullify from me the Kingdom of Heaven even for one hour.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָאוּמָּנִין — קוֹרִין בְּרֹאשׁ הָאִילָן וּבְרֹאשׁ הַנִּדְבָּךְ. וּמִתְפַּלְּלִין בְּרֹאשׁ הַזַּיִת וּבְרֹאשׁ הַתְּאֵנָה. וּשְׁאָר כָּל הָאִילָנוֹת — יוֹרְדִים לְמַטָּה וּמִתְפַּלְּלִין. וּבַעַל הַבַּיִת, בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ יוֹרֵד לְמַטָּה וּמִתְפַּלֵּל, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין דַּעְתּוֹ מְיוּשֶּׁבֶת עָלָיו.
human_translation: the Sages taught Laborers, recite atop the tree or atop the course of stones And they pray atop the olive tree or the fig tree, all the rest of the trees, they must climb down and pray. the homeowner, in all cases, must climb down and pray, as he will be unable to focus appropriately.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Craftsmen - read at the top of the palm tree and at the top of the tower. And pray at the top of the olive tree and at the top of the fig tree. And all other palm trees - descend below and pray. And the homeowner, whether this way or that way, descends below and prays, because his mind is not settled upon him.

hebrew_text: רָמֵי לֵיהּ רַב מָרִי בְּרַהּ דְּבַת שְׁמוּאֵל לְרָבָא, תְּנַן: הָאוּמָּנִין קוֹרִין בְּרֹאשׁ הָאִילָן וּבְרֹאשׁ הַנִּדְבָּךְ, אַלְמָא לָא בָּעֵי כַּוָּנָה. וּרְמִינְהִי: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע צָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּכַוֵּין אֶת לִבּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הַסְכֵּת וּשְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״. מַה לְּהַלָּן בְּ״הַסְכֵּת״ אַף כָּאן בְּ״הַסְכֵּת״.
human_translation: Rav Mari, son of the daughter of Shmuel, raised a contradiction before Rava: We learned Laborers may recite atop the tree or atop the course of stones We see that he does not require intent, And he raised a contradiction One who recites Shema must focus his heart, as it is stated: “Hear [ Shema ], Israel.” And below, it says: “Pay attention, and hear [ shema ], Israel” Just as there pay attention, so too here pay attention.
llm_translation: Rav Mari, son of Rava, raised an objection to Rava: We learned in a Mishnah: The craftsmen may recite the Shema at the beginning of the day and at the beginning of the afternoon prayer service, indicating that intent is not necessary. And we raised a dilemma: One who recites the Shema must focus his heart, as it is stated: "Hear, O Israel." And elsewhere it says: "Be silent and hear, O Israel." Just as there, in the word "be silent," intent is required, so too here, in the word "be silent," intent is required.

hebrew_text: אִשְׁתִּיק. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִידֵּי שְׁמִיעַ לָךְ בְּהָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָכִי אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת — וְהוּא שֶׁבְּטֵלִין מִמְּלַאכְתָּן וְקוֹרִין.
human_translation: was silent he said to him: Have you heard anything on this He replied: Rav Sheshet said as follows: And this when they are idle from their work and recite
llm_translation: He was silent. He said to him: Have you heard this from someone? He said to him: This is what Rav Sheshet said - and they are idle from their work and reading.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים עוֹסְקִים בִּמְלַאכְתָּן וְקוֹרִין!
human_translation: But wasn’t it taught Beit Hillel say: engage in their labor and recite
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: Beit Hillel say, "Engage in your work and read!"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּפֶרֶק רִאשׁוֹן, הָא בְּפֶרֶק שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: This is not difficult. This, the first paragraph while that, the second paragraph.
llm_translation: Not difficult: this in the first chapter, this in the second chapter.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַפּוֹעֲלִים שֶׁהָיוּ עוֹשִׂין מְלָאכָה אֵצֶל בַּעַל הַבַּיִת, קוֹרִין קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמְבָרְכִין לְפָנֶיהָ וּלְאַחֲרֶיהָ. וְאוֹכְלִין פִּתָּן וּמְבָרְכִין לְפָנֶיהָ וּלְאַחֲרֶיהָ, וּמִתְפַּלְּלִין תְּפִלָּה שֶׁל שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה. אֲבָל אֵין יוֹרְדִין לִפְנֵי הַתֵּיבָה, וְאֵין נוֹשְׂאִין כַּפֵּיהֶם.
human_translation: The Sages taught Laborers who were working for a homeowner recite Shema and recite the blessings before it and after it; and eat their bread they recite the blessing before and after it; and they recite the Amida prayer. However, they do not descend before the ark and do not lift their hands
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Workers who were doing work in the house of the homeowner, they recite the Shema and bless before it and after it. And they eat their bread and bless before it and after it, and they pray the eighteen blessings. But they do not go down in front of the ark, and they do not lift up their hands.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא מֵעֵין שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה! אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, הָא — רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ.
human_translation: Didn’t we learn a microcosm of the Amida prayer Rav Sheshet said: This is not difficult. This Rabban Gamliel, This Rabbi Yehoshua,
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: "From the age of eighteen!" Rav Sheshet said: It is not difficult, here is Rabban Gamliel, here is Rabbi Yehoshua.

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ, מַאי אִירְיָא פּוֹעֲלִים? אֲפִילּוּ כָּל אָדָם נָמֵי!
human_translation: if Rabbi Yehoshua, why discuss laborers every person may also
llm_translation: If Rabbi Yehoshua, what is the meaning of "poalim"? Even all people are standing!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן, בְּעוֹשִׂין בִּשְׂכָרָן. כָּאן, בְּעוֹשִׂין בִּסְעוּדָתָן.
human_translation: Rather, this that Rabban Gamliel, and this is not difficult: Here, where work for their wage while here, where work for their meal.
llm_translation: Rather, both this and that are in accordance with Rabban Gamliel, and there is no difficulty: here, they do it for their reward. Here, they do it for their meal.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: הַפּוֹעֲלִים שֶׁהָיוּ עוֹשִׂים מְלָאכָה אֵצֶל בַּעַל הַבַּיִת — קוֹרִין קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִתְפַּלְּלִין. וְאוֹכְלִין פִּתָּן — וְאֵין מְבָרְכִים לְפָנֶיהָ, אֲבָל מְבָרְכִין לְאַחֲרֶיהָ שְׁתַּיִם. כֵּיצַד? בְּרָכָה רִאשׁוֹנָה כְּתִקּוּנָהּ, שְׁנִיָּה פּוֹתֵחַ בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ וְכוֹלְלִין ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: And it was taught Laborers who were performing labor for the homeowner recite Shema and pray; and eat their bread they do not recite a blessing beforehand but they recite two the blessing thereafter, How so? The first blessing in its standard the second blessing, he begins the blessing of the land and they include Who builds Jerusalem within the blessing of the land,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: Workers who were doing work for the homeowner - they read the Shema and pray. And they eat bread - and they do not bless beforehand, but they bless after it twice. How so? The first blessing as it was instituted, the second opens with the blessing of the land and includes "Who builds Jerusalem" in the blessing of the land.

hebrew_text: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּעוֹשִׂין בִּשְׂכָרָן, אֲבָל עוֹשִׂין בִּסְעוּדָתָן אוֹ שֶׁהָיָה בַּעַל הַבַּיִת מֵיסֵב עִמָּהֶן — מְבָרְכִין כְּתִיקּוּנָהּ.
human_translation: In what is this said? with regard to who work for their wage, but work for their meal or if the homeowner reclined with them, they recite the blessings in their standard
llm_translation: In what case are these words spoken? When they do it for their wages, but if they do it for their meal or if the master of the house was dining with them, they recite the blessing properly.

hebrew_text: חָתָן פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״בְּשִׁבְתְּךָ בְּבֵיתֶךָ״ — פְּרָט לְעוֹסֵק בְּמִצְוָה. ״וּבְלֶכְתְּךָ בַּדֶּרֶךְ״ — פְּרָט לְחָתָן. מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ: הַכּוֹנֵס אֶת הַבְּתוּלָה — פָּטוּר, וְאֶת הָאַלְמָנָה — חַיָּיב.
human_translation: a groom is exempt from the recitation of Shema The Sages taught When you sit in your home, to the exclusion of one who is engaged in mitzva, and when you walk along the way, to the exclusion of a groom, from here, they said: One who marries a virgin is exempt but one who marries a widow is obligated.
llm_translation: The groom is exempt from reciting the Shema. The Rabbis taught: "When you sit in your house" - excluding one who is engaged in a mitzvah. "And when you walk on the way" - excluding a groom. From here they said: One who marries a virgin - is exempt, but one who marries a widow - is obligated.

hebrew_text: מַאי מַשְׁמַע? אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: כִּי דֶרֶךְ. מָה דֶּרֶךְ רְשׁוּת, אַף הָכָא נָמֵי רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: From where is it inferred Rav Pappa said Like the way; just as way is voluntary so too all voluntary activities.
llm_translation: What is implied? Rav Papa said: Like the way. Just as the way is optional, so too here it is optional.

hebrew_text: מִי לָא עָסְקִינַן דְּקָאָזֵיל לִדְבַר מִצְוָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: לִיקְרֵי.
human_translation: Are we not dealing with on his way to a mitzva; nevertheless, the Torah said to recite
llm_translation: We are dealing with one who is going to perform a mitzvah, and even so, the Merciful One said: "Read."

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, לֵימָא קְרָא ״בְּלֶכֶת״, מַאי ״בְּלֶכְתְּךָ״ — שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בְּלֶכֶת דִּידָךְ הוּא דִּמְחַיְּיבַתְּ, הָא דְמִצְוָה — פְּטִירַתְּ.
human_translation: If so, let the Torah say: When walking What is When you walk Conclude from this: It is of your walking, you are obligated but of mitzva, you are exempt.
llm_translation: If so, let us say the verse "when you walk," what is "when you walk" - learn from it: "when you walk" is what obligates us, as for the mitzvah - it is the conclusion.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי מַאי אִירְיָא הַכּוֹנֵס אֶת הַבְּתוּלָה? אֲפִילּוּ כּוֹנֵס אֶת הָאַלְמָנָה נָמֵי.
human_translation: If so, why discuss one who is marrying a virgin Even one who is marrying a widow also
llm_translation: So what is the case of one who gathers the virgin? Even if he gathers the widow, the same applies.

hebrew_text: הָכָא — טְרִיד, וְהָכָא — לָא טְרִיד.
human_translation: Here, preoccupied while here, he is not preoccupied.
llm_translation: Here - trid, and here - not trid.

hebrew_text: אִי מִשּׁוּם טִרְדָּא, אֲפִילּוּ טָבְעָה סְפִינָתוֹ בַּיָּם נָמֵי, אַלְּמָה אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר זַבְדָּא אָמַר רַב: אָבֵל חַיָּיב בְּכָל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה, חוּץ מִן הַתְּפִילִּין שֶׁהֲרֵי נֶאֱמַר בָּהֶן ״פְּאֵר״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״פְּאֵרְךָ חֲבוֹשׁ עָלֶיךָ וְגוֹ׳״!
human_translation: If due to preoccupation, even his ship sank at sea should why then did Rabbi Abba bar Zavda say Rav said: A mourner is obligated in all the mitzvot mentioned in the Torah except for phylacteries, as splendor is stated as it is stated “Bind your splendor upon yourself”
llm_translation: If because of trouble, even if his ship sank in the deep sea, why did Rabbi Abba bar Zavda say in the name of Rav: A mourner is obligated in all the commandments stated in the Torah, except for Tefillin, as it is stated about them "Your beauty" (Ezekiel 24:12).

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי הָתָם טִרְדָּא דִרְשׁוּת הָכָא טִרְדָּא דְמִצְוָה.
human_translation: There, preoccupation with a voluntary here, the preoccupation is mitzva
llm_translation: They said there: Tir'da of drash; here Tir'da of mitzvah.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ רָחַץ לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹן שֶׁמֵּתָה אִשְׁתּוֹ. אָמְרוּ לוֹ תַּלְמִידָיו: לִמַּדְתָּנוּ רַבֵּינוּ שֶׁאָבֵל אָסוּר לִרְחוֹץ? אָמַר לָהֶם אֵינִי כִּשְׁאָר בְּנֵי אָדָם, אִסְטְנִיס אֲנִי.
human_translation: He bathed on the first night after his wife died. His students said to him: you taught us, our teacher, that a mourner is prohibited to bathe? I am not like other people, I am delicate [ istenis ].
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: He washed on the first night after his wife died. His disciples said to him: Did you teach us, our teacher, that a mourner is forbidden to wash? He said to them: I am not like other people, I am an aristocrat.

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁמֵּת טָבִי עַבְדּוֹ קִבֵּל עָלָיו תַּנְחוּמִין. אָמְרוּ לוֹ תַּלְמִידָיו: לִמַּדְתָּנוּ רַבֵּינוּ שֶׁאֵין מְקַבְּלִין תַּנְחוּמִין עַל הָעֲבָדִים? אָמַר לָהֶם: אֵין טָבִי עַבְדִּי כִּשְׁאָר כָּל הָעֲבָדִים, כָּשֵׁר הָיָה.
human_translation: And when his slave, Tavi, died, accepted condolences for his His students said to him: Have you taught us, our teacher, that one does not accept condolences for slaves? My slave, Tavi, is not like all the rest of the slaves, he was virtuous
llm_translation: And when Tabi his servant died, he received condolences. His disciples said to him: "Did you not teach us, our master, that one does not accept condolences for slaves?" He said to them: "Tabi my servant was not like the rest of the slaves, he was kosher."

hebrew_text: חָתָן אִם רוֹצֶה לִקְרוֹת קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע לַיְלָה הָרִאשׁוֹן — קוֹרֵא, רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: לֹא כָּל הָרוֹצֶה לִיטּוֹל אֶת הַשֵּׁם, יִטּוֹל.
human_translation: if, a groom wishes to recite Shema on the first night, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Not everyone who wishes to assume the reputation may assume
llm_translation: The groom, if he wishes to recite the Shema on the first night - he recites. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Not everyone who wishes to take the Name should take it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבָּן (שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן) גַּמְלִיאֵל? קָסָבַר: אֲנִינוּת לַיְלָה — דְּרַבָּנַן, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְאַחֲרִיתָהּ כְּיוֹם מָר״. וּבִמְקוֹם אִיסְטְנִיס לָא גְזַרוּ בֵּיהּ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: What is the reason Rabban Gamliel He holds that acute mourning at night is by rabbinic law, as it is written: and the end will be like a bitter day” And in the case of a delicate person, the Sages did not issue a decree
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What is the reason for Rabban (Shimon ben) Gamliel? He holds: Nighttime is for the Sages, as it is written: "And its end is like a bitter day." And in a place of danger, the Sages did not decree upon it.

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁמֵּת טָבִי עַבְדּוֹ וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: When his servant, Tavi, died,
llm_translation: And when Tabi his servant died, and so forth.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: עֲבָדִים וּשְׁפָחוֹת אֵין עוֹמְדִין עֲלֵיהֶם בְּשׁוּרָה, וְאֵין אוֹמְרִים עֲלֵיהֶם בִּרְכַּת אֲבֵלִים וְתַנְחוּמֵי אֲבֵלִים.
human_translation: The Sages slaves and maidservants one does not stand in a row and one recites neither the blessing of the mourners nor the consolation of the mourners.
llm_translation: The sages taught: Slaves and maidservants do not stand over them in a row, and one does not recite over them the blessings of mourners and the consolations of mourners.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה וּמֵתָה שִׁפְחָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. נִכְנְסוּ תַּלְמִידָיו לְנַחֲמוֹ. כֵּיוָן שֶׁרָאָה אוֹתָם עָלָה לַעֲלִיָּיה, וְעָלוּ אַחֲרָיו. נִכְנַס לָאַנְפִּילוֹן, נִכְנְסוּ אַחֲרָיו. נִכְנַס לַטְּרַקְלִין, נִכְנְסוּ אַחֲרָיו. אָמַר לָהֶם: כִּמְדוּמֶּה אֲנִי שֶׁאַתֶּם נִכְוִים בְּפוֹשְׁרִים, עַכְשָׁיו אִי אַתֶּם נִכְוִים אֲפִילּוּ בְּחַמֵּי חַמִּין, לֹא כָּךְ שָׁנִיתִי לָכֶם: עֲבָדִים וּשְׁפָחוֹת אֵין עוֹמְדִים עֲלֵיהֶם בְּשׁוּרָה, וְאֵין אוֹמְרִים עֲלֵיהֶם בִּרְכַּת אֲבֵלִים וְלֹא תַּנְחוּמֵי אֲבֵלִים? אֶלָּא מָה אוֹמְרִים עֲלֵיהֶם? — כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאוֹמְרִים לוֹ לְאָדָם עַל שׁוֹרוֹ וְעַל חֲמוֹרוֹ שֶׁמֵּתוּ — ״הַמָּקוֹם יְמַלֵּא לְךָ חֶסְרוֹנְךָ״, כָּךְ אוֹמְרִים לוֹ עַל עַבְדּוֹ וְעַל שִׁפְחָתוֹ ״הַמָּקוֹם יְמַלֵּא לְךָ חֶסְרוֹנְךָ״.
human_translation: An incident Rabbi Eliezer’s maidservant died, his students entered to console him. When he saw them he went up to the second floor, and they went up after him. He entered the gatehouse [ anpilon ], and they entered after him. He entered the banquet hall [ teraklin ], they entered after him. he said to them: It seems to me that you would be burned by lukewarm water, Now you are not even burned by boiling hot water. Did I not teach you the following: slaves and maidservants one does not stand in a row and one neither recites the blessing of the mourners nor the consolation of the mourners, Rather, what does one say about them Just as we say to a person about his ox or donkey which died: May the Omnipresent replenish your loss, so too do we say for one’s slave or maidservant May the Omnipresent replenish your loss,
llm_translation: The incident of the death of the maidservant of Rabbi Eliezer. His disciples entered to console him. When he saw them, he ascended to the upper chamber, and they followed him. He entered the Anpilon, they entered after him. He entered the Traklin, they entered after him. He said to them: "I am like one of you who is engaged in interpreting, now you are not engaged even in the heat of the sun, so I did not change for you: Slaves and maidservants are not to be mourned for with a eulogy, nor are blessings of mourners to be said for them? Rather, what should be said for them? — Just as one says to a person about his ox or his donkey that died, 'May the Omnipresent fill your loss,' so one says to him about his slave and his maidservant, 'May the Omnipresent fill your loss.'"

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: עֲבָדִים וּשְׁפָחוֹת אֵין מַסְפִּידִין אוֹתָן. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אִם עֶבֶד כָּשֵׁר הוּא — אוֹמְרִים עָלָיו: ״הוֹי אִישׁ טוֹב וְנֶאֱמָן וְנֶהֱנֶה מִיגִיעוֹ״. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אִם כֵּן, מָה הִנַּחְתָּ לַכְּשֵׁרִים?
human_translation: It was taught in another One does not eulogize slaves and maidservants. Rabbi Yosei says: If he was a virtuous servant, one recites over him Alas, a good and loyal man who enjoyed of his hard labor. They said to him: If so, what have you left for virtuous
llm_translation: Talmudic text: It was taught in another Baraita: Slaves and maidservants are not eulogized. Rabbi Yosei says: If he is a qualified slave, they say about him, "Behold a good and faithful man who enjoys his labor." They said to him: If so, what have you left for the qualified ones?

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין קוֹרִין ״אָבוֹת״ אֶלָּא לִשְׁלֹשָׁה, וְאֵין קוֹרִין ״אִמָּהוֹת״ אֶלָּא לְאַרְבַּע.
human_translation: The Sages taught One may only call three patriarchs, And one may only call four matriarchs,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Avot" is only read with three, and "Imahot" is only read with four.

hebrew_text: אָבוֹת מַאי טַעְמָא? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא יָדְעִינַן אִי מֵרְאוּבֵן קָא אָתֵינַן אִי מִשִּׁמְעוֹן קָא אָתֵינַן, אִי הָכִי אִמָּהוֹת נָמֵי לָא יָדְעִינַן אִי מֵרָחֵל קָא אָתֵינַן אִי מִלֵּאָה קָא אָתֵינַן! אֶלָּא, עַד הָכָא חֲשִׁיבִי, טְפִי לָא חֲשִׁיבִי.
human_translation: What is the reason Patriarchs? If you say because we do not know whether we descend from Reuben or from Simon, if so, we do not know whether we descend from Rachel or from Leah, Instead, until they are significant beyond they are not significant
llm_translation: Fathers, what is the reason? Perhaps because we do not know whether it is from Reuben that we come or from Simeon that we come, and if so, we also do not know whether it is from the mothers, whether we come from Rachel or whether we come from Leah! Rather, until here it is considered, beyond here it is not considered.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידָךְ: עֲבָדִים וּשְׁפָחוֹת אֵין קוֹרִין אוֹתָם ״אַבָּא פְּלוֹנִי״ וְ״אִמָּא פְּלוֹנִית״. וְשֶׁל רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל הָיוּ קוֹרִים אוֹתָם ״אַבָּא פְּלוֹנִי״ וְ״אִמָּא פְּלוֹנִית״.
human_translation: it was taught in another One may not refer to slaves and maidservants as father [ abba ] so-and-so or mother [ imma ] so-and-so. But they would call of Rabban Gamliel “father so-and-so” and “mother so-and-so.”
llm_translation: It was taught in another Baraita: Slaves and maidservants are not called "So-and-so's father" or "So-and-so's mother." But in the household of Rabban Gamliel, they would call them "So-and-so's father" and "So-and-so's mother."

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה לִסְתּוֹר?! מִשּׁוּם דַּחֲשִׁיבִי.
human_translation: story to contradict because were significant,
llm_translation: The matter of Sitor?! Because it is important.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מַאי דִּכְתִיב, ״כֵּן אֲבָרֶכְךָ בְחַיָּי בְּשִׁמְךָ אֶשָּׂא כַפָּי״? ״כֵּן אֲבָרֶכְךָ בְחַיָּי״ — זוֹ קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע. ״בְּשִׁמְךָ אֶשָּׂא כַפָּי״ — זוֹ תְּפִלָּה. וְאִם עוֹשֶׂה כֵּן — עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב אוֹמֵר: ״כְּמוֹ חֵלֶב וָדֶשֶׁן תִּשְׂבַּע נַפְשִׁי״. וְלֹא עוֹד אֶלָּא שֶׁנּוֹחֵל שְׁנֵי עוֹלָמִים — הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה וְהָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְשִׂפְתֵי רְנָנוֹת יְהַלֶּל פִּי״.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: What is that which is written: “So I will bless You as I live, to Your name I will raise my hands” So I will bless You as I live, refers to the recitation of Shema , to Your name I will raise my hands, refers to prayer, And if one does so, the verse says about him: “As with fat and marrow, my soul will be satisfied” And not only but he inherits two worlds, this world and the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “With lips of joys [ renanot ], my mouth praises You”
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: What is the meaning of what is written, "So I will bless You as long as I live; in Your name, I will lift up my hands"? "So I will bless You as long as I live" - this refers to the recitation of the Shema. "In Your name, I will lift up my hands" - this refers to prayer. And if one does so, the verse says about him: "My soul will be satisfied as with fat and rich food." Moreover, he will inherit two worlds - this world and the world to come, as it is said: "And my mouth will praise You with joyful lips."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בָּתַר דִּמְסַיֵּים צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁתְּשַׁכֵּן בְּפוּרֵינוּ אַהֲבָה וְאַחְוָה וְשָׁלוֹם וְרֵיעוּת. וְתַרְבֶּה גְּבוּלֵנוּ בְּתַלְמִידִים וְתַצְלִיחַ סוֹפֵנוּ אַחֲרִית וְתִקְוָה. וְתָשִׂים חֶלְקֵנוּ בְּגַן עֵדֶן, וְתַקְּנֵנוּ בְּחָבֵר טוֹב וְיֵצֶר טוֹב בְּעוֹלָמֶךָ. וְנַשְׁכִּים וְנִמְצָא יִחוּל לְבָבֵנוּ לְיִרְאָה אֶת שְׁמֶךָ, וְתָבֹא לְפָנֶיךָ קוֹרַת נַפְשֵׁנוּ לְטוֹבָה״.
human_translation: after Rabbi Elazar concluded his prayer, he said the following May it be Your will, Lord our God, to cause to dwell in our lot love and brotherhood, peace and friendship. And may You make our borders rich in disciples and cause us to ultimately succeed, end and hope. And may You set our portion in the Garden of Eden, and may You establish for us a good companion and a good inclination in Your world. And may we rise early and find the aspiration of our hearts to fear Your name, and may the satisfaction of our souls come before You, for the best.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar after finishing his prayers said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You dwell among us with love, brotherhood, peace, and companionship. Increase our borders with students, and grant success to our end and hope. Place our portion in the Garden of Eden, and establish us in good company and good inclination in Your world. May we rise early and find our hearts inclined to fear Your name, and may the desire of our souls come before You for good."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בָּתַר דִּמְסַיֵּים צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁתָּצִיץ בְּבׇשְׁתֵּנוּ, וְתַבִּיט בְּרָעָתֵנוּ, וְתִתְלַבֵּשׁ בְּרַחֲמֶיךָ, וְתִתְכַּסֶּה בְּעֻזֶּךָ, וְתִתְעַטֵּף בַּחֲסִידוּתֶךָ, וְתִתְאַזֵּר בַּחֲנִינוּתֶךָ, וְתָבֹא לְפָנֶיךָ מִדַּת טוּבְךָ וְעִנְוְתָנוּתֶךְ״.
human_translation: after Rabbi Yoḥanan concluded his prayer, he said the following May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You look upon our shame and behold our plight, that You clothe Yourself in Your mercy, and cover Yourself with Your might, that You wrap Yourself in Your loving-kindness, and gird Yourself with Your grace, and may Your attributes of goodness and humility come before You.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan after he finished his prayers said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, to look upon our shame, and to see our affliction, and to clothe Yourself in Your mercy, and to cover Yourself with Your strength, and to wrap Yourself in Your kindness, and to gird Yourself with Your grace, and may You come before You with Your measure of goodness and humility."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי זֵירָא בָּתַר דִּמְסַיֵּים צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁלֹּא נֶחֱטָא וְלֹא נֵבוֹשׁ וְלֹא נִכָּלֵם מֵאֲבוֹתֵינוּ״.
human_translation: after Rabbi Zeira concluded his prayers he said the following May it be Your will, Lord our God, that we not sin or shame ourselves, and that we not disgrace ourselves before our forefathers,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira after he finished his prayers said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, that we do not sin, and that we do not be ashamed, and that we do not be disgraced by our forefathers."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי חִיָּיא בָּתַר דִּמְצַלֵּי אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁתְּהֵא תּוֹרָתְךָ אוּמָּנוּתֵנוּ, וְאַל יִדְוֶה לִבֵּנוּ, וְאַל יֶחְשְׁכוּ עֵינֵינוּ״.
human_translation: After Rabbi Ḥiyya prayed he said the following: May it be Your will, Lord our God, that Your Torah should be our vocation, and may our heart not become faint nor our eyes dim.
llm_translation: Rabbi Chiya Batra d'Metzalei said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, that Your Torah be our occupation, and let not our heart be inclined, and let our eyes not grow dim."

hebrew_text: רַב בָּתַר צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ שֶׁתִּתֵּן לָנוּ חַיִּים אֲרוּכִּים, חַיִּים שֶׁל שָׁלוֹם, חַיִּים שֶׁל טוֹבָה, חַיִּים שֶׁל בְּרָכָה, חַיִּים שֶׁל פַּרְנָסָה, חַיִּים שֶׁל חִלּוּץ עֲצָמוֹת, חַיִּים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶם יִרְאַת חֵטְא, חַיִּים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶם בּוּשָׁה וּכְלִימָּה, חַיִּים שֶׁל עוֹשֶׁר וְכָבוֹד, חַיִּים שֶׁתְּהֵא בָּנוּ אַהֲבַת תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם, חַיִּים שֶׁתְּמַלֵּא לָנוּ אֶת כָּל מִשְׁאֲלוֹת לִבֵּנוּ לְטוֹבָה״.
human_translation: After his prayer, Rav said the following: May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You grant us long life, a life of peace, a life of goodness, a life of blessing, a life of sustenance, a life of freedom of movement a life of dread of sin, a life without shame and disgrace, a life of wealth and honor, a life in which we have love of Torah and reverence for Heaven, a life in which You fulfill all the desires of our heart for good.
llm_translation: Rav Batra his students said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, to grant us healthy lives, lives of peace, lives of goodness, lives of blessing, lives of sustenance, lives of deliverance from suffering, lives with fear of sin, lives without shame and disgrace, lives of wealth and honor, lives in which we have love for Torah and fear of Heaven, lives in which all the desires of our hearts are fulfilled for good."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי בָּתַר צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ וֵאלֹהֵי אֲבוֹתֵינוּ, שֶׁתַּצִּילֵנוּ מֵעַזֵּי פָּנִים וּמֵעַזּוּת פָּנִים, מֵאָדָם רָע, וּמִפֶּגַע רָע, מִיֵּצֶר רָע, מֵחָבֵר רָע, מִשָּׁכֵן רָע, וּמִשָּׂטָן הַמַּשְׁחִית, וּמִדִּין קָשֶׁה וּמִבַּעַל דִּין קָשֶׁה, בֵּין שֶׁהוּא בֶּן בְּרִית בֵּין שֶׁאֵינוֹ בֶּן בְּרִית״.
human_translation: After his prayer, Rabbi said the following: May it be Your will, Lord our God, and God of our forefathers, that You save us from the arrogant and from arrogance from a bad man, from a bad mishap, from an evil instinct, from a bad companion, from a bad neighbor, from the destructive Satan, from a harsh trial and from a harsh opponent, whether he is a member of the covenant, or whether he is not a member of the covenant.
llm_translation: Rabbi Betar his students said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God and God of our fathers, that You deliver us from brazen-faced individuals and brazen-facedness, from a wicked person, and from wicked encounters, from evil inclination, from evil companions, from an evil neighbor, and from the destructive Satan, and from harsh judgment and from a harsh judge, whether he is in the covenant or not in the covenant."

hebrew_text: וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּקָיְימִי קָצוֹצֵי עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי.
human_translation: And despite the fact that officers stood over Rabbi
llm_translation: And even though the disciples of Rabbi were standing over her cutting.

hebrew_text: רַב סָפְרָא בָּתַר צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁתָּשִׂים שָׁלוֹם
human_translation: After his prayer, Rav Safra said the following: May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You establish peace
llm_translation: Rav Safra after his prayers said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, to establish peace."

hebrew_text: בְּפָמַלְיָא שֶׁל מַעְלָה. וּבְפָמַלְיָא שֶׁל מַטָּה, וּבֵין הַתַּלְמִידִים הָעוֹסְקִים בְּתוֹרָתֶךָ בֵּין עוֹסְקִין לִשְׁמָהּ בֵּין עוֹסְקִין שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ. וְכָל הָעוֹסְקִין שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ יְהִי רָצוֹן שֶׁיְּהוּ עוֹסְקִין לִשְׁמָהּ״.
human_translation: in the heavenly entourage [ pamalia ] and in the earthly entourage, and among the disciples engaged in Your Torah, whether they engage in its for its own sake or not for its own sake. And all those engaged not for its own sake, may it be will they will come to engage for its own sake.
llm_translation: In the upper chamber. And in the lower chamber, and among the students who engage in Your Torah, whether they engage for its own sake or not for its own sake. And all those who engage not for its own sake, may it be Your will that they come to engage for its own sake.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אָלֶכְּסַנְדְרִי בָּתַר צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ, שֶׁתַּעֲמִידֵנוּ בְּקֶרֶן אוֹרָה, וְאַל תַּעֲמִידֵנוּ בְּקֶרֶן חֲשֵׁכָה, וְאַל יִדְוֶה לִבֵּנוּ, וְאַל יֶחְשְׁכוּ עֵינֵינוּ״. אִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי, הָא רַב הַמְנוּנָא מְצַלֵּי לַהּ. וְרַבִּי אָלֶכְּסַנְדְרִי בָּתַר דִּמְצַלֵּי אָמַר הָכִי: ״רִבּוֹן הָעוֹלָמִים, גָּלוּי וְיָדוּעַ לְפָנֶיךָ שֶׁרְצוֹנֵנוּ לַעֲשׂוֹת רְצוֹנֶךָ, וּמִי מְעַכֵּב? — שְׂאוֹר שֶׁבָּעִיסָּה וְשִׁעְבּוּד מַלְכֻיוֹת. יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ שֶׁתַּצִּילֵנוּ מִיָּדָם, וְנָשׁוּב לַעֲשׂוֹת חוּקֵּי רְצוֹנְךָ בְּלֵבָב שָׁלֵם״.
human_translation: After his prayer, Rabbi Alexandri said the following: May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You station us in a lighted corner and not in a darkened corner, and do not let our hearts become faint nor our eyes dim. Some say that this was the prayer that Rav Hamnuna would recite, and that after Rabbi Alexandri prayed, he would say the following: Master of the Universe, it is revealed and known before You that our will is to perform Your will, and what prevents us? the yeast in the dough, and the subjugation to the kingdoms May it be Your will that You will deliver us from their hands, we may return to perform the edicts of Your will with a perfect heart.
llm_translation: Rabbi Alexander after his prayers said thus: "May it be Your will, Lord our God, that You establish us in the corner of light, and do not establish us in the corner of darkness, and may our heart not be ashamed, and may our eyes not darken." Some say, the great sage Menuna would conclude with this prayer. And Rabbi Alexander after concluding his prayer said thus: "Master of the Universe, it is revealed and known before You that our will is to do Your will, so who is hindering? — The leaven in the dough and subjugation to kingdoms. May it be Your will to save us from their hand, and may we return to fulfill the statutes of Your will with a complete heart."

hebrew_text: רָבָא בָּתַר צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״אֱלֹהַי, עַד שֶׁלֹּא נוֹצַרְתִּי אֵינִי כְּדַאי, וְעַכְשָׁיו שֶׁנּוֹצַרְתִּי כְּאִלּוּ לֹא נוֹצַרְתִּי. עָפָר אֲנִי בְּחַיַּי, קַל וָחוֹמֶר בְּמִיתָתִי, הֲרֵי אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ כִּכְלִי מָלֵא בּוּשָׁה וּכְלִימָּה. יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי, שֶׁלֹּא אֶחֱטָא עוֹד, וּמַה שֶּׁחָטָאתִי לְפָנֶיךָ מָרֵק בְּרַחֲמֶיךָ הָרַבִּים, אֲבָל לֹא עַל יְדֵי יִסּוּרִין וָחֳלָאִים רָעִים״. וְהַיְינוּ וִידּוּי דְרַב הַמְנוּנָא זוּטֵי בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי.
human_translation: After his prayer, Rava said the following: My God, before I was created I was worthless, and now that I have been created it is as if I had not been created, I am dust in life, all the more so in my death. I am before You as a vessel filled with shame and humiliation. may it be Your will, Lord my God, that I will sin no more, and that those that I have committed, cleanse in Your abundant mercy; but not by means of suffering and serious illness, And this is the confession of Rav Hamnuna Zuti on Yom Kippur.
llm_translation: Rava after his prayers said thus: "My God, before I was created, I was not worthy, and now that I am created, it is as if I was not created. I am dust in my life, all the more so in my death. Behold, I am before You like a vessel filled with shame and humiliation. May it be Your will, Lord my God, that I do not sin anymore, and whatever sins I have committed before You, erase with Your abundant mercies, but not through afflictions and severe illnesses." This is the confession of Rav Hamnuna Zuti on the Day of Atonement.

hebrew_text: מָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא כִּי הֲוָה מְסַיֵּים צְלוֹתֵיהּ אָמַר הָכִי: ״אֱלֹהַי, נְצוֹר לְשׁוֹנִי מֵרָע וְשִׂפְתוֹתַי מִדַּבֵּר מִרְמָה, וְלִמְקַלְּלַי נַפְשִׁי תִדּוֹם, וְנַפְשִׁי כֶּעָפָר לַכֹּל תִּהְיֶה. פְּתַח לִבִּי בְּתוֹרָתֶךָ, וּבְמִצְוֹתֶיךָ תִּרְדּוֹף נַפְשִׁי. וְתַצִּילֵנִי מִפֶּגַע רָע, מִיֵּצֶר הָרָע, וּמֵאִשָּׁה רָעָה, וּמִכָּל רָעוֹת הַמִּתְרַגְּשׁוֹת לָבֹא בָּעוֹלָם. וְכָל הַחוֹשְׁבִים עָלַי רָעָה מְהֵרָה הָפֵר עֲצָתָם וְקַלְקֵל מַחְשְׁבוֹתָם. יִהְיוּ לְרָצוֹן אִמְרֵי פִי וְהֶגְיוֹן לִבִּי לְפָנֶיךָ ה׳ צוּרִי וְגוֹאֲלִי״.
human_translation: When Mar, son of Ravina, would conclude his prayer, he said the following: My God, guard my tongue from evil and my lips from speaking deceit. To those who curse me let my soul be silent and may my soul be like dust to all. Open my heart to Your Torah, and may my soul pursue your mitzvot. And save me from a bad mishap, from the evil inclination, from a bad woman, and from all evils that suddenly come upon the world. And all who plan evil against me, swiftly thwart their counsel, and frustrate their plans. May the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart find favor before You, Lord, my Rock and my Redeemer.
llm_translation: Mar, son of Ravina, when he would finish his prayers, would say the following: "My God, guard my tongue from evil and my lips from speaking deceit. Let my soul be silent to those who curse me, and let my soul be like dust to all. Open my heart to Your Torah, and may my soul pursue Your commandments. Save me from evil encounters, from the evil inclination, from an evil woman, and from all the evils that are ready to come into the world. And may all those who plot evil against me quickly have their counsel thwarted and their thoughts disrupted. May the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be acceptable before You, Hashem, my Rock and my Redeemer."

hebrew_text: רַב שֵׁשֶׁת כִּי הֲוָה יָתֵיב בְּתַעֲנִיתָא, בָּתַר דִּמְצַלֵּי אָמַר הָכִי: ״רִבּוֹן הָעוֹלָמִים, גָּלוּי לְפָנֶיךָ בִּזְמַן שֶׁבֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ קַיָּים, אָדָם חוֹטֵא — וּמַקְרִיב קָרְבָּן. וְאֵין מַקְרִיבִין מִמֶּנּוּ, אֶלָּא חֶלְבּוֹ וְדָמוֹ, וּמִתְכַּפֵּר לוֹ. וְעַכְשָׁיו יָשַׁבְתִּי בְּתַעֲנִית וְנִתְמַעֵט חֶלְבִּי וְדָמִי, יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ שֶׁיְּהֵא חֶלְבִּי וְדָמִי שֶׁנִּתְמַעֵט כְּאִילּוּ הִקְרַבְתִּיו לְפָנֶיךָ עַל גַּבֵּי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ, וְתִרְצֵנִי״.
human_translation: when Rav Sheshet would sit in a fast, after he prayed he said as follows: Master of the Universe, it is revealed before You when the Temple is standing, one sins and offers a sacrifice. And only its fat and blood were offered from is atoned for him. And now, I sat in a fast and my fat and blood diminished. May it be Your will that my fat and blood that diminished be I offered before You on the altar, and may I find favor in Your eyes.
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet, when he was sitting in a fast, after he finished praying, said thus: "Master of the Universe, it is revealed before You that when the Temple stood, a person would sin and bring an offering. And they would only offer from it its fat and its blood, and he would be atoned for. And now, I have sat in a fast and my fat and blood have diminished, may it be Your will from before You that my diminished fat and blood be as if I had offered them before You on the altar, and You will accept me."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן כִּי הֲוָה מְסַיֵּים סִפְרָא דְאִיּוֹב, אָמַר הָכִי: ״סוֹף אָדָם לָמוּת וְסוֹף בְּהֵמָה לִשְׁחִיטָה, וְהַכֹּל לְמִיתָה הֵם עוֹמְדִים. אַשְׁרֵי מִי שֶׁגָּדֵל בַּתּוֹרָה וַעֲמָלוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה, וְעוֹשֶׂה נַחַת רוּחַ לְיוֹצְרוֹ, וְגָדֵל בְּשֵׁם טוֹב וְנִפְטָר בְּשֵׁם טוֹב מִן הָעוֹלָם, וְעָלָיו אָמַר שְׁלֹמֹה: 'טוֹב שֵׁם מִשֶּׁמֶן טוֹב וְיוֹם הַמָּוֶת מִיּוֹם הִוָּלְדוֹ'״.
human_translation: When Rabbi Yoḥanan would conclude the book of Job, he said the following: A person will ultimately die and an animal will ultimately be slaughtered, and all are destined for death. happy is he who grew up in Torah, whose labor is in Torah, who gives pleasure to his Creator, who grew up with a good name and who took leave of the world with a good name. and about him, Solomon said: “A good name is better than fine oil, and the day of death than the day of one’s birth”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan, when he would finish the book of Job, would say thus: "The end of man is to die, and the end of an animal is for slaughter, and all are destined for death. Fortunate is he who grows in Torah study and toils in Torah study, and brings joy to his Creator, and grows in a good name, and departs from the world with a good name. Concerning him, Solomon said: 'A good name is better than good oil, and the day of death than the day of birth.'"

hebrew_text: מַרְגְּלָא בְּפוּמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר: ״גְּמוֹר בְּכָל לְבָבְךָ וּבְכָל נַפְשְׁךָ לָדַעַת אֶת דְּרָכַי, וְלִשְׁקוֹד עַל דַּלְתֵי תוֹרָתִי. נְצוֹר תּוֹרָתִי בְּלִבְּךָ, וְנֶגֶד עֵינֶיךָ תִּהְיֶה יִרְאָתִי. שְׁמוֹר פִּיךְ מִכָּל חֵטְא, וְטַהֵר וְקַדֵּשׁ עַצְמְךָ מִכָּל אַשְׁמָה וְעָוֹן. וַאֲנִי אֶהְיֶה עִמְּךָ בְּכָל מָקוֹם״.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir was wont to say Study with all your heart and with all your soul to know My ways and to be diligent at the doors of My Torah. Keep My Torah in your heart, and fear of Me should be before your eyes. Guard your mouth from all transgression, and purify and sanctify yourself from all fault and iniquity. And I, will be with you everywhere.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Margela befumei d'Rabbi Meir: 'G'mor bechol levavcha uvechol nafshecha lada'at et drachai, velishkod al daltei torati. Netzor torati bilevavcha, venegeid einecha tihyeh yirati. Shmor picha mikol chet, vetaher vekadesh atzmcha mikol ashmah ve'avon. Va'ani eheyeh immcha bechol makom.'" English translation: "The tradition in the mouth of Rabbi Meir: 'Fill your heart and soul to know My ways, and be diligent at the doors of My Torah. Guard My Torah in your heart, and My fear shall be before your eyes. Keep your mouth from all sin, and purify and sanctify yourself from all guilt and transgression. And I will be with you in every place.'"

hebrew_text: מַרְגְּלָא בְּפוּמַּיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן דְּיַבְנֶה: ״אֲנִי בְּרִיָּה, וַחֲבֵרִי בְּרִיָּה. אֲנִי מְלַאכְתִּי בָּעִיר וְהוּא מְלַאכְתּוֹ בַּשָּׂדֶה. אֲנִי מַשְׁכִּים לִמְלַאכְתִּי, וְהוּא מַשְׁכִּים לִמְלַאכְתּוֹ. כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהוּא אֵינוֹ מִתְגַּדֵּר בִּמְלַאכְתִּי, כָּךְ אֲנִי אֵינִי מִתְגַּדֵּר בִּמְלַאכְתּוֹ. וְשֶׁמָּא תֹּאמַר: אֲנִי מַרְבֶּה, וְהוּא מַמְעִיט — שָׁנִינוּ: אֶחָד הַמַּרְבֶּה וְאֶחָד הַמַּמְעִיט וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיְּכַוֵּין לִבּוֹ לַשָּׁמַיִם״.
human_translation: The Sages in Yavne were wont to say: I am creature and my counterpart is creature. My work is in the city and his work is in the field. I rise early for my work and he rises early for his work. And just as he does not presume to my work, so I do not presume to his work. Lest you say: I a lot, while he a little, it has been taught: One who brings a substantial and one who brings a meager as long as he directs his heart towards Heaven
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Margela b'pumaihu d'Rabanan d'Yavneh: 'Ani b'riyah, v'chaveri b'riyah. Ani melachti ba'ir v'hu melachtu basadeh. Ani mashkim l'melachti, v'hu mashkim l'melachtu. K'shem shehu einu mitgader b'melachti, kach ani eini mitgader b'melachtu. V'shema tomar: Ani marbeh, v'hu mam'it — shaninu: Echad hamarbeh v'echad hamam'it u'vilvad sheyekhavvein libo lashamayim.'" English translation: "It is told in the study hall of the Rabbis of Yavneh: 'I am a creature, and my friend is a creature. I am occupied in the city, and he is occupied in the field. I rise early for my work, and he rises early for his work. Just as he is not defined by my work, so I am not defined by his work. And perhaps you will say: I increase, and he decreases — we were taught: Whether one increases or one decreases, as long as one directs his heart to Heaven.'"

hebrew_text: מַרְגְּלָא בְּפוּמֵּיהּ דְּאַבָּיֵּי: לְעוֹלָם יְהֵא אָדָם עָרוּם בְּיִרְאָה. ״מַעֲנֶה רַךְ מֵשִׁיב חֵמָה״. וּמַרְבֶּה שָׁלוֹם עִם אֶחָיו וְעִם קְרוֹבָיו וְעִם כָּל אָדָם וַאֲפִילּוּ עִם גּוֹי בַּשּׁוּק, כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּהֵא אָהוּב לְמַעְלָה וְנֶחְמָד לְמַטָּה, וִיהֵא מְקוּבָּל עַל הַבְּרִיּוֹת.
human_translation: Abaye was wont to say: One must always be shrewd in fear “A soft answer turns away wrath” increase peace with one’s brethren and with one’s relatives, and with all people, even with a non-Jew in the marketplace, so that he will be loved above pleasant below and acceptable to all creatures.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Margela befumei deAbbaye: Leolam yehi adam arum beyirah. 'Ma'aneh rach meshiv chemah.' Umarbeh shalom im echav veim krovav veim kol adam vaafilu im goy bashuk, kedei sheyehi ahuv lemaalah venechmad lematah, viyehi mekubal al haberiyot." English translation: "The foot of Abbaye: A person should always be subtle in fear. 'A soft answer turns away wrath.' And one should increase peace with his brothers, relatives, and with all people, even with a gentile in the marketplace, so that he will be beloved above and esteemed below, and be accepted by all creatures."

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ עָלָיו עַל רַבָּן יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי שֶׁלֹּא הִקְדִּימוֹ אָדָם שָׁלוֹם מֵעוֹלָם, וַאֲפִילּוּ גּוֹי בַּשּׁוּק.
human_translation: they said about Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai that no one ever preceded him in greeting, not even a non-Jew in the marketplace,
llm_translation: They said about Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai that no person ever preceded him with a greeting of peace, not even a gentile in the marketplace.

hebrew_text: מַרְגְּלָא בְּפוּמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא: תַּכְלִית חָכְמָה — תְּשׁוּבָה וּמַעֲשִׂים טוֹבִים, שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא אָדָם קוֹרֵא וְשׁוֹנֶה וּבוֹעֵט בְּאָבִיו וּבְאִמּוֹ וּבְרַבּוֹ וּבְמִי שֶׁהוּא גָּדוֹל מִמֶּנּוּ בְּחָכְמָה וּבְמִנְיָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״רֵאשִׁית חָכְמָה יִרְאַת ה׳ שֵׂכֶל טוֹב לְכָל עוֹשֵׂיהֶם״. ״לָעוֹשִׂים״ לֹא נֶאֱמַר, אֶלָּא ״לְעוֹשֵׂיהֶם״ — לָעוֹשִׂים לִשְׁמָהּ וְלֹא לָעוֹשִׂים שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ. וְכָל הָעוֹשֶׂה שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ, נוֹחַ לוֹ שֶׁלֹּא נִבְרָא.
human_translation: Rava was wont to say: The objective of wisdom repentance and good deeds; that one should not read and study and spurn his father and his mother and his teacher and one who is greater than he in wisdom or in number as it is stated: “The beginning of wisdom is fear of the Lord, a good understanding have all who fulfill them” It is not stated All who fulfill, but rather: All who fulfill them, those who do for their own sake, not those who do them not for their own sake. One who does them not for their own sake, preferable for him had he not been created.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Margela befumei d'Rava: Tachlit chachma — teshuva u'ma'asim tovim, shelo yehi adam korei u'shoneh u'bo'et b'aviv u'v'imo u'v'rabbo u'v'mi shehu gadol mimenu b'chachma u'b'minyan, shene'emar: 'Reishit chachma yirat Hashem sechel tov le'chol oseihem.' 'La'oseim' lo ne'emar, ela 'le'oseihem' — la'oseim lishmah v'lo la'oseim shelo lishmah. V'chol ha'oseh shelo lishmah, noach lo shelo nivra." English translation: "The footstool at the feet of Rava said: The end of wisdom is repentance and good deeds, so that a person should not read, repeat, and investigate in his father, mother, teacher, or anyone greater than him in wisdom and understanding, as it is stated: 'The beginning of wisdom is the fear of the Lord, good understanding to all who perform them.' 'For the doers' was not stated, but 'to those who perform them' — for those who do for the sake of Heaven and not for those who do not do for the sake of Heaven. And anyone who does not do for the sake of Heaven, it would have been better for him not to have been created."

hebrew_text: מַרְגְּלָא בְּפוּמֵּיהּ דְּרַב: לֹא כָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא אֵין בּוֹ לֹא אֲכִילָה וְלֹא שְׁתִיָּהּ וְלֹא פְּרִיָּה וּרְבִיָּה וְלֹא מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן וְלֹא קִנְאָה וְלֹא שִׂנְאָה וְלֹא תַּחֲרוּת, אֶלָּא צַדִּיקִים יוֹשְׁבִין וְעַטְרוֹתֵיהֶם בְּרָאשֵׁיהֶם וְנֶהֱנִים מִזִּיו הַשְּׁכִינָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֶּחֱזוּ אֶת הָאֱלֹהִים וַיֹּאכְלוּ וַיִּשְׁתּוּ״.
human_translation: Rav was wont to say: The World-to-Come is not like this world. In the World-to-Come there is no eating, no drinking, no procreation, no negotiations, no jealousy, no hatred, and no competition. Rather, the righteous sit with their crowns upon their heads, enjoying the splendor of the Divine Presence, as it is stated: “And they beheld God, and they ate and drank”
llm_translation: The foot of Rav: Not like this world is the world to come. In the world to come there is no eating, no drinking, no procreation, no business dealings, no jealousy, no hatred, no competition. Rather, the righteous sit with crowns on their heads and enjoy the radiance of the Divine Presence, as it is said: "And they saw God, and they ate and drank."

hebrew_text: גְּדוֹלָה הַבְטָחָה שֶׁהִבְטִיחָן הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְנָשִׁים יוֹתֵר מִן הָאֲנָשִׁים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נָשִׁים שַׁאֲנַנּוֹת קֹמְנָה שְׁמַעְנָה קוֹלִי בָּנוֹת בֹּטְחוֹת הַאְזֵנָּה אִמְרָתִי״.
human_translation: Greater is the promise made by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to women than to men, as it is stated: “Rise up, women at ease; hear My voice, confident daughters, listen to what I say”
llm_translation: Great is the trust that the Holy One, blessed be He, has entrusted to women more than to men, as it is stated: "The women who are at ease, stand up and hear my voice, you confident daughters, listen to my speech."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב לְרַבִּי חִיָּיא: נָשִׁים בְּמַאי זָכְיָין? בְּאַקְרוֹיֵי בְּנַיְיהוּ לְבֵי כְנִישְׁתָּא, וּבְאַתְנוֹיֵי גַּבְרַיְיהוּ בֵּי רַבָּנַן, וְנָטְרִין לְגַבְרַיְיהוּ עַד דְּאָתוּ מִבֵּי רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rav said to Rabbi Ḥiyya: what do women merit for bringing their children to read in the synagogue, and for sending their husbands to study in the study hall, and for waiting for their husbands until they return from the study hall.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav to Rabbi Chiya: With what do women merit? With bringing their sons to the synagogue, and with causing their husbands to study Torah, and they wait for their husbands until they return from the study hall.

hebrew_text: כִּי הֲווֹ מִפַּטְרִי רַבָּנַן מִבֵּי רַבִּי אַמֵּי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ מִבֵּי רַבִּי חֲנִינָא, אָמְרִי לֵיהּ הָכִי: ״עוֹלָמְךָ תִּרְאֶה בְּחַיֶּיךָ, וְאַחֲרִיתְךָ לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, וְתִקְוָתְךָ לְדוֹר דּוֹרִים. לִבְּךָ יֶהְגֶּה תְּבוּנָה, פִּיךָ יְדַבֵּר חָכְמוֹת וּלְשׁוֹנְךָ יַרְחִישׁ רְנָנוֹת, עַפְעַפֶּיךָ יַיְשִׁירוּ נֶגְדְּךָ, עֵינֶיךָ יָאִירוּ בִּמְאוֹר תּוֹרָה, וּפָנֶיךָ יַזְהִירוּ כְּזוֹהַר הָרָקִיעַ, שִׂפְתוֹתֶיךָ יַבִּיעוּ דַּעַת, וְכִלְיוֹתֶיךָ תַּעֲלוֹזְנָה מֵישָׁרִים, וּפְעָמֶיךָ יָרוּצוּ לִשְׁמוֹעַ דִּבְרֵי עַתִּיק יוֹמִין״.
human_translation: When the Sages took leave of the study hall of Rabbi Ami, and some say the study hall of Rabbi Ḥanina, they would say to him the following May you see your world, in your lifetime, and may your end be to life in the World-to-Come, and may your hope for many generations. your heart meditate understanding, your mouth speak wisdom, and your tongue whisper with praise. your eyelids look directly before you, your eyes shine in the light of Torah, and your face radiate like the brightness of the firmament. your lips express knowledge, your kidneys rejoice in the upright, and your feet run to hear the words of the Ancient of Days,
llm_translation: When the Rabbis would take leave from the house of Rabbi Ammi, and they would say to him from the house of Rabbi Chanina, they would say to him thus: "Your world you shall see in your lifetime, and your end for the life of the World to Come, and your hope for generations of generations. Your heart shall meditate understanding, your mouth shall speak wisdom, and your tongue shall utter songs, your eyelashes shall sing before you, your eyes shall shine with the light of Torah, and your face shall gleam like the brightness of the firmament, your lips shall express knowledge, and your kidneys shall exult in uprightness, and your feet shall run to hear the words of the ancient days."

hebrew_text: כִּי הֲווֹ מִפַּטְרִי רַבָּנַן מִבֵּי רַב חִסְדָּא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ מִבֵּי רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי, אָמְרוּ לֵיהּ הָכִי: ״אַלּוּפֵינוּ מְסֻבָּלִים וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: When the Sages took leave of the study hall of Rav Ḥisda, and some say the study hall of Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani, they would say to him the following, “Our leaders are laden,
llm_translation: When the Rabbis were taking leave from the house of Rav Ḥisda, and they said to him from the house of Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani, they said to him thus: "Our leaders are burdened, etc."

hebrew_text: ״אַלּוּפֵינוּ מְסֻבָּלִים״ — רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, חַד אָמַר: ״אַלּוּפֵינוּ״ — בַּתּוֹרָה, וּ״מְסֻבָּלִים״ — בְּמִצְוֹת. וְחַד אָמַר: ״אַלּוּפֵינוּ״ — בַּתּוֹרָה וּבְמִצְוֹת, וּ״מְסֻבָּלִים״ — בְּיִסּוּרִים.
human_translation: Our leaders are laden. Rav and Shmuel, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar, One said: Our leaders in Torah are laden with mitzvot. And one said: Our leaders in Torah and mitzvot are laden with suffering.
llm_translation: "Our leaders are burdened" — Rav and Shmuel, and some say it was said by Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar: one said: "Our leaders" — in Torah, and "are burdened" — in commandments. And one said: "Our leaders" — in Torah and in commandments, and "are burdened" — in afflictions.

hebrew_text: ״אֵין פֶּרֶץ״ — שֶׁלֹּא תְּהֵא סִיעָתֵנוּ כְּסִיעָתוֹ שֶׁל דָּוִד שֶׁיָּצָא מִמֶּנּוּ אֲחִיתוֹפֶל. ״וְאֵין יוֹצֵאת״ — שֶׁלֹּא תְּהֵא סִיעָתֵנוּ כְּסִיעָתוֹ שֶׁל שָׁאוּל שֶׁיָּצָא מִמֶּנּוּ דּוֹאֵג הָאֲדוֹמִי. ״וְאֵין צְוָחָה״ — שֶׁלֹּא תְּהֵא סִיעָתֵנוּ כְּסִיעָתוֹ שֶׁל אֱלִישָׁע שֶׁיָּצָא מִמֶּנּוּ גֵּחֲזִי. ״בִּרְחוֹבוֹתֵינוּ״ — שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא לָנוּ בֵּן אוֹ תַּלְמִיד שֶׁמַּקְדִּיחַ תַּבְשִׁילוֹ בָּרַבִּים, כְּגוֹן יֵשׁוּ הַנּוֹצְרִי.
human_translation: “There is no breach”; that our faction should not be like the faction of David, from which Ahitophel emerged, “And no going forth”; that our faction should not be like the faction of Saul, from which Doeg the Edomite emerged, “And no outcry”; that our faction should not be like the faction of Elisha, from which Geihazi emerged. “In our open places”; that we should not have a child or student who overcooks his food in public, as Jesus the Nazarene.
llm_translation: "Ein Peretz" - that our group should not be like the group of David, from which Ahitophel emerged. "Ve'ein Yotz'et" - that our group should not be like the group of Saul, from which Doeg the Edomite emerged. "Ve'ein Tzvacha" - that our group should not be like the group of Elisha, from which Gehazi emerged. "Birechovoteinu" - that we should not have a son or student who spoils his dish in public, like Jesus the Nazarene.

hebrew_text: ״שִׁמְעוּ אֵלַי אַבִּירֵי לֵב הָרְחוֹקִים מִצְּדָקָה״, רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר. חַד אָמַר: כָּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ נִזּוֹנִין בִּצְדָקָה, וְהֵם נִזּוֹנִין בִּזְרוֹעַ. וְחַד אָמַר: כָּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ נִזּוֹנִין בִּזְכוּתָם, וְהֵם אֲפִילּוּ בִּזְכוּת עַצְמָן אֵין נִזּוֹנִין. כִּדְרַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב.
human_translation: “Hear Me, stubborn-hearted who are far from charity” Rav and Shmuel, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar, One said: The entire world is sustained by charity, while are sustained by force, And one said: The entire world is sustained by the merit their while they are not sustained not even by their own merit, in accordance with Rav Yehuda Rav said.
llm_translation: "Listen to me, you mighty of heart who are far from righteousness," Rav and Shmuel, and some say it was said by Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar to her. One said: The entire world is sustained by charity, and they are sustained by the arm. And one said: The entire world is sustained by their merit, and they are not even sustained by their own merit. As Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: בְּכָל יוֹם וְיוֹם בַּת קוֹל יוֹצֵאת מֵהַר חוֹרֵב וְאוֹמֶרֶת: כָּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ נִזּוֹנִין בִּשְׁבִיל חֲנִינָא בְּנִי, וַחֲנִינָא בְּנִי דַּי לוֹ בְּקַב חָרוּבִין מֵעֶרֶב שַׁבָּת לְעֶרֶב שַׁבָּת.
human_translation: As Rav Yehuda said Rav said: Every day a Divine Voice emerges from Mount Horeb and says: The entire world is sustained by Ḥanina my son, and Ḥanina, my son, a kav of carobs is sufficient from Shabbat eve to Shabbat eve.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Every day a heavenly voice emerges from Mount Horeb and proclaims: "The entire world is sustained for the sake of Chanina my son, and Chanina my son is sufficient with a measure of carobs from one Friday evening to the next Friday evening."

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַב יְהוּדָה. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה מַאן ״אַבִּירֵי לֵב״ — גּוֹבָאֵי טַפְשָׁאֵי. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: תִּדַּע, דְּהָא לָא אִיגַּיַּיר גִּיּוֹרָא מִינַּיְיהוּ.
human_translation: And disagrees with Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda said, who are the stubborn-hearted? foolish of Gova’ei. Rav Yosef said: Know as no convert has ever converted from their
llm_translation: Disagreement of Rav Yehudah. For Rav Yehudah said: Who are the "abbirei lev"? — The arrogant ones. Rav Yosef said: Know that they do not accept proselytes from them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: בְּנֵי מָתָא מַחְסֵיָא ״אַבִּירֵי לֵב״ נִינְהוּ, דְּקָא חָזוּ יְקָרָא דְאוֹרָיְיתָא תְּרֵי זִמְנֵי בְּשַׁתָּא, וְלָא קָמִגַּיַּיר גִּיּוֹרָא מִינַּיְיהוּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: of Mata Meḥasya are the stubborn-hearted, as they witness the glory of the Torah twice a year yet no convert has ever converted from their
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: The people of Mata Mechesia are called "the mighty of heart," for they would see the preciousness of the Torah twice a year, and not neglect the study of Torah from them.

hebrew_text: חָתָן אִם רוֹצֶה לִקְרוֹת וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: if a groom wishes to recite
llm_translation: Son-in-law, if he wants to read, and so on.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל חָיֵישׁ לְיוּהֲרָא וְרַבָּנַן לָא חָיְישִׁי לְיוּהֲרָא, וְהָא אִיפְּכָא שָׁמְעִינַן לְהוּ! דִּתְנַן: מָקוֹם שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ לַעֲשׂוֹת מְלָאכָה בְּתִשְׁעָה בְּאָב — עוֹשִׂין. מָקוֹם שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ שֶׁלֹּא לַעֲשׂוֹת — אֵין עוֹשִׂין. וְכָל מָקוֹם תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים בְּטֵלִים. רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: לְעוֹלָם יַעֲשֶׂה כָּל אָדָם אֶת עַצְמוֹ כְּתַלְמִיד חָכָם.
human_translation: Is that to say that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is concerned about presumptuousness and the Rabbis are not concerned about presumptuousness? Didn’t we learn they the opposite? As we learned A place where they were accustomed to perform labor on Ninth of Av, one perform A place where they were accustomed not to perform one not perform And everywhere, Torah scholars are idle Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: one should always conduct himself as a Torah scholar.
llm_translation: In the matter of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, he is concerned for the honor, but the Rabbis are not concerned for the honor, and behold, we have heard the opposite! For it was taught: In a place where they are accustomed to work on the ninth of Av, they work. In a place where they are not accustomed, they do not work. And in every place, the students of the sages are exempt. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A person should always conduct himself as a disciple of a wise person.

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבָּנַן אַדְּרַבָּנַן, קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אַדְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל!
human_translation: there is a contradiction between the Rabbis and the Rabbis there is a contradiction between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel
llm_translation: The difficulty of the sages is a difficulty, the difficulty of Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel is a difficulty, the difficulty of Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מוּחְלֶפֶת הַשִּׁיטָה. רַב שִׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם לֹא תַּחְלִיף. דְּרַבָּנַן אַדְּרַבָּנַן לָא קַשְׁיָא: קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, כֵּיוָן דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא קָא קָרוּ וְאִיהוּ נָמֵי קָרֵי — לָא מִיחְזֵי כְּיוּהֲרָא. הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא עָבְדִי מְלָאכָה וְאִיהוּ לָא קָא עָבֵיד — מִיחְזֵי כְּיוּהֲרָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The attribution is reversed Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said: Actually, not reverse the Rabbis and the Rabbis is not difficult. the recitation of Shema since everyone is reciting and he is also reciting it does not appear as presumptuousness. Here, since everyone is performing labor and he is not performing labor, appears as presumptuousness.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: The switching of the branch. Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi, said: One should never switch. The Rabbis do not find difficulty: the recitation of the Shema, since everyone else is reciting and he is not, it does not appear as if he is doing something special. Here, since everyone else is working and he is not, it appears as if he is doing something special.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אַדְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָתָם בְּכַוָּנָה תַלְיָא מִילְּתָא, וַאֲנַן סָהֲדֵי דְּלָא מָצֵי לְכַוּוֹנֵי דַּעְתֵּיהּ. אֲבָל הָכָא, הָרוֹאֶה אוֹמֵר: מְלָאכָה הוּא דְּאֵין לוֹ. פּוּק חֲזִי כַּמָּה בַּטְלָנֵי אִיכָּא בְּשׁוּקָא.
human_translation: between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is not difficult. There, the matter is dependent upon his concentrate, it is clear to all he is unable to concentrate. But here, one who sees says: It is he has no labor Go out and see how many idle people there are in the marketplace,
llm_translation: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: It is not difficult. There, the matter depends on intention, and we testify that he did not have the intention. But here, one who sees says: It is a forbidden labor. Go out and see how many idle people there are in the marketplace.

hebrew_text: הדרן עלך היה קורא
llm_translation: The honor upon you, he was reading.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁמֵּתוֹ מוּטָּל לְפָנָיו — פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין, וּמִכָּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: One whose deceased is laid out before him is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer, and from phylacteries, as well as all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One whose dead body is lying before him - he is exempt from reciting the Shema, from prayer, from wearing tefillin, and from all the commandments stated in the Torah.

hebrew_text: נוֹשְׂאֵי הַמִּטָּה וְחִלּוּפֵיהֶן, וְחִלּוּפֵי חִלּוּפֵיהֶן, אֶת שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמִּטָּה, וְאֶת שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמִּטָּה. אֶת שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמִּטָּה צוֹרֶךְ בָּהֶם — פְּטוּרִין, וְאֶת שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמִּטָּה צוֹרֶךְ בָּהֶם — חַיָּיבִין. וְאֵלּוּ וָאֵלּוּ פְּטוּרִים מִן הַתְּפִלָּה.
human_translation: the pallbearers and their replacements and the replacements of their replacements, those before the bier and those after the bier. Those before the bier who are needed are exempt while those after the bier, they are needed obligated these and those are exempt from prayer,
llm_translation: Those who carry the bed and their substitutes, and the substitutes of their substitutes, both those in front of the bed and those behind the bed. Those in front of the bed are exempt from prayer and those behind the bed are obligated to pray. And both these and those are exempt from prayer.

hebrew_text: קָבְרוּ אֶת הַמֵּת וְחָזְרוּ, אִם יְכוֹלִין לְהַתְחִיל וְלִגְמוֹר עַד שֶׁלֹּא יַגִּיעוּ לַשּׁוּרָה — יַתְחִילוּ. וְאִם לָאו — לֹא יַתְחִילוּ.
human_translation: they buried the deceased and returned, if they begin and conclude before they arrive at the row, they should begin. If not they should not begin.
llm_translation: Bury the dead and return, if able to begin and finish until they reach the row - they should begin. And if not - they should not begin.

hebrew_text: הָעוֹמְדִים בַּשּׁוּרָה, הַפְּנִימִיִּים — פְּטוּרִים, וְהַחִיצוֹנִים — חַיָּיבִים. נָשִׁים וַעֲבָדִים וּקְטַנִּים פְּטוּרִים מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין, וְחַיָּיבִין בִּתְפִלָּה וּבִמְזוּזָה וּבְבִרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן.
human_translation: those standing in the row, those interior are exempt those exterior are obligated Women, slaves and minors are exempt from the recitation of Shema and from phylacteries, but are obligated in prayer, mezuza and Grace after Meals.
llm_translation: Those standing in the courtyard, the inner ones are exempt, and the outer ones are obligated. Women, slaves, and minors are exempt from reciting the Shema and from wearing Tefillin, but they are obligated in prayer, Mezuzah, and the blessing after meals.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מוּטָּל לְפָנָיו — אִין, וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ מוּטָּל לְפָנָיו — לָא.
human_translation: laid out before him, yes, not laid out before him, no,
llm_translation: "Gema' mutal lefanav — ein, ve'she'eino mutal lefanav — la."

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהִי: מִי שֶׁמֵּתוֹ מוּטָּל לְפָנָיו — אוֹכֵל בְּבַיִת אַחֵר, וְאִם אֵין לוֹ בַּיִת אַחֵר — אוֹכֵל בְּבֵית חֲבֵירוֹ, וְאִם אֵין לוֹ בֵּית חֲבֵירוֹ — עוֹשֶׂה מְחִיצָה וְאוֹכֵל, וְאִם אֵין לוֹ דָּבָר לַעֲשׂוֹת מְחִיצָּה — מַחֲזִיר פָּנָיו וְאוֹכֵל. וְאֵינוֹ מֵיסֵב וְאוֹכֵל. וְאֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל בָּשָׂר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן, וְאֵינוֹ מְבָרֵךְ, וְאֵינוֹ מְזַמֵּן.
human_translation: raises a contradiction One whose deceased is laid out before him eats in another room. If he does not have another room, he eats in the house of a friend. If he does not have a friend’s house he makes a partition and eats. If he does not have material to make a partition, he averts his face eats. And he does not recline while he eats, Furthermore, he neither eats meat nor drinks wine, and does not recite blessing and does not invite
llm_translation: And they asked: If one's deceased is lying before him — he eats in another house, and if he does not have another house — he eats in his friend's house, and if he does not have his friend's house — he makes a partition and eats, and if he has nothing to make a partition — he turns his face and eats. And he does not recline and eat. And he does not eat meat and he does not drink wine, and he does not recite a blessing, and he does not invite others.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו, וְאֵין מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו, וּפָטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין וּמִכׇּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה. וּבְשַׁבָּת מֵיסֵב וְאוֹכֵל בָּשָׂר וְשׁוֹתֶה יַיִן, וּמְבָרֵךְ וּמְזַמֵּן, וּמְבָרְכִין עָלָיו וּמְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו, וְחַיָּיב בְּכָל הַמִּצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה. רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב בְּאֵלּוּ — נִתְחַיֵּיב בְּכוּלָּן.
human_translation: And to recite a blessing on his behalf, nor do others invite him He is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer and from phylacteries, and from all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah. On Shabbat, he reclines and eats meat and drinks wine, and recites blessings and invite and others may recite blessings on his behalf and invite him and he is obligated in all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Just as he is obligated to these he is obligated to all
llm_translation: And not bless upon him, and not invite upon him, and exempt from reading Shema and from prayer and from Tefillin and from all the commandments stated in the Torah. And on Shabbat, he reclines and eats meat and drinks wine, and blesses and invites, and they bless upon him and invite upon him, and is obligated in all the commandments stated in the Torah. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Since he is obligated in these - he is obligated in all of them.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ — תַּשְׁמִישׁ הַמִּטָּה אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is between The between them is conjugal relations.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said: What is the difference between them - there is marital relations that distinguishes between them.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין וּמִכׇּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: תַּרְגְּמָא אַמַּחֲזִיר פָּנָיו וְאוֹכֵל. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁמּוּטָּל עָלָיו לְקוֹבְרוֹ, כְּמוּטָל לְפָנָיו דָּמֵי. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיָּקׇם אַבְרָהָם מֵעַל פְּנֵי מֵתוֹ״, וְנֶאֱמַר: ״וְאֶקְבְּרָה מֵתִי מִלְּפָנָי״, כָּל זְמַן שֶׁמּוּטָּל עָלָיו לְקוֹבְרוֹ כְּמוּטָל לְפָנָיו דָּמֵי.
human_translation: In any event, teaches one is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer and from phylacteries, and from all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah. Rav Pappa said: Explain one turns his face and eats, Rav Ashi says: since it is incumbent upon him to bury the deceased, as if he is laid out before him, as it is stated: “And Abraham rose up from before his dead” and it is stated: “So that I may bury my dead from before me” As long as it is incumbent upon him to bury him, as he is laid out before him.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who is engaged in eating is exempt from reciting the Shema, from prayer, from putting on tefillin, and from all the other mitzvot mentioned in the Torah! Rav Papa said: If one is translating, he may turn his face away and eat. Rav Ashi said: Once a person is destined to be buried, his status is like one who is already buried, as it is stated: "And Abraham arose from before his dead" (Genesis 23:3), and it is also stated: "And I will bury my dead from before me" (Genesis 23:4). As long as one is destined to be buried, his status is like one who is already buried.

hebrew_text: מֵתוֹ — אִין, אֲבָל מְשַׁמְּרוֹ — לָא.
human_translation: his deceased yes, But, watching over no,
llm_translation: His death - no, but his preservation - yes.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: הַמְשַׁמֵּר אֶת הַמֵּת, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵתוֹ — פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין וּמִכׇּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה! מְשַׁמְּרוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵתוֹ, מֵתוֹ אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְשַׁמְּרוֹ.
human_translation: Wasn’t it taught One who watches over the deceased, even if it is not his deceased is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer and from phylacteries, and from all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah? one watches over but it is not his deceased it is his deceased but he is not watching over
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: One who guards a dead body, even though it is not his dead relative — he is exempt from reciting the Shema, from prayer, from wearing Tefillin, and from all the commandments stated in the Torah! If he guards it, even though it is not his dead relative, his dead relative even though he does not guard it.

hebrew_text: מֵתוֹ וּמְשַׁמְּרוֹ — אִין, אֲבָל מְהַלֵּךְ בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת — לָא. וְהָתַנְיָא: לֹא יְהַלֵּךְ אָדָם בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת וּתְפִילִּין בְּרֹאשׁוֹ וְסֵפֶר תּוֹרָה בִּזְרוֹעוֹ וְקוֹרֵא. וְאִם עוֹשֶׂה כֵּן — עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״לוֹעֵג לָרָשׁ חֵרֵף עוֹשֵׂהוּ״.
human_translation: his deceased watching over he is However, one walking in a cemetery is not Wasn’t it taught One may not walk in a cemetery with phylacteries on his head and a Torah scroll in his arm and read If one does so he commits due to “He who mocks the poor blasphemes his Creator”
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "His dead and guarding - no, but walking in the cemetery - yes. And it was taught: A person should not walk in the cemetery with Tefillin on his head, a Torah scroll in his arm, and read. And if he does so - he transgresses the prohibition of 'He who mocks the poor insults his Maker.'"

hebrew_text: הָתָם, תּוֹךְ אַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת הוּא דְאָסוּר, חוּץ לְאַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת — חַיָּיב. דְּאָמַר מָר מֵת תּוֹפֵס אַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת לִקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע. הָכָא, חוּץ לְאַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת נָמֵי פָּטוּר.
human_translation: There, within four cubits that is prohibited. beyond four cubits one is obligated As the Master said: The deceased occupies four cubits recitation of Shema . Here, beyond four cubits he is also exempt.
llm_translation: There, within four cubits, it is prohibited; outside of four cubits - obligated. As Mar said: One who dies must take four cubits for the recitation of Shema. Here, outside of four cubits, one is also exempt.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. הַמְשַׁמֵּר אֶת הַמֵּת אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵתוֹ — פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין וּמִכׇּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה. הָיוּ שְׁנַיִם — זֶה מְשַׁמֵּר וְזֶה קוֹרֵא, וְזֶה מְשַׁמֵּר וְזֶה קוֹרֵא. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: הָיוּ בָּאִים בִּסְפִינָה — מַנִּיחוֹ בְּזָוִית זוֹ, וּמִתְפַּלְּלִין שְׁנֵיהֶם בְּזָוִית אַחֶרֶת.
human_translation: matter itself. One who watches over the deceased, even though it is not his dead is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer and from phylacteries, and from all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah. two were this watches and that recites that watches and this recites Ben Azzai says: they were traveling on a boat, they to set down in this corner and both pray in another corner
llm_translation: Body. One who guards the deceased even though he is not his relative - exempt from reciting the Shema, from prayer, from wearing tefillin, and from all the commandments stated in the Torah. If there are two people - one guards and one reads, and one guards and one reads. Ben Azzai says: If they come by boat - place one in one corner, and they both pray in another corner.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אָמַר רָבִינָא: חוֹשְׁשִׁין לְעַכְבָּרִים אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ. מָר סָבַר: חָיְישִׁינַן. וּמַר סָבַר: לָא חָיְישִׁינַן.
human_translation: What is between these Ravina said: between them is concerned about mice The Sage holds that we are concerned The Sage, maintains that we are not concerned about mice
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? Ravina said: There is a difference between them regarding being concerned about mice. One Master holds: We are concerned, and the other Master holds: We are not concerned.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמּוֹלִיךְ עֲצָמוֹת מִמָּקוֹם לְמָקוֹם, הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יִתְּנֵם בְּדִסַקַּיָּא וְיִתְּנֵם עַל גַּבֵּי חֲמוֹר וְיִרְכַּב עֲלֵיהֶם, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנּוֹהֵג בָּהֶם מִנְהַג בִּזָּיוֹן. וְאִם הָיָה מִתְיָרֵא מִפְּנֵי גּוֹיִם וּמִפְּנֵי לִסְטִים — מוּתָּר. וּכְדֶרֶךְ שֶׁאָמְרוּ בַּעֲצָמוֹת כָּךְ אָמְרוּ בְּסֵפֶר תּוֹרָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One who transports bones from place to place may not place them in a saddlebag [ disakaya ] and place them on the donkey’s back and ride on them, as he treats disgracefully. However, if he is afraid of gentiles highwaymen he is permitted And just as they said with regard to bones, so they said with regard to a Torah scroll.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who transports bones from place to place, he may not place them in a basket and place them on the back of a donkey and ride upon them, because this is a disrespectful practice. But if he is afraid of gentiles or bandits, it is permitted. And just as they said regarding bones, so they said regarding a Torah scroll.

hebrew_text: אַהֵיָיא? אִילֵּימָא אַרֵישָׁא — פְּשִׁיטָא! מִי גָּרַע סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה מֵעֲצָמוֹת? אֶלָּא אַסֵּיפָא.
human_translation: To what If you say the first clause obvious. Is a Torah scroll less than bones to the latter clause
llm_translation: Ahayya? Ileima areisha - peshita! Mi gara sefer torah me'atzamot? Ella asseifa.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַחֲבָה אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: כָּל הָרוֹאֶה הַמֵּת וְאֵינוֹ מְלַוֵּהוּ עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״לֹעֵג לָרָשׁ חֵרֵף עֹשֵׂהוּ״. וְאִם הִלְוָהוּ מַה שְּׂכָרוֹ? אָמַר רַב אַסִּי, עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב אוֹמֵר: ״מַלְוֵה ה׳ חוֹנֵן דָּל״ ״וּמְכַבְּדוֹ חֹנֵן אֶבְיוֹן״.
human_translation: Raḥava said Rav Yehuda said: One who sees the deceased and does not escort him has committed a transgression due to “He who mocks the poor blasphemes his Creator.” (Proverbs 17:5) And if he does escort him, what is his reward? Rav Asi said: The verse says about him: “He who gives to the poor gives a loan to the Lord, but he who is gracious to the poor honors Him”
llm_translation: Rahavah said, Rav Yehudah said: Anyone who sees a dead person and does not accompany him transgresses the verse, "He who mocks the poor insults his Maker" (Proverbs 17:5). And if he does accompany him, what is his reward? Rav Assi said: Regarding him the verse states, "Whoever is gracious to the poor lends to the Lord, and He will repay him for his good deed" (Proverbs 19:17).

hebrew_text: רַבִּי חִיָּיא וְרַבִּי יוֹנָתָן הֲווֹ שָׁקְלִי וְאָזְלִי בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת. הֲוָה קָשַׁדְיָא תְּכֵלְתָּא דְרַבִּי יוֹנָתָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי חִיָּיא: דַּלְיַיהּ, כְּדַי שֶׁלֹּא יֹאמְרוּ: לְמָחָר בָּאִין אֶצְלֵנוּ, וְעַכְשָׁיו מְחָרְפִין אוֹתָנוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Yonatan were walking in a cemetery and the sky-blue string Rabbi Yonatan’s was cast Rabbi Ḥiyya said Lift it, so will not say: Tomorrow, come to us, and now insulting us.
llm_translation: Rabbi Chiya and Rabbi Yonatan were walking and went to the cemetery. There was a blue thread of Rabbi Yonatan. Rabbi Chiya said to him: "Remove it, so they will not say, 'Tomorrow they come to us, and now they are cursing us.'"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וּמִי יָדְעִי כּוּלֵּי הַאי? וְהָא כְּתִיב: ״וְהַמֵּתִים אֵינָם יוֹדְעִים מְאוּמָה״! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִם קָרִיתָ — לֹא שָׁנִיתָ. אִם שָׁנִיתָ — לֹא שִׁלַּשְׁתָּ. אִם שִׁלַּשְׁתָּ — לֹא פֵּירְשׁוּ לְךָ. ״כִּי הַחַיִּים יוֹדְעִים שֶׁיָּמוּתוּ״ — אֵלּוּ צַדִּיקִים שֶׁבְּמִיתָתָן נִקְרְאוּ חַיִּים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּבְנָיָהוּ בֶן יְהוֹיָדָע בֶּן אִישׁ חַי רַב פְּעָלִים מִקַּבְצְאֵל הוּא הִכָּה אֵת שְׁנֵי אֲרִאֵל מוֹאָב וְהוּא יָרַד וְהִכָּה אֶת הָאֲרִי בְּתוֹךְ הַבּוֹר בְּיוֹם הַשָּׁלֶג״.
human_translation: said to him: Do know so much? Isn’t it stated: “And the dead know nothing” said to him: If you read you did not a second time, and if you a second time, you did not a third time, and if you a third time, they did not explain it to you For the living know that they will die, these are the righteous, who even in their death are called living. as it is stated: “And Benayahu, son of Yehoyada, son of a valiant man of Kabze’el, who had done mighty deeds, he smote the two altar-hearths of Moab; he went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow”
llm_translation: He said to him: And who knows all this? But it is written: "And the dead know nothing!" He said to him: If you have read it - you have not changed it. If you have changed it - you have not repeated it. If you have repeated it - they did not explain it to you. "For the living know that they will die" - these are the righteous who are called living in their death, as it is said: "And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a living man, great in deeds, from Kabzeel, he struck down two lion-like heroes of Moab; he also went down and struck down a lion in a pit on a snowy day."
