llm_translation: Disagreement of Shmuel, for Shmuel said: There is no difference between this world and the days of the Messiah except for the cessation of subjugation to kingdoms alone. As it is stated: "For the needy shall not cease out of the land."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כׇּל הַנְּבִיאִים כּוּלָּן לֹא נִתְנַבְּאוּ אֶלָּא לְבַעֲלֵי תְשׁוּבָה, אֲבָל צַדִּיקִים גְּמוּרִים ״עַיִן לֹא רָאָתָה אֱלֹהִים זוּלָתְךָ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: All of the prophets only prophesied with regard to penitents but with regard to the full-fledged righteous “No eye has seen it, God, aside from You.”
llm_translation: And Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: All the prophets, all of them, were only prophesied for those who repent, but completely righteous individuals "Eye has not seen, O God, besides You."

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: מָקוֹם שֶׁבַּעֲלֵי תְשׁוּבָה עוֹמְדִין — צַדִּיקִים גְּמוּרִים אֵינָם עוֹמְדִין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שָׁלוֹם שָׁלוֹם לָרָחוֹק וְלַקָּרוֹב״. ״לָרָחוֹק״ בְּרֵישָׁא, וַהֲדַר ״לַקָּרוֹב״.
human_translation: And this disagrees with Rabbi Abbahu As Rabbi Abbahu said: In the place where penitents stand, even the full-fledged righteous do not stand, as it is stated: “Peace, peace upon him who is far and him who is near.” him who is far, and thereafter him who is near,
llm_translation: Dispute of Rabbi Avahu, for Rabbi Avahu said: Where penitents stand, completely righteous individuals do not stand, as it is stated: "Peace, peace to the far and to the near." "To the far" initially, and then "to the near."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר לְךָ: מַאי ״רָחוֹק״ — שֶׁהָיָה רָחוֹק מִדְּבַר עֲבֵירָה מֵעִיקָּרָא. וּמַאי ״קָרוֹב״ — שֶׁהָיָה קָרוֹב לִדְבַר עֲבֵירָה, וְנִתְרַחֵק מִמֶּנּוּ הַשְׁתָּא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said to you: What is him who is far? who was distant from an act of transgression from the outset, What is him who is near? who was close to an act of transgression but has now distanced from it,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said to you: What is "far"? — that he was far from the root of sin. And what is "near"? — that he was near to sin, and distanced himself from it at that moment.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״עַיִן לֹא רָאָתָה״? אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: זֶה יַיִן הַמְשׁוּמָּר בַּעֲנָבָיו מִשֵּׁשֶׁת יְמֵי בְּרֵאשִׁית. רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר: זֶה עֵדֶן, שֶׁלֹּא שָׁלְטָה בּוֹ עֵין כׇּל בְּרִיָּה.
human_translation: What is “No eye has seen it”? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: That is the wine that has been preserved in its grapes since the six days of creation Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said: That is Eden, which no creature’s eye has surveyed.
llm_translation: What is meant by "an eye that has not seen"? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: This refers to wine that is preserved in its grapes from the six days of Creation. Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said: This is Eden, which no eye of any creature has ever ruled over.

hebrew_text: שֶׁמָּא תֹּאמַר: אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן הֵיכָן הָיָה? בַּגָּן.
human_translation: Lest you will say: Where was Adam the first in the Garden
llm_translation: Perhaps you will say: Where was Adam the first man? In the Garden.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁמָּא תֹּאמַר: הוּא גַּן, הוּא עֵדֶן, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְנָהָר יוֹצֵא מֵעֵדֶן לְהַשְׁקוֹת אֶת הַגָּן״, גַּן לְחוּד וְעֵדֶן לְחוּד.
human_translation: And lest you will say: It is Garden and it is Eden; the verse states: “And a river went out from Eden to water the Garden” Garden on its own and Eden on its own.
llm_translation: And perhaps you will say: He is the garden, he is the Eden, Scripture says: "And a river goes out of Eden to water the garden," Garden is separate and Eden is separate.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁחָלָה בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל. שִׁגֵּר שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים אֵצֶל רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא לְבַקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים. כֵּיוָן שֶׁרָאָה אוֹתָם, עָלָה לָעֲלִיָּיה, וּבִקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים. בִּירִידָתוֹ אָמַר לָהֶם: לְכוּ, שֶׁחֲלָצַתּוּ חַמָּה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: וְכִי נָבִיא אַתָּה?! אָמַר לָהֶן: לֹא נָבִיא אָנֹכִי וְלֹא בֶן נָבִיא אָנֹכִי, אֶלָּא כָּךְ מְקּוּבְּלַנִי: אִם שְׁגוּרָה תְּפִלָּתִי בְּפִי — יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁהוּא מְקוּבָּל, וְאִם לָאו — יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁהוּא מְטוֹרָף. יָשְׁבוּ וְכָתְבוּ וְכִוְּונוּ אוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה. וּכְשֶׁבָּאוּ אֵצֶל רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, אָמַר לָהֶן: הָעֲבוֹדָה, לֹא חִסַּרְתֶּם וְלֹא הוֹתַרְתֶּם, אֶלָּא כָּךְ הָיָה מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה חֲלָצַתּוּ חַמָּה וְשָׁאַל לָנוּ מַיִם לִשְׁתּוֹת.
human_translation: The Sages taught: an incident where Rabban Gamliel’s son fell ill. dispatched two scholars to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa to pray for mercy on his behalf. When saw them he went up to the attic and prayed for mercy on his behalf. Upon his descent, he said to go as the fever has already left asked him: Are you a prophet? He replied to them: I am neither a prophet nor son of a prophet but I have received this If my prayer is fluent in my mouth I know that is accepted. And if not, I know that is rejected. sat and wrote and approximated that moment When they came before Rabban Gamliel said to them: by the Temple service you were neither earlier or later; rather, this is how the event his fever broke and he asked us for water to drink.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There was an incident involving the son of Rabban Gamliel who fell ill. He sent two Torah scholars to Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa to request mercy for him. When he saw them, he ascended to the upper room and requested mercy for him. Upon his descent, he said to them: "Go, for you have removed the sun." They said to him: "Are you a prophet?" He said to them: "I am not a prophet, nor am I the son of a prophet, but this is how I have been taught: If my prayer is fluent in my mouth - I know that it is accepted, and if not - I know that it is rejected." They sat, wrote, and concentrated for that hour. When they came to Rabban Gamliel, he said to them: "The service, you have not lacked and you have not left out, but this is what happened at that time - you removed the sun and he asked us for water to drink."

hebrew_text: וְשׁוּב מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא שֶׁהָלַךְ לִלְמוֹד תּוֹרָה אֵצֶל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי, וְחָלָה בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי. אָמַר לוֹ: חֲנִינָא בְּנִי, בַּקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים וְיִחְיֶה. הִנִּיחַ רֹאשׁוֹ בֵּין בִּרְכָּיו וּבִקֵּשׁ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים, וְחָיָה. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן זַכַּאי: אִלְמָלֵי הֵטִיחַ בֶּן זַכַּאי אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ בֵּין בִּרְכָּיו כׇּל הַיּוֹם כּוּלּוֹ — לֹא הָיוּ מַשְׁגִּיחִים עָלָיו. אָמְרָה לוֹ אִשְׁתּוֹ: וְכִי חֲנִינָא גָּדוֹל מִמְּךָ? אָמַר לָהּ: לָאו, אֶלָּא הוּא דּוֹמֶה כְּעֶבֶד לִפְנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ, וַאֲנִי דּוֹמֶה כְּשַׂר לִפְנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ.
human_translation: And another incident Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa, who went to study Torah before Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, and Rabbi Yoḥanan’s son fell ill. He said to him: Ḥanina, my son, pray for mercy on behalf of so that he will live. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa placed his head between his knees and prayed for mercy upon his behalf, and lived. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said Had ben Zakkai stuck his head between his knees throughout the entire day, they would have paid him no attention. His wife said to him: And is Ḥanina greater than you? He replied to her: No, but he is like a servant before the King, I, am like a minister before the King,
llm_translation: And there is a story about Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa who went to study Torah with Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai, and the son of Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai fell ill. He said to him: Chanina my son, pray for him to live. He placed his head between his knees and prayed for him, and he lived. Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said: If ben Zakkai had placed his head between his knees all day long, they would not have paid attention to him. His wife said to him: Is Chanina greater than you? He said to her: No, but he is like a servant before the king, and I am like a minister before the king.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אַל יִתְפַּלֵּל אָדָם אֶלָּא בְּבַיִת שֶׁיֵּשׁ שָׁם חַלּוֹנוֹת. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְכַוִּין פְּתִיחָן לֵיהּ בְּעִלִּיתֵהּ (לָקֳבֵל) [נֶגֶד] יְרוּשְׁלֶם״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One may only pray in a house with windows, as it is stated there were open windows
llm_translation: And Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: A person should only pray in a house that has windows, as it is stated: "And set the opening thereof toward Jerusalem" (Daniel 6:11).

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: חֲצִיף עֲלַי מַאן דִּמְצַלֵּי בְּבַקְתָּא.
human_translation: Rav Kahana said: I consider impudent one who prays in a field.
llm_translation: Rav Kahana said: "It is angering to me the one who extinguishes in the pit."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: חֲצִיף עֲלַי מַאן דִּמְפָרֵשׁ חִטְאֵיהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אַשְׁרֵי נְשׂוּי פֶּשַׁע כְּסוּי חֲטָאָה״.
human_translation: Rav Kahana also said: I consider impudent one who specifies his transgression, as it is stated: “Happy is he whose iniquity is forgiven, whose transgression is covered over”
llm_translation: And Rav Kahana said: Woe to one who reveals his sins, as it is said: "Happy is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered."

hebrew_text: הדרן עלך אין עומדין
llm_translation: We will return to you, we do not stand.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כֵּיצַד מְבָרְכִין עַל הַפֵּירוֹת? עַל פֵּירוֹת הָאִילָן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״, חוּץ מִן הַיַּיִן, שֶׁעַל הַיַּיִן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הַגֶּפֶן״. וְעַל פֵּירוֹת הָאָרֶץ הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, חוּץ מִן הַפַּת, שֶׁעַל הַפַּת הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. וְעַל הַיְּרָקוֹת הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי דְשָׁאִים״.
human_translation: How does one recite a blessing over fruits? Over fruits tree one recites: Who creates fruit of the tree, with the exception of wine. Over wine one recites: Who creates fruit of the vine. Over fruits the earth, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground, with the exception of bread. as over bread one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth. Over vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Rabbi Yehuda says Who creates various kinds of herbs.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: How does one bless over fruits? Over the fruits of the tree, one says: "Who creates the fruit of the tree," except for wine, for over wine one says: "Who creates the fruit of the vine." And over the fruits of the ground, one says: "Who creates the fruit of the earth," except for bread, for over bread one says: "Who brings forth bread from the earth." And over vegetables, one says: "Who creates the fruit of the earth." Rabbi Yehuda says: "Who creates various types of herbs."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״קֹדֶשׁ הִלּוּלִים לַה׳״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁטְּעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לִפְנֵיהֶם וּלְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. מִכָּאן אָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: אָסוּר לְאָדָם שֶׁיִּטְעוֹם כְּלוּם קוֹדֶם שֶׁיְּבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: From where are these matters, As the Sages taught “…sanctified for praises before the Lord” teaches they require blessing beforehand and thereafter, From here, Rabbi Akiva said: A person is forbidden to taste anything before he recites a blessing,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What are these words teaching us? For the Rabbis taught: "Holy are the Hallelujahs to the Lord," teaches that they are obligated to bless before and after them. From here Rabbi Akiva said: It is forbidden for a person to taste them as nothing before blessing.

hebrew_text: וְהַאי ״קֹדֶשׁ הִלּוּלִים״ לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא? הַאי מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ חַד דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא אַחֲלֵיהּ וַהֲדַר אִכְלֵיהּ. וְאִידָךְ דָּבָר הַטָּעוּן שִׁירָה, טָעוּן חִלּוּל, וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ טָעוּן שִׁירָה, אֵין טָעוּן חִלּוּל. וְכִדְרַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן דְּאָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין אוֹמְרִים שִׁירָה אֶלָּא עַל הַיַּיִן? — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתֹּאמֶר לָהֶם הַגֶּפֶן הֶחֳדַלְתִּי אֶת תִּירוֹשִׁי הַמְשַׂמֵּחַ אֱלֹהִים וַאֲנָשִׁים״, אִם אֲנָשִׁים מְשַׂמֵּחַ, אֱלֹהִים בַּמֶּה מְשַׂמֵּחַ? מִכָּאן שֶׁאֵין אוֹמְרִים שִׁירָה אֶלָּא עַל הַיַּיִן!
human_translation: And this “Sanctified for praises,” come for that This is necessary One that the Merciful One said: Redeem it and then eat it. And the other An object which requires a song requires redemption. And that which does not require a song does not require redemption. And in accordance with Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said Rabbi Yonatan said, as Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said Rabbi Yonatan said: From where one only recites a song over the wine As it is stated: “And the vine replied: Should I leave my wine, which gladdens God and man, If gladdens people, in what does it gladden God? from here that one only recites a song over wine,
llm_translation: The "holy of holies" is thus the reason it came? This one requires for it one as it says the Merciful One allows it and then eats it. And the other, a matter that requires singing, requires desecration, and that which does not require singing, does not require desecration. And like Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said, Rabbi Yonatan said in the name of Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani who said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: From where do we know that one only recites a song over wine? — As it says: "And the vine said to them, 'Should I leave my wine, which cheers God and men?'" If men bring joy, with what does God bring joy? From here we learn that one only recites a song over wine!

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּתָנֵי ״נֶטַע רְבָעִי״. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּתָנֵי ״כֶּרֶם רְבָעִי״ מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? דְּאִתְּמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּרַבִּי, חַד תָּנֵי ״כֶּרֶם רְבָעִי״, וְחַד תָּנֵי ״נֶטַע רְבָעִי״.
human_translation: this well according to the one who taught, A fourth-year sapling However, according to the one who taught, A fourth-year grapevine, what can be said? As it was stated: Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi one taught A fourth-year grapevine, and one taught A fourth-year sapling.
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: To whom does the one who teaches "a planted fourth" leave room for? Rather, to whom does the one who teaches "a vineyard fourth" leave room for? What can be said? For it was stated: Rabbi Chiya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi, one teaches "a vineyard fourth," and one teaches "a planted fourth."

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּתָנֵי ״כֶּרֶם רְבָעִי״ הָנִיחָא אִי יָלֵיף גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״לְהוֹסִיף לָכֶם תְּבוּאָתוֹ״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״וּתְבוּאַת הַכָּרֶם״. מָה לְהַלָּן כֶּרֶם, אַף כָּאן כֶּרֶם. אִייַּתַּר לֵיהּ חַד ״הִלּוּל״ לִבְרָכָה.
human_translation: And according to the one who taught: A fourth year grapevine, this well if he derives from a verbal analogy [ gezera shava ], As it was taught Rabbi said: It is stated here so that it may increase your produce [ tevuato ]; And it is stated below, with the produce [ utevuat ] of the vineyard” Just as below, vineyards; so too, here, vineyards. one extra hillul the blessing.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And according to the one who teaches "a quarter vineyard," it is satisfactory if it is similar to a decree. For it was taught: Rabbi says: It is stated here "to add to you its produce," and it is stated there "and the produce of the vineyard." Just as there it is a vineyard, so too here it is a vineyard. One additional word is necessary for it, "praise," for a blessing.

hebrew_text: וְאִי לָא יָלֵיף גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה, בְּרָכָה מְנָא לֵיהּ? וְאִי נָמֵי יָלֵיף גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה, אַשְׁכְּחַן לְאַחֲרָיו, לְפָנָיו מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: And if he does not derive a verbal analogy, from where does he derive to recite a blessing And even if he derives a verbal analogy, we found after from where beforehand?
llm_translation: If he does not derive a gezeirah shavah, how does he establish a blessing? And if indeed he does derive a gezeirah shavah, we find it both before and after him, from where?

hebrew_text: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא, דְּאָתְיָא בְּקַל וָחוֹמֶר: כְּשֶׁהוּא שָׂבֵעַ מְבָרֵךְ, כְּשֶׁהוּא רָעֵב — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן.
human_translation: not difficult, as it derived by means of an a fortiori inference: If when he is satiated, he recite a blessing when he is hungry, all the more so
llm_translation: Here is the translation of the Talmudic text you provided: Talmudic text: This is not difficult, for it can be derived a fortiori: when one is satiated, he blesses; when he is hungry — all the more so. English translation:

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן כֶּרֶם, שְׁאָר מִינִין מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: we found vineyards, from where other types of
llm_translation: I have found a vineyard, how many other species are required?

hebrew_text: דְּיָלֵיף מִכֶּרֶם: מָה כֶּרֶם דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה וְטָעוּן בְּרָכָה, אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה — טָעוּן בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: It is derived from vineyard: Just as vineyard is an item which one derives benefit and it requires a blessing, so too, any item which one derives benefit, requires a blessing.
llm_translation: He will benefit from his vineyard: What is a vineyard? Something that benefits and requires a blessing, so too, anything that benefits requires a blessing.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא לְמִפְרַךְ: מָה לְכֶרֶם שֶׁכֵּן חַיָּיב בְּעוֹלֵלוֹת!
human_translation: This can be refuted, What vineyard, that it is obligated in small, incomplete clusters of grapes [ olelot ]
llm_translation: There is a dispute: What about a vineyard, that similarly is liable for its offspring!

hebrew_text: קָמָה תּוֹכִיחַ. מָה לְקָמָה שֶׁכֵּן חַיֶּיבֶת בְּחַלָּה!
human_translation: standing grain can prove What ripe grain, that it is obligated in ḥalla
llm_translation: She shall rise and rebuke. What is the comparison to a "rise" that it is also obligated in challah!

hebrew_text: כֶּרֶם יוֹכִיחַ. וְחָזַר הַדִּין: לֹא רְאִי זֶה כִּרְאִי זֶה וְלֹא רְאִי זֶה כִּרְאִי זֶה, הַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן: דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה וְטָעוּן בְּרָכָה, אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה — טָעוּן בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: vineyards can prove And the derivation has reverted The aspect of this is not like the aspect of that, and the aspect of that is not like the aspect of this; the common denominator is: items which one derives benefit and requires a blessing. So too, any item which one derives benefit, requires a blessing.
llm_translation: A vineyard will prove. And the judgment returned: Not similar this to similar this and not similar this to similar this, the equal side in them: a matter that benefits and requires a blessing, also every matter that benefits — requires a blessing.

hebrew_text: מָה לְהַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן שֶׁכֵּן יֵשׁ בּוֹ צַד מִזְבֵּחַ. וְאָתֵי נָמֵי זַיִת דְּאִית בֵּיהּ צַד מִזְבֵּחַ.
human_translation: What the common denominator have an aspect altar, an olive may also be derived as it too has an aspect altar,
llm_translation: What is similar to the side that has an altar. And comes the verse of the olive tree that has a side of an altar.

hebrew_text: וְזַיִת מִצַּד מִזְבֵּחַ אָתֵי? וְהָא בְּהֶדְיָא כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ ״כֶּרֶם״, דִּכְתִיב ״וַיַּבְעֵר מִגָּדִישׁ וְעַד קָמָה וְעַד כֶּרֶם זָיִת״. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: ״כֶּרֶם זַיִת״ אִקְּרֵי, ״כֶּרֶם״ סְתָמָא לָא אִקְּרֵי.
human_translation: Is an olive derived from has an aspect altar? Isn’t it written explicitly with regard to listed kerem ; as it is written: “And burnt up from the shocks and the standing grain and the olive yards [ kerem zayit ]” Rav Pappa said: is called kerem zayit , it is not called kerem unmodified,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And olive from the side of the altar comes? But in it is written 'vineyard,' as it is written 'and he cleared from the thornbush and up to the standing grain and up to the vineyard of olive.' Rav Papa said: 'vineyard of olive' it is called, 'vineyard' alone is not called."

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא: מָה לְהַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן שֶׁכֵּן יֵשׁ בָּהֶן צַד מִזְבֵּחַ! אֶלָּא, דְּיָלֵיף לַהּ מִשִּׁבְעַת הַמִּינִין: מָה שִׁבְעַת הַמִּינִין דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה וְטָעוּן בְּרָכָה, אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁנֶּהֱנֶה טָעוּן בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: in any case, it is difficult: What the common denominator possess an aspect altar. Rather, it is derived from upon the seven species. Just as the seven species are items which one derives benefit and require a blessing, any item which one derives benefit, requires a blessing.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: From every place difficult: what to the side the equal in them that so there is in them side of altar! Rather, that it is preferable to it from seven species: what seven species a thing that benefits and requires blessing, so too every thing that benefits requires blessing. English translation: From every place difficult: what is the similarity between them that they both have an aspect of altar! Rather, it is preferable to it from the seven species: just as the seven species are things that benefit and require a blessing, so too every thing that benefits requires a blessing.

hebrew_text: מָה לְשִׁבְעַת הַמִּינִין שֶׁכֵּן חַיָּיבִין בְּבִכּוּרִים? וְעוֹד: הָתִינַח לְאַחֲרָיו, לְפָנָיו מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: What about the seven species? That one is obligated in of first fruits. Furthermore, this well thereafter; from where beforehand
llm_translation: What about the seven species that are obligated in first fruits? And furthermore: if one sold his field, from where does he derive the law of redemption?

hebrew_text: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא דְּאָתֵי בְּקַל וָחוֹמֶר: כְּשֶׁהוּא שָׂבֵעַ מְבָרֵךְ, כְּשֶׁהוּא רָעֵב — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן.
human_translation: not difficult, as it derived by means of an a fortiori inference: If when he is satiated, he recite a blessing when he is hungry, all the more so
llm_translation: Here is the difficulty that comes with a fortiori argument: when one is satiated, he blesses; when he is hungry — all the more so.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּתָנֵי ״נֶטַע רְבָעִי״, הָא תִּינַח כֹּל דְּבַר נְטִיעָה. דְּלָאו בַּר נְטִיעָה, כְּגוֹן בָּשָׂר בֵּיצִים וְדָגִים מְנָא לֵיהּ? אֶלָּא סְבָרָא הוּא: אָסוּר לוֹ לָאָדָם שֶׁיֵּהָנֶה מִן הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: according to the one who taught: A fourth-year sapling it well everything that can be planted, items that cannot be planted, such as meat, eggs, and fish, from where does he Rather, reason: One is forbidden to derive benefit from this world without a blessing.
llm_translation: And for the one who teaches "a quarter planting," this includes anything that is planted. For if it is not in the category of planting, such as meat, eggs, and fish, how does he count it? Rather, it is a logical deduction: It is forbidden for a person to benefit from this world without a blessing.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אָסוּר לוֹ לָאָדָם שֶׁיֵּהָנֶה מִן הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה. וְכׇל הַנֶּהֱנֶה מִן הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה מָעַל. מַאי תַּקַּנְתֵּיהּ? — יֵלֵךְ אֵצֶל חָכָם.
human_translation: The Sages taught One is forbidden to derive benefit from this world, without a blessing And anyone who derives benefit from this world without a blessing, misuse What is his remedy? He should go to a Sage.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: It is forbidden for a person to derive benefit from this world without a blessing. And anyone who derives benefit from this world without a blessing, it is as if he has misappropriated. What is the remedy for it? — Let him go to a wise person.

hebrew_text: יֵלֵךְ אֵצֶל חָכָם?! מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? הָא עֲבַד לֵיהּ אִיסּוּרָא! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: יֵלֵךְ אֵצֶל חָכָם מֵעִיקָּרָא וִילַמְּדֶנּוּ בְּרָכוֹת כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יָבֹא לִידֵי מְעִילָה.
human_translation: He should go to a Sage; what will he do to him? he has already violated a prohibition? Rather, Rava said, He should go to a Sage initially, and will teach him blessings, so that he will not come to misuse
llm_translation: He should go to a wise man?! What does he do with him? He causes him distress! Rather, Rava said: He should go to a wise man from the outset and learn from him blessings so that he does not come to transgression.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל הַנֶּהֱנֶה מִן הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה כְּאִילּוּ נֶהֱנָה מִקׇּדְשֵׁי שָׁמַיִם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לַה׳ הָאָרֶץ וּמְלוֹאָהּ״. רַבִּי לֵוִי רָמֵי: כְּתִיב ״לַה׳ הָאָרֶץ וּמְלוֹאָהּ״, וּכְתִיב ״הַשָּׁמַיִם שָׁמַיִם לַה׳ וְהָאָרֶץ נָתַן לִבְנֵי אָדָם״! לָא קַשְׁיָא כָּאן קוֹדֶם בְּרָכָה,
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: One who derives benefit from this world without a blessing, it is as if he enjoyed objects consecrated to the heavens, as it is stated: “The earth and all it contains is the Lord’s, Rabbi Levi raised a contradiction: It is written: “The earth and all it contains is the Lord’s,” and it is written “The heavens are the Lord’s and the earth He has given over to mankind” not difficult. Here, before a blessing
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: Anyone who benefits from this world without a blessing, it is as if he benefits from the sanctities of heaven, as it is stated: "The earth is the Lord's, and the fullness thereof." Rabbi Levi raises an objection: It is written, "The earth is the Lord's, and the fullness thereof," and it is also written, "The heavens are the Lord's heavens, but the earth He has given to the sons of men!" There is no difficulty here; the blessing comes first.

hebrew_text: כָּאן לְאַחַר בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: here, after a blessing
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Here for after blessing.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא: כׇּל הַנֶּהֱנֶה מִן הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה כְּאִילּוּ גּוֹזֵל לְהַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וּכְנֶסֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״גּוֹזֵל אָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ וְאוֹמֵר אֵין פָּשַׁע חָבֵר הוּא לְאִישׁ מַשְׁחִית״. וְאֵין ״אָבִיו״ אֶלָּא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הֲלֹא הוּא אָבִיךְ קָּנֶךָ״, וְאֵין ״אִמּוֹ״ אֶלָּא כְּנֶסֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שְׁמַע בְּנִי מוּסַר אָבִיךָ וְאַל תִּטּוֹשׁ תּוֹרַת אִמֶּךָ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa said: Anyone who derives benefit from this world without a blessing, it is as if he stole from God and the community of Israel, as it is stated: “Whoever robs his father and his mother and says: It is no transgression, he is the companion of a destroyer” his father, refers to none other than God, as it is stated: “Is He not your Father Who created you, his mother refers to none other than the community of Israel, as it is stated: “Hear, my son, the discipline of your father, and do not forsake the Torah of your mother”
llm_translation: Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: Anyone who benefits from this world without a blessing, it is as if he has stolen from the Holy One, blessed be He, and from the congregation of Israel, as it is stated: "He robs his father and his mother, and says, 'It is no transgression,' he is a companion to a destroyer." And "his father" refers to none other than the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is stated: "Is He not your Father who acquired you?" And "his mother" refers to the congregation of Israel, as it is stated: "Hear, my son, the instruction of your father, and do not forsake the teaching of your mother."

hebrew_text: מַאי ״חָבֵר הוּא לְאִישׁ מַשְׁחִית״? אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא: חָבֵר הוּא לְיָרׇבְעָם בֶּן נְבָט שֶׁהִשְׁחִית אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל לַאֲבִיהֶם שֶׁבַּשָּׁמַיִם.
human_translation: What He is the companion of a destroyer? Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa said: a companion of Jeroboam ben Nevat, who corrupted Israel before their Father in heaven
llm_translation: What is meant by "he is a companion to a man of destruction"? Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: He is a companion to Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin against their Father in Heaven.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא רָמֵי: כְּתִיב ״וְלָקַחְתִּי דְגָנִי בְּעִתּוֹ וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב ״וְאָסַפְתָּ דְגָנֶךָ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa raised a contradiction: It is written, “I will take back My grain at its time and it is written: “And you shall gather your grain,
llm_translation: Rabbi Chanina bar Papa raised a contradiction: It is written, "And I will take My grain in its time," and it is written, "And you shall gather in your grain."

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן בִּזְמַן שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל עוֹשִׂין רְצוֹנוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם, כָּאן בִּזְמַן שֶׁאֵין יִשְׂרָאֵל עוֹשִׂין רְצוֹנוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: not difficult. Here, a time when they perform God’s will. Here, a time when they do not perform God’s will,
llm_translation: Not difficult: here when Israel do the will of the Omnipresent, here when Israel do not do the will of the Omnipresent.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וְאָסַפְתָּ דְגָנֶךָ״ מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? — לְפִי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא יָמוּשׁ סֵפֶר הַתּוֹרָה הַזֶּה מִפִּיךָ״ — יָכוֹל דְּבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְאָסַפְתָּ דְגָנֶךָ״ — הַנְהֵג בָּהֶן מִנְהַג דֶּרֶךְ אֶרֶץ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל.
human_translation: The Sages taught: What the verse states: “And you shall gather your grain”? Because it is stated: “This Torah shall not depart from your mouths, I might that these matters are as they are written; the verse states: “And you shall gather your grain, assume in their the way of the world; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "And you shall gather in your grain" - what is the Talmud to say? - Because it is stated: "This Torah scroll shall not depart from your mouth" - one might think that words should be as they are written, the Talmud teaches: "And you shall gather in your grain" - conduct yourself with them in a manner of proper behavior, these are the words of Rabbi Yishmael.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַאי אוֹמֵר: אֶפְשָׁר אָדָם חוֹרֵשׁ בִּשְׁעַת חֲרִישָׁה, וְזוֹרֵעַ בִּשְׁעַת זְרִיעָה, וְקוֹצֵר בִּשְׁעַת קְצִירָה, וְדָשׁ בִּשְׁעַת דִּישָׁה, וְזוֹרֶה בִּשְׁעַת הָרוּחַ, תּוֹרָה מַה תְּהֵא עָלֶיהָ? אֶלָּא בִּזְמַן שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל עוֹשִׂין רְצוֹנוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם — מְלַאכְתָּן נַעֲשֵׂית עַל יְדֵי אֲחֵרִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעָמְדוּ זָרִים וְרָעוּ צֹאנְכֶם וְגוֹ׳״, וּבִזְמַן שֶׁאֵין יִשְׂרָאֵל עוֹשִׂין רְצוֹנוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם — מְלַאכְתָּן נַעֲשֵׂית עַל יְדֵי עַצְמָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָסַפְתָּ דְגָנֶךָ״. וְלֹא עוֹד אֶלָּא שֶׁמְּלֶאכֶת אֲחֵרִים נַעֲשֵׂית עַל יָדָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעָבַדְתָּ אֶת אוֹיְבֶךָ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: Is it possible that a person plows in the plowing season and sows in the sowing season and harvests in the harvest season and threshes in the threshing season and winnows in the windy season, what will become of Torah? Rather, when Israel performs God’s will, their work is performed by others, as it is stated: “And strangers will stand and feed your flocks, When Israel does not perform God’s will, their work is performed by them “And you shall gather your grain.” Moreover, others’ work will be performed by them, as it is stated: “You shall serve your enemy
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: It is possible for a person to plow at the time of plowing, and to sow at the time of sowing, and to reap at the time of harvesting, and to thresh at the time of threshing, and to winnow at the time of winnowing, what will be the Torah concerning it? Rather, when the people of Israel do the will of the Omnipresent, their work is done by others, as it is stated: "And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks." But when the people of Israel do not do the will of the Omnipresent, their work is done by themselves, as it is stated: "And you shall gather in your grain." And not only that, but the work of others is done by them, as it is stated: "And you shall serve your enemy."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הַרְבֵּה עָשׂוּ כְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, וְעָלְתָה בְּיָדָן. כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי, וְלֹא עָלְתָה בְּיָדָן.
human_translation: Abaye said: many have acted in accordance with Rabbi Yishmael, and were successful Many have acted in accordance with Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai and were not successful
llm_translation: Abaye said: Many acted like Rabbi Yishmael, and it succeeded in their hands. Like Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai, and it did not succeed in their hands.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רָבָא לְרַבָּנַן: בְּמָטוּתָא מִינַּיְיכוּ, בְּיוֹמֵי נִיסָן וּבְיוֹמֵי תִּשְׁרֵי לָא תִּתְחֲזוֹ קַמַּאי, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא תִּטַּרְדוּ בִּמְזוֹנַיְיכוּ כּוּלָּא שַׁתָּא.
human_translation: Rava said to the Sages I implore you; during Nisan and Tishrei, do not appear before me. so that you will not be preoccupied with your sustenance all year.
llm_translation: He said to them, Rava to the Rabbis: In the city of Matuta, from where are you? In the days of Nisan and in the days of Tishrei, do not go out early, so that you will not be disturbed in your sustenance, all the year.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי: בֹּא וּרְאֵה שֶׁלֹּא כְּדוֹרוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים דּוֹרוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנִים. דּוֹרוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים עָשׂוּ תּוֹרָתָן קֶבַע וּמְלַאכְתָּן עֲרַאי, זוֹ וָזוֹ נִתְקַיְּימָה בְּיָדָן. דּוֹרוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנִים שֶׁעָשׂוּ מְלַאכְתָּן קֶבַע וְתוֹרָתָן עֲרַאי, זוֹ וָזוֹ לֹא נִתְקַיְּימָה בְּיָדָן.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi El’ai: Come and see that the latter generations are not like the earlier generations; The earlier generations made their Torah permanent and their work occasional, this, and that, were successful for them. the latter generations who made their work permanent and their Torah occasional, neither this nor that was successful for them.
llm_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Yehuda son of Rabbi Ilai: Come and see that the later generations are not like the earlier generations. The earlier generations made their Torah study fixed and their work occasional, both of which were upheld in their hands. The later generations, however, made their work fixed and their Torah study occasional, neither of which were upheld in their hands.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי: בֹּא וּרְאֵה שֶׁלֹּא כְּדוֹרוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים דּוֹרוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנִים. דּוֹרוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים הָיוּ מַכְנִיסִין פֵּירוֹתֵיהֶן דֶּרֶךְ טְרַקְסְמוֹן כְּדֵי לְחַיְּיבָן בְּמַעֲשֵׂר, דּוֹרוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנִים מַכְנִיסִין פֵּירוֹתֵיהֶן דֶּרֶךְ גַּגּוֹת, דֶּרֶךְ חֲצֵרוֹת, דֶּרֶךְ קַרְפֵּיפוֹת, כְּדֵי לְפׇטְרָן מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: אֵין הַטֶּבֶל מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּמַעֲשֵׂר עַד שֶׁיִּרְאֶה פְּנֵי הַבַּיִת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בִּעַרְתִּי הַקֹּדֶשׁ מִן הַבַּיִת״.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi El’ai: Come and see that the latter generations are not like the earlier generations. earlier generations, would bring their fruits into their courtyards through the main gate in order to obligate them in tithes. the latter generations bring their fruits through roofs, through courtyards and through enclosed courtyards, in order to exempt them from tithing. As Rabbi Yannai said: Untithed produce is not obligated in tithing until it sees the front of the house as it is stated “I have removed the consecrated from the house”
llm_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Yehuda son of Rabbi Ilai: Come and see that the generations of the earlier ones are not like the generations of the later ones. The generations of the earlier ones would bring in their fruits by way of the window in order to obligate them in tithing, while the generations of the later ones bring in their fruits by way of the roofs, by way of the courtyards, by way of the lattices, in order to exempt them from tithing. For Rabbi Yannai said: The obligation of tithing does not apply to produce until it sees the face of the house, as it is stated: "I have removed the consecrated things from the house."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ חָצֵר קוֹבַעַת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָכְלוּ בִשְׁעָרֶיךָ וְשָׂבֵעוּ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even courtyard determines as it is written and they shall eat in your gates and be satisfied”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Even a courtyard establishes ownership, as it is stated: "And they shall eat in your gates and be satisfied."

hebrew_text: חוּץ מִן הַיַּיִן וְכוּ׳: מַאי שְׁנָא יַיִן? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִשְׁתַּנִּי לְעִלּוּיָא אִשְׁתַּנִּי לִבְרָכָה, וַהֲרֵי שֶׁמֶן, דְּאִשְׁתַּנִּי לְעִלּוּיָא וְלָא אִשְׁתַּנִּי לִבְרָכָה, דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שֶׁמֶן זַיִת מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״.
human_translation: with the exception of wine What is different wine, If you say that because the fruit changed for the better the blessing changed. oil changed for the better and its blessing did not change. As Rabbi Yehuda said Shmuel said, and so too Rabbi Yitzḥak said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Over olive oil, one recites: Who creates fruit of the tree,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Outside of wine, etc.: What is different about wine? Perhaps because it changes for elevation, it changes for blessing. And behold, oil, which changes for elevation but does not change for blessing, as Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel, and so said Rabbi Yitzchak in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Over olive oil, one recites "Who creates the fruit of the tree."

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: הָתָם מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר. הֵיכִי נְבָרֵיךְ? נְבָרֵיךְ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הַזַּיִת״ — פֵּירָא גּוּפֵיהּ ״זַיִת״ אִקְּרִי.
human_translation: said: There, it is because it is impossible how shall we recite the blessing? we recite the blessing: Who creates fruit of the olive, the fruit itself is called olive
llm_translation: They said: There, because it is not possible. How is it possible? It is possible with "Bo'rei pri ha'zayit" - the fruit itself is called "olive."

hebrew_text: וּנְבָרֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי עֵץ זַיִת״? אֶלָּא אָמַר מָר זוּטְרָא: חַמְרָא — זָיֵין, מִשְׁחָא — לָא זָיֵין.
human_translation: as we may recite the blessing: Who creates fruit of the olive tree, Rather, Mar Zutra offered wine nourishes, oil does not nourish.
llm_translation: And should one recite the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the tree olive"? Rather, Mar Zutra said: Wine is made from olives, oil is not made from olives.

hebrew_text: וּמִשְׁחָא לָא זָיֵין? וְהָתְנַן הַנּוֹדֵר מִן הַמָּזוֹן — מוּתָּר בַּמַּיִם וּבַמֶּלַח. וְהָוֵינַן בַּהּ: מַיִם וּמֶלַח הוּא דְּלָא אִקְּרִי ״מָזוֹן״, הָא כׇּל מִילֵּי אִקְּרִי ״מָזוֹן״.
human_translation: And oil does not nourish? Didn’t we learn One who vows that nourishment is permitted water and salt, And we discussed this water and salt are not considered nourishment, but all items are considered nourishment.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And from oil, one does not pledge? And we learned: One who vows from food — is permitted with water and with salt. And we understand from it: water and salt, for it is not called 'food,' but all things are called 'food.'"

hebrew_text: נֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, דְּאָמְרִי אֵין מְבָרְכִין ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״ אֶלָּא בַּחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִין בִּלְבַד. וְאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: בְּאוֹמֵר ״כׇּל הַזָּן עָלַי״.
human_translation: Let us say that this is a conclusive refutation of Rav and Shmuel, who said: One only recites: Who creates various kinds of nourishment, over the five species alone, And Rav Huna said where and says: Anything that nourishes to me.
llm_translation: The word of Neima should be established as the opinion of Rav and Shmuel, who said: One only recites "Blessed is the One who creates various kinds of foods" over the five species alone. And Rav Huna said: By saying "All sustenance is upon me."

hebrew_text: אַלְמָא מִשְׁחָא זָיֵין! אֶלָּא, חַמְרָא סָעֵיד, וּמִשְׁחָא לָא סָעֵיד. וְחַמְרָא מִי סָעֵיד? וְהָא רָבָא הֲוָה שָׁתֵי חַמְרָא כׇּל מַעֲלֵי יוֹמָא דְפִסְחָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּנִגְרְרֵיהּ לְלִבֵּיהּ וְנֵיכוֹל מַצָּה טְפֵי? טוּבָא — גָּרֵיר, פּוּרְתָּא — סָעֵיד.
human_translation: Apparently, oil nourishes. Rather, Wine satisfies, oil does not satisfy. And does wine satisfy? Wouldn’t Rava drink wine all the eve of Passover in order to stimulate his heart, so that he might eat more matza A lot stimulates, a little satisfies.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Alma mishcha zayin! Ela, chamra sa'ed, u'mishcha la sa'ed. Ve'chamra mi sa'ed? Ve'ha Rava havah shatei chamra kol ma'alei yoma d'Pischa, ki heichi d'nigreirei lelibei u'neichol matza tefe? Tuba - gareir, purta - sa'ed." English translation: "Why is oil superior? Rather, wine is beneficial, and oil is not beneficial. And why is wine beneficial? For Rava used to drink wine every day of Passover, so that it would drag the matzah down to his stomach and he could eat more. Good wine - drags down, poor wine - is beneficial."

hebrew_text: וּמִי סָעֵיד כְּלָל?! וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְיַיִן יְשַׂמַּח לְבַב אֱנוֹשׁ וְלֶחֶם לְבַב אֱנוֹשׁ יִסְעָד וְגוֹ׳״ — נַהֲמָא הוּא דְּסָעֵיד חַמְרָא לָא סָעֵיד! אֶלָּא, חַמְרָא אִית בֵּיהּ תַּרְתֵּי: סָעֵיד וּמְשַׂמַּח. נַהֲמָא מִסְעָד סָעֵיד, שַׂמּוֹחֵי לָא מְשַׂמַּח.
human_translation: Does satisfy at all? Isn’t it written: “Wine gladdens the heart of man, and bread fills man’s heart” bread is that which satisfies, wine does not satisfy. Rather, wine has two it satisfies and gladdens. Bread, satisfies but does not gladden.
llm_translation: "And who is Sa'ed in general?! And it is written: 'And wine gladdens the heart of man, and bread sustains the heart of man, etc.' — This is a saying: wine alone does not gladden! Rather, wine has two aspects: gladdening and sustaining. This is the saying: one who is sustained is Sa'ed, but one who gladdens does not gladden."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי נְבָרֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת! לָא קָבְעִי אִינָשֵׁי סְעוֹדְתַּיְיהוּ עִלָּוֵיהּ.
human_translation: If so, let us recite three blessings over it People do not base their meals on
llm_translation: So that they should bless upon it three blessings! People do not establish their meals upon it.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק לְרָבָא: אִי קָבַע עִלָּוֵיהּ סְעוֹדְתֵּיהּ מַאי? אָמַר לֵיהּ: לִכְשֶׁיָּבֹא אֵלִיָּהוּ וְיֹאמַר אִי הָוֵי קְבִיעוּתָא. הַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא בָּטְלָה דַּעְתּוֹ אֵצֶל כׇּל אָדָם.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: If one based his meal on it, what is the When Elijah comes and says whether it can serve as the basis Nevertheless, now, his intention is irrelevant by all other men
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak to Rava: If he established upon it his meal, what is it? He said to him: When Elijah comes and says, "It is established." Now, his mind was diverted from everyone.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שֶׁמֶן זַיִת מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּקָא שָׁתֵי לֵיהּ מִשְׁתָּא — אוֹזוֹקֵי מַזִּיק לֵיהּ. דְּתַנְיָא: הַשּׁוֹתֶה שֶׁמֶן שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה — מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַקֶּרֶן, וְאֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ. הַסָּךְ שֶׁמֶן שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה — מְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַקֶּרֶן וּמְשַׁלֵּם אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ.
human_translation: the matter itself. Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said, and so too Rabbi Yitzḥak said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One recites the blessing: Who creates fruit of the tree, over olive oil What are the circumstances? If you say that he drank it it causes damage to As it was taught One who drinks oil of teruma , pays the principal and does not pay fifth One who anoints with the oil of teruma pays the principal and pays the fifth,
llm_translation: Body. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel, and so said Rabbi Yitzchak in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: When one blesses olive oil, one recites "Who creates the fruit of the tree" over it. How so? If you say that he drinks it as is — he is liable for causing harm. As it was taught: One who drinks oil of terumah — he pays the principal but does not pay the additional fifth. One who anoints with oil of terumah — he pays the principal and he pays the additional fifth.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דְּקָא אָכֵיל לֵיהּ עַל יְדֵי פַּת. אִי הָכִי, הָוְיָא לֵיהּ פַּת עִיקָּר וְהוּא טָפֵל. וּתְנַן, זֶה הַכְּלָל: כׇּל שֶׁהוּא עִיקָּר וְעִמּוֹ טְפֵלָה — מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָעִיקָּר וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַטְּפֵלָה! אֶלָּא דְּקָא שָׁתֵי לֵיהּ עַל יְדֵי ״אֲנִיגְרוֹן״, דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: ״אֲנִיגְרוֹן״ — מַיָּא דְסִלְקָא, ״אַנְסִיגְרוֹן״ — מַיָּא
human_translation: Rather, he eats by bread If so, bread is primary and secondary, and we learned This is the principle: Any that is primary, and with secondary, one recites a blessing over the primary exempts the secondary Rather, where he is drinking it by means of an anigeron , as Rabba bar Shmuel said: Anigeron water beet ansigeron the water
llm_translation: Rather, he is eating it with bread. If so, bread should be the main thing and it is secondary. And we learned: this is the principle: anything that is primary with something secondary — one blesses over the primary and exempts the secondary! Rather, he is drinking it with "anigron," as Rabba bar Shmuel said: "Anigron" is water that has been drawn, "ansigron" is water.

hebrew_text: דְּכוּלְּהוּ שִׁלְקֵי.
human_translation: all boiled
llm_translation: They all agree.

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, הָוֵה לֵיהּ אֲנִיגְרוֹן עִיקָּר וְשֶׁמֶן טָפֵל, וּתְנַן, זֶה הַכְּלָל: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא עִיקָּר וְעִמּוֹ טְפֵלָה, מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָעִיקָּר וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַטְּפֵלָה!
human_translation: if so, anigeron is primary and oil is secondary, and we learned This is the principle: Any that is primary, and with secondary, one recites a blessing over the primary exempts the secondary
llm_translation: If so, let there be to him Anigron as the main and oil as secondary, and we learned: this is the principle: anything that is primary with a secondary, one blesses on the primary and exempts the secondary!

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּחוֹשֵׁשׁ בִּגְרוֹנוֹ. דְּתַנְיָא: הַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בִּגְרוֹנוֹ לֹא יְעָרְעֶנּוּ בְּשֶׁמֶן תְּחִלָּה בְּשַׁבָּת, אֲבָל נוֹתֵן שֶׁמֶן הַרְבֵּה לְתוֹךְ אֲנִיגְרוֹן וּבוֹלֵעַ.
human_translation: With what are we dealing here? one who has a sore throat, As it was taught One who has a sore throat should not, ab initio , gargle oil on Shabbat However, he may, add a large amount of oil to the anigeron and swallow it.
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? - Concerned about his throat. As it was taught: One who is concerned about his throat should not gargle with oil initially on Shabbat, but he may pour a lot of oil into a cup and swallow.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְתֵימָא: כֵּיוָן דְּלִרְפוּאָה קָא מְכַוֵּין לָא לְבָרֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ כְּלָל, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כֵּיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ הֲנָאָה מִינֵּיהּ, בָּעֵי בָּרוֹכֵי.
human_translation: This is obvious Lest you say: Since he intends for medicinal let him not recite a blessing over it at all, it teaches us since he derived pleasure from it, he must recite a blessing
llm_translation: It is obvious! What might you say: since it is not for healing that one is preparing it, one should not recite a blessing over it at all, we learn that since it provides some benefit, it requires a blessing.

hebrew_text: קִמְחָא דְחִיטֵּי, רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְרַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: wheat flour, Rav Yehuda said Who creates fruit of the ground, and Rav Naḥman said By Whose word all things came to be.
llm_translation: Flour of wheat, Rav Yehudah said: "Who creates the fruit of the ground," and Rav Nachman said: "That everything comes into being by His word."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא לְרַב נַחְמָן: לָא תִּפְלוֹג עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה, דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וּשְׁמוּאֵל קָיְימִי כְּווֹתֵיהּ. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שֶׁמֶן זַיִת מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״. אַלְמָא: אַף עַל גַּב דְּאִשְׁתַּנִּי — בְּמִלְּתֵיהּ קָאֵי. הָא נָמֵי, אַף עַל גַּב דְּאִשְׁתַּנִּי — בְּמִלְּתֵיהּ קָאֵי.
human_translation: Rava said to Rav Naḥman: Do not disagree with Rav Yehuda, as Rabbi Yoḥanan and Shmuel hold in accordance with his As Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said, and so too Rabbi Yitzḥak said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One recites the blessing: Who creates fruit of the tree, over olive oil. Consequently, even though has changed the formula remains as it was. This too, even though has changed remains as it was:
llm_translation: Rava said to Rav Nachman: Do not argue with regard to the ruling of Rav Yehudah, for Rabbi Yochanan and Shmuel agree with him. For Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel, and similarly Rabbi Yitzchak said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Over olive oil, one recites the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the tree." This implies that even though it has changed, it stands on its original essence. The same applies here, even though it has changed, it stands on its original essence.

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם — לֵית לֵיהּ עִלּוּיָא אַחֲרִינָא, הָכָא — אִית לֵיהּ עִלּוּיָא אַחֲרִינָא בְּפַת.
human_translation: Is it comparable? There, has no additional enhancement, here, has additional enhancement as bread.
llm_translation: Who is similar? There — it does not have another elevation, here — it has another elevation in bread.

hebrew_text: וְכִי אִית לֵיהּ עִלּוּיָא אַחֲרִינָא לָא מְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״ אֶלָּא ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״? וְהָא אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַב מַתְנָא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אַקָּרָא חַיָּיא וְקִמְחָא דִשְׂעָרֵי מְבָרְכִינַן עֲלַיְיהוּ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיָה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. מַאי לָאו דְּחִיטֵּי בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה!
human_translation: When it has additional enhancement, one does not recite: Who creates fruit of the ground; rather all things Didn’t Rabbi Zeira say Rav Mattana said Shmuel said: Over a raw gourd and over barley flour, one recites the blessing: By Whose word all things came to be. What, is that not to say that over wheat Who creates fruit of the ground?
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And if there is another type of food, we do not bless over it 'Who creates the fruit of the earth,' but 'Who created everything'? But didn't Rabbi Zeira say in the name of Rav Mattana who said in the name of Shmuel: For bread and cooked dishes, we bless over them 'by Whose word everything came to be.' Why not bless over wheat 'Who creates the fruit of the earth'?"

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּחִיטֵּי נָמֵי ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיָה בִּדְבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: No, also By Whose word all things came to be, wheat
llm_translation: Not is it for, wheat, people, "that everything happens by His word."

hebrew_text: וְלַשְׁמְעִינַן דְּחִיטֵּי וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן דִּשְׂעָרֵי!
human_translation: Then let teach us with regard to wheat and all the more so regarding barley
llm_translation: And to hear the wheat, and all the more so the barley!

hebrew_text: אִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן דְּחִיטֵּי הֲוָה אָמֵינָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי דְּחִיטֵּי, אֲבָל דִּשְׂעָרֵי לָא לְבָרֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ כְּלָל, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Had taught us wheat, I would have said: This applies wheat but barley let one not recite a blessing at all. it teaches us
llm_translation: If we were to hear that wheat was said, I would say that these are the words of wheat, but barley is not included in it at all, this implies to us.

hebrew_text: וּמִי גָּרַע מִמֶּלַח וְזָמִית, דִּתְנַן עַל הַמֶּלַח וְעַל הַזָּמִית אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. אִצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא מֶלַח וְזָמִית עָבֵיד אִינָשׁ דְּשָׁדֵי לְפוּמֵּיהּ, אֲבָל קִמְחָא דִשְׂעָרֵי הוֹאִיל וְקָשֶׁה לְקוּקְיָאנֵי, לָא לְבָרֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ כְּלָל, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כֵּיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ הֲנָאָה מִינֵּיהּ בָּעֵי בָּרוֹכֵי.
human_translation: Is it inferior to salt and salt water [ zamit ]? As we learned over salt and salt water one recites: By Whose word all things came to be, it was necessary it might enter your mind to say: one places salt or salt water into his mouth, barley flour, which and causes intestinal worms, let one recite no blessing over it at all. it teaches us, since one derives pleasure from it, he must recite a blessing.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who subtracted from salt and pitch, as we learned in the Mishnah: regarding salt and pitch one says, "that everything is accomplished by His word." It was necessary, for had you not said, I would have thought that salt and pitch, which a person can throw before him, but hair powder, since it is hard for the lice, one should not bless upon it at all. It is taught to us that since it provides benefit to him, one should bless upon it.

hebrew_text: קוֹרָא, רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: heart of palm [ kura ], Rav Yehuda said Who creates fruit of the ground. Shmuel, said By Whose word all things came to be.
llm_translation: Reader, Rav Yehudah said: "Who creates the fruit of the earth," and Shmuel said: "That everything comes into being through His word."

hebrew_text: רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, פֵּירָא הוּא. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיָה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, הוֹאִיל וְסוֹפוֹ לְהַקְשׁוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said: Who creates fruit of the ground; it is a fruit. And Shmuel said: By Whose word all things came to be, since it will ultimately harden
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said, "Borei peri ha'adamah," peira hu. And Shmuel said, "Shehakol nihyah bidvaro," ho'il ve'sofo le'hakshot.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל לְרַב יְהוּדָה: שִׁינָּנָא, כְּווֹתָךְ מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּהָא צְנוֹן סוֹפוֹ לְהַקְשׁוֹת וּמְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. וְלָא הִיא: צְנוֹן נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְפוּגְלָא, דִּקְלָא לָא נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְקוֹרָא.
human_translation: Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: Shinnana . It is reasonable in accordance with your a radish ultimately hardens recites over it: Who creates fruit of the ground. That is not so; people plant a radish with the soft in mind. people do not plant palm trees with the heart of palm in mind
llm_translation: Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: "A radish, as it is formed, for its end is to harden, and we bless over it 'Who creates the fruit of the earth.' But it is not so: a radish, when planted by people of discernment, for it is not planted by people of discernment, it hardens."

hebrew_text: וְכׇל הֵיכָא דְּלָא נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי לָא מְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ? וַהֲרֵי צָלָף, דְּנָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְפִרְחָא, וּתְנַן: עַל מִינֵי נִצְפָּה, עַל הֶעָלִין וְעַל הַתְּמָרוֹת אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְעַל הָאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְעַל הַקַּפְרֵיסִין אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״.
human_translation: And whenever people do not plant with that in mind, one does not recite a blessing over it? caper-bush that people plant with their fruit in mind, and we learned that with regard to the parts of the caper-bush [ nitzpa ], over the leaves and young fronds, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground, and over the berries and buds he recites: Who creates fruit of the tree.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And in every place where people do not plant, why do we not recite a blessing over it? But behold the willow, where people do plant, and we learned: concerning different species of foliage, regarding the leaves and the dates, one says "Who creates the fruit of the earth," and regarding gourds and cucumbers, one says "Who creates the fruit of the tree."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: צָלָף נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְשׁוּתָא, דִּקְלָא לָא נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְקוֹרָא. וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּקַלְּסֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל לְרַב יְהוּדָה, הִלְכְתָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said Caper-bushes, people plant with leaves in mind; palm trees, people do not plant with heart of palm in mind. Although Shmuel praised Rav Yehuda, the halakha is in accordance with Shmuel.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman son of Yitzchak said: If a palm tree is planted, people have knowledge of dates, but if a date palm is not planted, people do not have knowledge of dates. And even though Shmuel contradicted Rav Yehuda, the halakha follows the opinion of Shmuel.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: צָלָף שֶׁל עׇרְלָה בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ זוֹרֵק אֶת הָאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְאוֹכֵל אֶת הַקַּפְרֵיסִין. לְמֵימְרָא דַּאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת פֵּירֵי וְקַפְרֵיסִין לָאו פֵּירֵי? וּרְמִינְהוּ: עַל מִינֵי נִצְפָּה, עַל הֶעָלִים וְעַל הַתְּמָרוֹת אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְעַל הָאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְעַל הַקַּפְרֵיסִין אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״!
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Rav said: A caper-bush during the first three years of its growth [ orla ] outside of Eretz one throws out the berries, but eats the buds. Is that to say that the berries are fruit and the bud is not fruit? The Gemara raises a contradiction With regard to the parts of the caper-bush [ nitzpa ], over the leaves and young fronds, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground, and over the berries, and buds he recites: Who creates fruit of the tree.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: One who scatters foreskin peelings in a public domain may feed the pigeons and eat the capers. Is it to be inferred that pigeons are considered produce, and capers are not produce? But raise an objection: In regard to various species of produce, concerning leaves and dates one recites "Who creates the fruit of the ground," and concerning pigeons and capers one recites "Who creates the fruit of the tree"!

hebrew_text: הוּא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: צָלָף מִתְעַשֵּׂר תְּמָרוֹת וַאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְקַפְרֵיסִין. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: אֵין מִתְעַשֵּׂר אֶלָּא אֲבִיּוֹנוֹת בִּלְבַד, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא פֶּרִי.
human_translation: statement is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, as we learned Rabbi Eliezer says: A caper-bush is tithed from its young fronds, berries and buds, And Rabbi Akiva says: Only the berries alone are tithed, because it is fruit.
llm_translation: He who said like Rabbi Akiva, as we learned: Rabbi Eliezer says: One tithes from palm branches, willows, and caper bushes. Rabbi Akiva says: One only tithes from caper bushes alone, because it is a fruit.

hebrew_text: וְנֵימָא: ״הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא״! אִי אָמַר הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא אֲפִילּוּ בָּאָרֶץ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: כׇּל הַמֵּיקֵל בָּאָרֶץ — הֲלָכָה כְּמוֹתוֹ בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ, אֲבָל בָּאָרֶץ — לָא.
human_translation: He should have said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, Had said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, I would have said even in Eretz he teaches us Anyone who is lenient in Eretz the halakha is in accordance with his outside of Eretz but not in Eretz
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was stated: "The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva!" If one were to say the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, I would have said even in the land, it is heard for us: Whoever is lenient in the land — the halakha is like him outside the land, but in the land — not.

hebrew_text: וְנֵימָא: ״הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ״, דְּכׇל הַמֵּיקֵל בָּאָרֶץ — הֲלָכָה כְּמוֹתוֹ בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ. אִי אָמַר הָכִי, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי גַּבֵּי מַעְשַׂר אִילָן, דְּבָאָרֶץ גּוּפָא מִדְּרַבָּנַן, אֲבָל גַּבֵּי עׇרְלָה, דְּבָאָרֶץ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, אֵימָא בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ נָמֵי נִגְזוֹר, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: let say: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva outside of Eretz as anyone who is lenient in Eretz the halakha is in accordance with his outside of Eretz Had he said that, I would have said: That only applies with regard to the tithing of trees, in Eretz itself is an obligation by rabbinic law; but with regard to orla , is in Eretz by Torah law, say that we should issue a decree even outside of Eretz he teaches us
llm_translation: And it was stated: "The halakha is like Rabbi Akiva in the outskirts of the land," for anyone who is lenient in the land — the halakha is like him in the outskirts of the land. If he said so, I would have said these matters regarding tithing of trees, which in the land itself is according to the Rabbis, but regarding the prohibition of uncircumcised fruit, which in the land is from the Torah, one might say that in the outskirts of the land it is also decreed. This is what he teaches us.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְמָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי דְּקָא זָרֵיק אֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְקָאָכֵיל קַפְרֵיסִין. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי דַעְתָּךְ, כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּמֵיקֵל? וְלֶעֱבֵיד מָר כְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי דִּמְקִילִּי טְפֵי! דִּתְנַן: צָלָף, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: כִּלְאַיִם בַּכֶּרֶם. וּבֵית הַלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֵין כִּלְאַיִם בַּכֶּרֶם. אֵלּוּ וְאֵלּוּ מוֹדִים שֶׁחַיָּיב בְּעׇרְלָה.
human_translation: Ravina found Mar bar Rav Ashi throwing away the berries and eating the buds said to What is your opinion, in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who is lenient, then you should act in accordance with Beit Shammai, who are even more lenient. As we learned Beit Shammai say: A caper-bush is a diverse kind in the vineyard, Beit Hillel say: not a diverse kind in a vineyard. these and those, agree obligated in orla .
llm_translation: Ravinah found Mar bar Rav Ashi who was throwing grape pits and eating capers. He said to him: What is your opinion, like Rabbi Akiva who is lenient? And do the Master's will like Beit Shammai who are lenient in matters of tithing! As we learned: "If a locust falls into a vineyard, Beit Shammai says: It renders the vineyard forbidden. Beit Hillel says: It does not render the vineyard forbidden." Both agree that one is liable for orlah.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא: אָמְרַתְּ צָלָף בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים כִּלְאַיִם בַּכֶּרֶם, אַלְמָא מִין יָרָק הוּא, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: אֵלּוּ וְאֵלּוּ מוֹדִים שֶׁחַיָּיב בְּעׇרְלָה, אַלְמָא מִין אִילָן הוּא!
human_translation: This itself is problematic: You said that Beit Shammai say: A caper-bush is a diverse kind in a vineyard; apparently, it is a type of vegetable and then you taught: These and those, agree obligated in orla ; apparently, it is a type of tree.
llm_translation: The matter is difficult: Tzalaf of Beit Shammai says "Kil'ayim in the vineyard." This implies it is a type of vegetable. And then it teaches: "Both these and those agree that it is subject to the laws of 'orlah." This implies it is a type of tree!

hebrew_text: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי סַפּוֹקֵי מְסַפְּקָא לְהוּ, וְעָבְדִי הָכָא לְחוּמְרָא וְהָכָא לְחוּמְרָא. מִכׇּל מָקוֹם, לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי הָוֵה לֵיהּ סָפֵק עׇרְלָה, וּתְנַן: סָפֵק עׇרְלָה — בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל אָסוּר, וּבְסוּרְיָא מוּתָּר. וּבְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ יוֹרֵד
human_translation: not difficult; Beit Shammai are uncertain and here, they act stringently and here, they act stringently. In any case, according to Beit Shammai uncertain orla , we learned Uncertain orla in Eretz Yisrael is forbidden to eat, and in Syria it is permitted, Outside of Eretz may go down
llm_translation: Here is the word-for-word English translation of the Talmudic text: "The matter is not difficult: Beit Shammai are doubtful, they are doubtful to them, and they did here stringency here stringency. In any case, Beit Shammai had a doubt of foreskin, and we learned: Doubt of foreskin — in the land of Israel is forbidden, and in Syria is permitted. And outside the land one may descend."

hebrew_text: וְלוֹקֵחַ — וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יִרְאֶנּוּ לוֹקֵט.
human_translation: and take as long as does not see him gather
llm_translation: And one who gathers - and only if he does not intend to gather.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בִּמְקוֹם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר עָבְדִינַן כְּוָתֵיהּ, וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי בִּמְקוֹם בֵּית הִלֵּל — אֵינָהּ מִשְׁנָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva in place of Rabbi Eliezer, we act in accordance with his And Beit Shammai where Beit Hillel not mishna,
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva in the place of Rabbi Eliezer we follow his view, and Beit Shammai in the place of Beit Hillel - it is not a Mishnah.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּנַעֲשָׂה שׁוֹמֵר לַפְּרִי, וְרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״וַעֲרַלְתֶּם עׇרְלָתוֹ אֶת פִּרְיוֹ״, אֶת הַטָּפֵל לְפִרְיוֹ, וּמַאי נִיהוּ — שׁוֹמֵר לַפְּרִי.
human_translation: Let us derive serves as protection for the fruit, and the Torah says: you shall regard its fruit [ et piryo ] as orla ” et piryo that which is secondary to the fruit. What is that? That which is protection for the fruit.
llm_translation: And it should be derived that one who becomes a guardian for the fruit, and the Merciful One said: "And you shall uncircumcise the foreskin of his fruit," regarding the one who is secondary to his fruit, and what is the case? - a guardian for the fruit.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הֵיכָא אָמְרִינַן דְּנַעֲשָׂה שׁוֹמֵר לַפְּרִי — הֵיכָא דְּאִיתֵיהּ בֵּין בְּתָלוּשׁ בֵּין בִּמְחוּבָּר, הָכָא בִּמְחוּבָּר — אִיתֵיהּ, בְּתָלוּשׁ — לֵיתֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rava said: Where do we say becomes protection for the fruit? when it exists both when is detached and when it is connected here, it exists when is connected but when it is detached it does not,
llm_translation: Rava said: Where do we say that if a watchman was appointed for the fruit - where he was present whether suspended or attached, here if it was attached - he is present, if suspended - he is not present.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: פִּיטְמָא שֶׁל רִמּוֹן מִצְטָרֶפֶת, וְהַנֵּץ שֶׁלּוֹ אֵין מִצְטָרֵף. מִדְּקָאָמַר הַנֵּץ שֶׁלּוֹ אֵין מִצְטָרֵף, אַלְמָא דְּלָאו אוֹכֶל הוּא. וּתְנַן גַּבֵּי עׇרְלָה: קְלִיפֵּי רִמּוֹן וְהַנֵּץ שֶׁלּוֹ, קְלִיפֵּי אֱגוֹזִים וְהַגַּרְעִינִין חַיָּיבִין בְּעׇרְלָה.
human_translation: Abaye raised a challenge The crown of a pomegranate joins And its flower, does not join From that it says the pomegranate’s flower does not join, consequently is not food. And we learned The rinds of a pomegranate and its flower, nutshells, and pits are obligated in orla .
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him: Abaye raised an objection: The peel of a pomegranate combines, but its seed does not combine. From the fact that it says its seed does not combine, it implies that it is not edible. And we learned in the Mishnah regarding orlah: The peels of a pomegranate and its seed, the peels of walnuts and their kernels are subject to the laws of orlah.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: הֵיכָא אָמְרִינַן דְּנַעֲשָׂה לְהוּ שׁוֹמֵר לְפֵירֵי — הֵיכָא דְּאִיתֵיהּ בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר פֵּירָא, הַאי קַפְרֵס לֵיתֵיהּ בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר פֵּירָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said Where do we say becomes protection for the fruit? Where it exists when the fruit is ripe. This bud does not exist when the fruit is ripe,
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: Where do we say that if a watchman was appointed for produce - where he was present at the time of the completion of the produce, this basket of produce is not present at the time of the completion of the produce.

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ: הָנֵי מְתַחֲלֵי דְעׇרְלָה אֲסִירִי, הוֹאִיל וְנַעֲשׂוּ שׁוֹמֵר לְפֵירֵי. וְשׁוֹמֵר לְפֵירֵי אִימַּת הָוֵי — בְּכוּפְרָא, וְקָא קָרֵי לֵיהּ ״שׁוֹמֵר לְפֵירֵי״.
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say Rabba bar Avuh said: Those orla date coverings are prohibited, because they became protection for the fruit. And when do protection for the fruit? When the fruit is still young; and he, calls them protection for the fruit.
llm_translation: I?! And didn't Rav Nachman say in the name of Rabba bar Avuh: Those who are newly circumcised are forbidden, since they have become "guardians of the figs." And when is one considered a "guardian of the figs"? In Capernaum, and it is called "guardian of the figs."

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, דִּתְנַן רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: סְמָדַר אָסוּר מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא פֶּרִי. וּפְלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman held Rabbi Yosei, as we learned Rabbi Yosei says: The grape-bud, is prohibited because it is a fruit. The Rabbis disagree with him,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman holds like Rabbi Yosei, as we learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Yosei says: S'madar is prohibited because it is a fruit. And the Rabbis disagree with him.

hebrew_text: מַתְקִיף לַהּ רַב שִׁימִי מִנְּהַרְדְּעָא: וּבִשְׁאָר אִילָנֵי מִי פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ? וְהָתְנַן: מֵאֵימָתַי אֵין קוֹצְצִין אֶת הָאִילָנוֹת בַּשְּׁבִיעִית — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: כׇּל הָאִילָנוֹת מִשֶּׁיּוֹצִיאוּ, וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: הֶחָרוּבִין מִשֶּׁיְּשַׁרְשְׁרוּ, וְהַגְּפָנִים מִשֶּׁיְּגָרְעוּ, וְהַזֵּיתִים מִשֶּׁיָּנֵיצוּ, וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הָאִילָנוֹת מִשֶּׁיּוֹצִיאוּ.
human_translation: Rav Shimi of Neharde’a strongly objects to this Do the Rabbis disagree with with regard to of all other trees Didn’t we learn From when may one no cut trees during the Sabbatical year Beit Shammai say: All trees, from when fruit emerge And Beit Hillel say: Carob trees from when they chains vines misheyegaru , olives from when they blossom, and all other trees from when emerges.
llm_translation: Rav Shimi from Nehardea objects to her: And in the case of other trees, what do the Rabbis disagree about it? And we learned in a Mishnah: From when do we not prune trees in the Sabbatical year? Beit Shammai says: All trees from when they sprout, and Beit Hillel says: Carob trees from when they take root, and vines from when they shed their leaves, and olive trees from when they blossom, and all other trees from when they sprout.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב אַסִּי: הוּא בּוֹסֶר, הוּא גֵּרוּעַ, הוּא פּוֹל הַלָּבָן. פּוֹל הַלָּבָן סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ?! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: שִׁיעוּרוֹ כְּפוֹל הַלָּבָן. מַאן שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ דְּאָמַר בּוֹסֶר אִין, סְמָדַר לָא — רַבָּנַן, וְקָתָנֵי שְׁאָר כׇּל הָאִילָנוֹת — מִשֶּׁיּוֹצִיאוּ?
human_translation: And Rav Asi said: It is an unripe grape, it is a grape kernel, it is a white bean. Does it enter your mind a white bean? Rather, say: Its size, of a white bean. whom did you hear that said: An unripe grape, yes, a grape-bud, no, the Rabbis and it is taught all other trees from when emerges.
llm_translation: And Rav Assi said: He is a boser, he is gerua, he is pol halavan. Pol halavan, is it your opinion?! Rather say: his measurement is like pol halavan. Who heard him say boser is not, smadar is not - Rabbanan, and it teaches other trees - from when they produce?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: הֵיכָא אָמְרִינַן דְּהָוֵי שׁוֹמֵר לְפֵרֵי — הֵיכָא דְּכִי שָׁקְלַתְּ לֵיהּ לְשׁוֹמֵר מָיֵית פֵּירָא. הָכָא כִּי שָׁקְלַתְּ לֵיהּ — לָא מָיֵית פֵּירָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said Where do we say becomes protection for the fruit? Where if you remove the protection, the fruit dies. Here, when you remove the fruit does not die.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: Where do we say that one is considered a guardian for produce? In a case where you handed it over to a guardian of produce. Here, when you handed it over to him, it did not become produce.

hebrew_text: הֲוָה עוֹבָדָא וְשַׁקְלוּהּ לְנֵץ דְּרִמּוֹנָא, וִיבַשׁ רִמּוֹנָא, וְשַׁקְלוּהּ לְפִרְחָא דְבִיטִיתָא — וְאִיקַּיַּים בִּיטִיתָא.
human_translation: there was an incident and they removed the flower of a pomegranate, and the pomegranate withered. And they removed the flower of the fruit of a caper-bush and the fruit of the caper-bush survived.
llm_translation: The matter was that they took a pomegranate bud, and the pomegranate bud dried up, and they took a beet sprout - and the beet sprout established itself.

hebrew_text: (וְהִלְכְתָא כְּמָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי דְּזָרֵיק אֶת הָאֲבִיּוֹנוֹת וְאָכֵיל אֶת הַקַּפְרֵיסִין. וּמִדִּלְגַבֵּי עׇרְלָה לָאו פֵּירָא נִינְהוּ, לְגַבֵּי בְּרָכוֹת נָמֵי לָאו פֵּירָא נִינְהוּ, וְלָא מְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״, אֶלָּא ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.)
human_translation: The halakha is in accordance with Mar bar Rav Ashi, who discarded the berries and ate the buds. And since they are not fruit with regard to orla , they are also not fruit with regard to blessings, and one does not recite over them: Who creates fruit of the tree, but rather: Who creates fruit of the ground.
llm_translation: The halakha is like Mar bar Rav Ashi who throws away the pits and eats the capers. And regarding foreskins, they are not considered a barrier, but regarding blessings, they are not considered a barrier, and we do not recite the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the tree" over it, but rather "Who creates the fruit of the ground."

hebrew_text: פִּלְפְּלֵי, רַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״, רָבָא אָמַר: לָא כְלוּם. וְאָזְדָא רָבָא לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: כַּס פִּלְפְּלֵי בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי — פָּטוּר, כַּס זַנְגְּבִילָא בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי — פָּטוּר.
human_translation: peppers. Rav Sheshet said: By Whose word all things came to be. Rava said: One not recite at all. This is consistent with Rava’s opinion as Rava said: One who chews on peppers on Yom Kippur is exempt, one who chews on ginger on Yom Kippur is exempt.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Pilpelai, Rav Sheshet amar: "Shehakol", Rava amar: La'kelum. Ve'azda Rava le'ta'ameih, de'amar Rava: Kas pilpelai be'yoma de'kippurei - patur, kas zangvilai be'yoma de'kippurei - patur. English translation: Pilpelai, Rav Sheshet said: "That everything", Rava said: Not at all. And Rava followed his reasoning, for Rava said: A measure of peppercorns on Yom Kippur eve - exempt, a measure of ginger on Yom Kippur eve - exempt.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי, הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִמַּשְׁמַע שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וַעֲרַלְתֶּם עׇרְלָתוֹ אֶת פִּרְיוֹ״ אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁעֵץ מַאֲכָל הוּא? אֶלָּא מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״עֵץ מַאֲכָל״ — לְהָבִיא עֵץ שֶׁטַּעַם עֵצוֹ וּפִרְיוֹ שָׁוֶה, וְאֵיזֶהוּ? — זֶה הַפִּלְפְּלִין. לְלַמֶּדְךָ שֶׁהַפִּלְפְּלִין חַיָּיבִין בְּעׇרְלָה, וּלְלַמֶּדְךָ שֶׁאֵין אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל חֲסֵרָה כְּלוּם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֶרֶץ אֲשֶׁר לֹא בְמִסְכֵּנֻת תֹּאכַל בָּהּ לֶחֶם לֹא תֶחְסַר כֹּל בָּהּ״.
human_translation: The Gemara raised an objection Rabbi Meir would say: By inference from that which is stated: “You shall regard its fruit as orla ,” don’t I know that it is a tree food? Rather, what does the verse state: “Any tree for food”? To include a tree whose wood and fruit have the same taste. And which is this? This is the pepper And to teach you that the peppers, obligated in orla , and to teach that Eretz Yisrael lacks nothing, as it is stated: “A land where you shall eat bread without scarceness, you shall lack nothing” Obviously,
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: Rabbi Meir used to say, "From the language itself, as it is stated, 'And you shall uncircumcise the foreskin of its fruit,' I do not know that it refers to a fruit-bearing tree? Rather, what is the teaching when it says 'fruit-bearing tree' - to bring a tree whose taste and fruit are similar, and which is that? - this is the pepper tree. To teach you that pepper trees are subject to the laws of orlah, and to teach you that the land of Israel lacks nothing, as it is stated: 'A land in which you will eat bread without scarcity, you will lack nothing in it.'"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּרַטִּיבְתָּא, הָא בְּיַבִּשְׁתָּא.
human_translation: not difficult, This, is when it is damp and this, is when it is dry.
llm_translation: Not difficult: this in wetness, this in dryness.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לְמָרִימָר: כַּס זַנְגְּבִילָא בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי פָּטוּר? וְהָא אָמַר רָבָא: הַאי הִמְלְתָא דְּאָתְיָא מִבֵּי הִנְדּוּאֵי — שַׁרְיָא, וּמְבָרְכִינַן עֲלַהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּרַטִּיבְתָּא, הָא בְּיַבִּשְׁתָּא.
human_translation: the Sages said to Mareimar: is one who chews ginger on Yom Kippur exempt? Didn’t Rava say: One is permitted the ginger that comes from India, and over it, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. not difficult. This, is when it is damp this, is when it is dry.
llm_translation: The sages said to Marimar: "A cup of zangvilah on Yom Kippur exempts?" But Rava said: "This dish that comes from the markets of Hinduvai is permitted, and we bless over it 'Who creates the fruit of the earth.' It is not difficult: this is in a moist state, that is in a dry state."

hebrew_text: חֲבִיץ קְדֵרָה וְכֵן דַּיְיסָא, רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר: ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. בְּדַיְיסָא גְּרֵידָא כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּ״בוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. כִּי פְּלִיגִי בְּדַיְיסָא כְּעֵין חֲבִיץ קְדֵרָה, רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״, סָבַר דּוּבְשָׁא עִיקָּר. רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, סָבַר סְמִידָא עִיקָּר. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: כְּוָתֵיהּ דְּרַב כָּהֲנָא מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: ḥavitz , pot as well as pounded grain. Rav Yehuda said By Whose word all things came to be. Rav Kahana said Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. With regard to pounded grain alone, everyone agrees that one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. When they argue, it is with regard to pounded grain in the manner of a ḥavitz pot. Rav Yehuda said all things held that the honey is primary, Rav Kahana said Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, he held that the flour, is primary, Rav Yosef said: It is reasonable in accordance with Rav Kahana, as Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that has of the five species in it, one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment,
llm_translation: A pot of a stove and similarly a bowl, Rav Yehudah said: "Everything is dependent on its substance." Rav Kahana said: "Creator of various kinds of sustenance." In the case of a bowl, the entire world does not dispute that it is "Creator of various kinds of sustenance." When they dispute in the case of a bowl like a pot of a stove, Rav Yehudah said "everything," he holds that the primary substance is honey. Rav Kahana said "Creator of various kinds of sustenance," he holds that the secondary substance is the primary one. Rav Yosef said: The reasoning of Rav Kahana is more logical, for Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that contains from the five species, one blesses over it "Creator of various kinds of sustenance."

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. וְאִיתְּמַר נָמֵי, רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת.
human_translation: the matter itself. Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that has of the five species in it, one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. it was stated Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that is from the five species one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.
llm_translation: Body: Rav and Shmuel who say both: all that has in it from five species bless on it "Who creates various kinds of foods." And it was stated: truly, Rav and Shmuel who say both: all that is from five species bless on it "Who creates various kinds of foods."

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן ״כֹּל שֶׁהוּא״ הֲוָה אָמֵינָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיתֵיהּ בְּעֵינֵיהּ, אֲבָל עַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבוֹת — לָא.
human_translation: necessary, had he taught us Anything that is I would have said because is in its pure, but in a mixture, no,
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if we were to hear "anything that is," I would say it is because it exists in his eyes, but through mixtures - no.
