hebrew_text: קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן — ״כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ״. וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן ״כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ״ הָוֵה אָמֵינָא כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ חֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִים — אִין, אֲבָל אוֹרֶז וְדוֹחַן — לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּעַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבֶת. אֲבָל אִיתֵיהּ בְּעֵינֵיהּ — נֵימָא אֲפִילּוּ אוֹרֶז וְדוֹחַן נָמֵי מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן — כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִים הוּא דִּמְבָרְכִין עָלָיו בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת, לְאַפּוֹקֵי אוֹרֶז וְדוֹחַן, דַּאֲפִילּוּ אִיתֵיהּ בְּעֵינֵיהּ לָא מְבָרְכִינַן ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: he teaches us: Anything that has in it, And had he taught us Anything that has in it, I would have said anything that has in it, yes, However, rice and millet no, because it in a mixture. However, is in its pure, say even over rice and millet one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, he teaches us Anything that is from the five species one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, to the exclusion of rice and millet, which, even in its pure, one does not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.
llm_translation: We hear - "anything that has in it." And if we would hear "anything that has in it," I would say anything that has in it the five species - no, but rice and millet - yes, because they are subject to mixture. But if it is by itself - it is said, even rice and millet, we still bless "Who creates various kinds of foods" over it. We hear - anything that is from the five species, we bless "Who creates various kinds of foods" over it, to exclude rice and millet, for even if it is by itself, we do not bless "Who creates various kinds of foods" over it.

hebrew_text: וְאוֹרֶז וְדוֹחַן לָא מְבָרְכִינַן ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״? וְהָתַנְיָא: הֵבִיאוּ לְפָנָיו פַּת אוֹרֶז וּפַת דּוֹחַן — מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו תְּחִלָּה וָסוֹף כְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה. וְגַבֵּי מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה תַּנְיָא: בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: And rice and millet we do not recite: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment? But wasn’t it taught If they brought before him rice bread or millet bread, he recites the blessing over it before and after, as a cooked dish And with regard to a cooked dish, it was taught At the start, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end, one recites one blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And rice and millet, do we not recite 'Blessed is the One who creates various kinds of foods' over them? And it was taught: If one brings before him a loaf of rice and a loaf of millet - he recites a blessing over them at the beginning and at the end, like the practice of a pot. And regarding the practice of a pot, it was taught: At the beginning, one recites 'Blessed is the One who creates various kinds of foods' over it, and at the end, one recites over it a single blessing resembling three." English translation:

hebrew_text: כְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה וְלָא כְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה: כְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה דִּמְבָרְכִין עָלָיו תְּחִלָּה וָסוֹף, וְלָא כְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה דְּאִילּוּ בְּמַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה — בַּתְּחִלָּה ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״ וּלְבַסּוֹף בְּרָכָה מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ, וְאִילּוּ הָכָא — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, וּלְבַסּוֹף ״בּוֹרֵא נְפָשׁוֹת רַבּוֹת וְחֶסְרוֹנָן עַל כָּל מַה שֶּׁבָּרָאתָ״.
human_translation: like a cooked dish, and is not like a cooked dish like a cooked dish one recites a blessing over it beginning and end. And it is unlike a cooked dish over a cooked dish, at the start, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end, one blessing abridged from three whereas here, over at the start, one recites: By Whose word all things came to be, and at the end, Who creates the many forms of life and their needs for all that You have created.
llm_translation: As the case of a pot, and not as the case of a pot: Like the case of a pot where one blesses over it both at the beginning and at the end, and not like the case of a pot where even in the case of a pot — at the beginning "Who creates various kinds of sustenance" and at the end a blessing resembling three, but here — at the beginning one blesses over it "by Whose word everything came to be," and at the end "Who creates many souls and their deficiencies for all that You have created."

hebrew_text: וְאוֹרֶז לָאו מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה הוּא? וְהָתַנְיָא, אֵלּוּ הֵן מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה: חִילְקָא, טַרְגִּיס, סוֹלֶת, זָרִיז, וְעַרְסָן, וְאוֹרֶז.
human_translation: And rice is not a cooked dish? Wasn’t it taught these are cooked dishes: Wheat kernels split into two parts, wheat kernels crushed into three parts [ teraggis ], flour, wheat kernels crushed into four parts [ zariz ], wheat kernels crushed into five parts [ arsan ] and rice?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Is rice not considered a type of pot dish? And it was taught: These are the types of pot dishes: Chilka, Targis, Solet, Zariz, Arsan, and Orez.

hebrew_text: הָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי אוֹמֵר: אוֹרֶז מִין דָּגָן הוּא, וְחַיָּיבִין עַל חִמּוּצוֹ כָּרֵת, וְאָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח. אֲבָל רַבָּנַן לָא.
human_translation: Whose this It is Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri’s as it was taught Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: Rice is a type of grain one is liable to karet if it leavens And a person fulfills his obligation on Passover; however, the Rabbis, no,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises a contradiction: Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri is the one who said it, as it was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri says: Rice is a type of grain, and one is liable for its leavening with karet, and a person fulfills his obligation with it on Passover. But the Rabbis disagree.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן לָא?! וְהָתַנְיָא: הַכּוֹסֵס אֶת הַחִטָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. טְחָנָהּ אֲפָאָהּ וּבִשְּׁלָהּ, בִּזְמַן שֶׁהַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת. אִם אֵין הַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: And the Rabbis not Wasn’t it taught One who chews wheat recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. he ground baked it, and cooked When the slices are intact at the start one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth, and at the end one recites three blessings When the slices are not intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: The sages disagree?! But it was taught: One who harvests wheat, recites over it "Blessed is the Creator of the fruit of the ground." He grinds it, sifts it, and kneads it, when the pieces are still intact — initially, one recites over it "Who brings forth bread from the earth," and ultimately recites over it three blessings. If the pieces are not intact — initially, one recites over it "Who creates various kinds of sustenance," and ultimately recites over it one blessing resembling three.

hebrew_text: הַכּוֹסֵס אֶת הָאוֹרֶז מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. טְחָנוֹ אֲפָאוֹ וּבִשְּׁלוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת, בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: One who chews rice recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. If one ground it, baked it, and then cooked it, even though the pieces are intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: The one who harvests the rice, blesses over it "Borei Pri Ha'adama." He grinds it, bakes it, and cooks it, even though the grains are still intact. Initially, one blesses over it "Borei Minei Mezonot," and ultimately blesses over it with one blessing resembling three.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי, אִילֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי הִיא דְּאָמַר אוֹרֶז מִין דָּגָן הוּא, ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״ וְשָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת בָּעֵי בָּרוֹכֵי!
human_translation: Whose this If you say that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri who said rice is a type of grain, Who brings forth bread from the earth, and three blessings
llm_translation: The text reads: "Mani, I would say it is Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri who said: rice is a type of grain, 'Who brings forth bread from the earth,' and requires three blessings for those who eat it!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו, רַבָּנַן הִיא, וּתְיוּבְתָּא דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל!
human_translation: Rather, isn’t it the Rabbis, conclusive refutation of Rav and Shmuel.
llm_translation: Rather, it is a matter for the Rabbis, and the resolution is that of Rav and Shmuel!

hebrew_text: תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: is a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: The text "תְּיוּבְתָּא" translates to "Tevuta" in English.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: הַכּוֹסֵס אֶת הַחִטָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. וְהָתַנְיָא ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי זְרָעִים״! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וְהָא רַבָּנַן. דִּתְנַן: וְעַל יְרָקוֹת אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי דְשָׁאִים״.
human_translation: the Master said: One who chews wheat recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Wasn’t it taught Who creates various kinds of seeds? not difficult, This Rabbi Yehuda, and this Rabbis. As we learned Over vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Rabbi Yehuda says: Who creates various kinds of herbs.
llm_translation: The Master said: One who covers the wheat, blesses over it "Borei Pri Ha'adama." And it was taught: "Borei Minei Zeraim"! It is not difficult: here is Rabbi Yehuda, and here are the Rabbis. As we learned: And on vegetables one says "Borei Pri Ha'adama," Rabbi Yehuda says: "Borei Minei Desha'im."

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר, הַכּוֹסֵס אֶת הָאוֹרֶז מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. טְחָנוֹ אֲפָאוֹ וּבִשְּׁלוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת, בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: the Master said: One who chews rice recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. If one ground it, baked it and then cooked it, even though the pieces are intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: The Master said, one who threshes the rice, he blesses over it "Who creates the fruit of the ground." He grinds it, bakes it, even though the grains are still intact, initially he blesses over it "Who creates various kinds of sustenance," and ultimately one blessing resembling three.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא לְבַסּוֹף וְלָא כְלוּם! אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, וְהָא רַבָּנַן. דְּתַנְיָא, זֶה הַכְּלָל: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מִשִּׁבְעַת הַמִּינִים, רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: Wasn’t it taught at the end not any Rav Sheshet said: not difficult, This, Rabban Gamliel. This, Rabbis. As it was taught this is the principle: Anything that is from the seven species Rabban Gamliel says: three blessings And the Rabbis say: One blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "And it was taught at the end, and not like nothing! Rav Sheshet said: It is not difficult: here is Rabban Gamliel, and here are the Rabbis. As it was taught: this is the principle: anyone who is from the seven species, Rabban Gamliel says three blessings, and the sages say one blessing similar to three."

hebrew_text: וּמַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל וְהַזְּקֵנִים שֶׁהָיוּ מְסוּבִּין בַּעֲלִיָּיה בִּירִיחוֹ, וְהֵבִיאוּ לִפְנֵיהֶם כּוֹתָבוֹת וְאָכְלוּ, וְנָתַן רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל רְשׁוּת לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לְבָרֵךְ. קָפַץ וּבֵרַךְ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: עֲקִיבָא, עַד מָתַי אַתָּה מַכְנִיס רֹאשְׁךָ בֵּין הַמַּחֲלוֹקֶת! אָמַר לוֹ: רַבֵּינוּ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאַתָּה אוֹמֵר כֵּן וַחֲבֵרֶיךָ אוֹמְרִים כֵּן, לִמַּדְתָּנוּ רַבֵּינוּ יָחִיד וְרַבִּים הֲלָכָה כָּרַבִּים.
human_translation: And incident involving Rabban Gamliel and the Sages who were sitting in an upper floor in Jericho and they brought dates before them and they ate. And Rabban Gamliel gave Rabbi Akiva permission to recite the blessing. Rabbi Akiva hurried and recited one blessing abridged from three Rabban Gamliel said: Akiva, until when will you stick your head into the dispute said to him: Our teacher, even though you say this while your colleagues say that, you taught us, our teacher, an individual and the many, the halakha is in accordance with the many.
llm_translation: And the incident with Rabban Gamliel and the elders who were reclining in the upper chamber in Jericho, and they brought before them writings and they ate, and Rabban Gamliel gave permission to Rabbi Akiva to bless. He jumped up and Rabbi Akiva blessed with a blessing similar to three. Rabban Gamliel said to him: Akiva, until when will you bring your head between the disputants! He said to him: Our master, even though you say so and your colleagues say so, you have taught us, our master, that the law follows the majority.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשְּׁמוֹ: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מִשִּׁבְעַת הַמִּינִים
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says in his name, anything that is from the seven species
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says in his name: "Anyone who is from the seven species."

hebrew_text: וְלֹא מִין דָּגָן הוּא, אוֹ מִין דָּגָן וְלֹא עֲשָׂאוֹ פַּת — רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים בְּרָכָה אַחַת. כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ לֹא מִשִּׁבְעַת הַמִּינִין וְלֹא מִין דָּגָן, כְּגוֹן פַּת אוֹרֶז וְדוֹחַן — רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים וְלֹא כְלוּם.
human_translation: and is not a species of grain, or which is a species of grain and has not been made into bread, Rabban Gamliel says three blessings and the Rabbis say a single blessing. And anything that is neither one of the seven species nor a species of grain, such as rice bread or millet bread, Rabban Gamliel says one blessing abridged from three and the Rabbis say not any
llm_translation: "And not of the species of grain it is, or of the species of grain and not its product bread — Rabban Gamliel says three blessings, and the Sages say one blessing. Anything that is neither of the seven species nor of the species of grain, such as rice or millet — Rabban Gamliel says one blessing resembling three, and the Sages say it is nothing."

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקִימְתָּא — כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל? אֵימָא סֵיפָא דְּרֵישָׁא, אִם אֵין הַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלֶיהָ בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ. מַנִּי: אִי רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, הַשְׁתָּא אַכּוֹתָבוֹת וְאַדַּיְיסָא אָמַר רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת, אִם אֵין הַפְּרוּסוֹת קַיָּימוֹת מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: How did you establish In accordance with Rabban Gamliel. Say the latter clause of the first when the slices are not intact, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from three Whose If Rabban Gamliel, now dates and pounded wheat, Rabban Gamliel said three blessings where the slices are not intact, is it necessary
llm_translation: With what food do you establish the meal blessing - like Rabban Gamliel? Say the end of the beginning, if the pieces are not intact - at first one blesses over it "Who creates various kinds of foods," and in the end one blesses over it one blessing resembling three. Who is the authority? If Rabban Gamliel, now it is written and it is sufficient that Rabban Gamliel said three blessings, if the pieces are not intact, what is the need for the question?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא רַבָּנַן. אִי הָכִי קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבָּנַן אַדְּרַבָּנַן! אֶלָּא לְעוֹלָם רַבָּנַן, וּתְנִי גַּבֵּי אוֹרֶז: ״וּלְבַסּוֹף אֵינוֹ מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו וְלֹא כְּלוּם״.
human_translation: Rather, it is clear the Rabbis. If so, there is a contradiction between the Rabbis and the Rabbis. Rather, actually, the Rabbis and and teach with regard to rice: At the end, one does not recite any blessing,
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious, sages. If so, it is a difficulty of sages to sages! Rather, indeed sages, and it was taught regarding cedar wood: "And ultimately one does not recite a blessing over it, nor is it considered a disgrace."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הַאי רִיהֲטָא דְּחַקְלָאֵי דְּמַפְּשִׁי בֵּיהּ קִמְחָא, מְבָרֵךְ ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. מַאי טַעְמָא? — דִּסְמִידָא עִיקָּר. דְּמָחוֹזָא, דְּלָא מַפְּשִׁי בֵּיהּ קִמְחָא, מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיָה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. מַאי טַעְמָא? — דּוּבְשָׁא עִיקָּר. וַהֲדַר אָמַר רָבָא: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי, ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִים מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: Rava said: the farmer’s mixture of flour and honey to which they add flour, one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. What is the reason? the flour is primary Meḥoza they do not add flour, one recites: By Whose word all things came to be. What is the reason? the honey is primary And Rava reconsidered and said: both this, that, Who creates the various kinds of nourishment. As Rav and Shmuel both said: Anything that is from the five species one recites over it: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.
llm_translation: Rava said: This kneaded dough of the Babylonians, in which flour is mixed, one blesses "Who creates various kinds of sustenance." What is the reason? — Because it is the primary ingredient. In the region of Mehoza, where flour is not mixed in, one blesses over it "by whose word all things exist." What is the reason? — Because it is the primary ingredient. And Rava further said: In both cases, one blesses "Who creates various kinds of sustenance." For Rav and Shmuel both said: In anything that contains one of the five species of grain, one blesses "Who creates various kinds of sustenance."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: הַאי חֲבִיצָא דְּאִית בֵּיהּ פֵּרוּרִין כְּזַיִת — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת. דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ פֵּרוּרִין כְּזַיִת — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״, וּלְבַסּוֹף בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: this cooked dish, which contains pieces an olive-bulk, at the start one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth, and afterward one recites three blessings which does not contain pieces an olive-bulk, at the start one recites: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment, and at the end one recites one blessing abridged from three
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: This type of dish that contains whole olives - at the beginning one recites "Who brings forth bread from the earth" over it, and at the end one recites three blessings over it. If it does not contain whole olives - at the beginning one recites "Who creates various kinds of foods" over it, and at the end one blessing that is like three.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ — דְּתַנְיָא: הָיָה עוֹמֵד וּמַקְרִיב מְנָחוֹת בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם — אוֹמֵר: ״בָּרוּךְ שֶׁהֶחֱיָינוּ וְקִיַּמְנוּ וְהִגִּיעָנוּ לַזְּמַן הַזֶּה״. נְטָלָן לְאׇכְלָן — מְבָרֵךְ ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. וְתָנֵי עֲלַהּ: וְכוּלָּן, פּוֹתְתָן כְּזַיִת.
human_translation: And Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this As it was taught would stand and offer meal-offerings in Jerusalem, he would recite: Who has given us life, sustained us, and brought us to this time, When he would take to eat them, he would recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth. And it was taught on the And all of the he crumbles olive-bulk.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this to her? — As it was taught: If one was standing and offering meal offerings in Jerusalem, he says: "Blessed is He who has kept us alive, sustained us, and brought us to this time." He takes them to eat them — he recites "Who brings forth bread from the earth." And it was taught about it: And all of them, he breaks them like an olive.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, לְתַנָּא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל דְּאָמַר פּוֹרְכָן עַד שֶׁמַּחְזִירָן לְסׇלְתָּן, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּלָא בָּעֵי בָּרוֹכֵי ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״?! וְכִי תֵּימָא הָכִי נָמֵי, וְהָתַנְיָא: לָקַט מִכּוּלָּן כְּזַיִת וַאֲכָלָן, אִם חָמֵץ הוּא — עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, וְאִם מַצָּה הוּא — אָדָם יוֹצֵא בּוֹ יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח.
human_translation: Abaye said to But so, then now, according to the tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael said He crushes them until he restores them to they were flour, so too, he need not recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth? And if you say that is so, wasn’t it taught One who gathered an olive-bulk from all of and ate them, if it was leavened bread punishable by karet . If of unleavened bread, one fulfills his obligation on Passover.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: Rather from now on, according to the Tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael who said, "One blesses the bread until they return it to its flour," is it not so that the blessers do not require "Who brings forth bread from the earth"?! And if you will say that it is so, but it was taught: "If one gathered grains all like an olive and ate them, if it is leavened — the punishment is excision, and if it is unleavened — a person fulfills his obligation with it on Passover."

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּשֶׁעֵרְסָן. אִי הָכִי אֵימָא סֵיפָא, וְהוּא שֶׁאֲכָלָן בִּכְדֵי אֲכִילַת פְּרָס — וְאִי בְּשֶׁעֵרְסָן, הַאי ״שֶׁאֲכָלָן״, ״שֶׁאֲכָלוֹ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: with what are we dealing here? where and compacted them If so, say the latter clause, this case when he ate them, in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf of bread. And if one compacted them that When he ate them, When he ate it, is what it needed
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? - with their gate. If so, say the latter part, and that he ate them in the amount of a Peras' worth - and if with their gate, does the term "he ate them" require "he ate it"?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּבָא מִלֶּחֶם גָּדוֹל.
human_translation: Rather, With what are we dealing here? where came from a large bread
llm_translation: Rather, here we are dealing with what? With the case of "Bava Metzia."

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵה עֲלַהּ? אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: הַאי חֲבִיצָא, אַף עַל גַּב דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ פֵּרוּרִין כְּזַיִת — מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. אָמַר רָבָא: וְהוּא דְּאִיכָּא עֲלֵיהּ תּוֹרִיתָא דְנַהְמָא.
human_translation: What was about Rav Sheshet said: this cooked dish, which contains crumbs, even though it does not contain crumbs of an olive-bulk, one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth. Rava said: This is have the appearance of bread
llm_translation: What is the ruling regarding it? Rav Sheshet said: This egg, even though it does not contain any crumbs the size of an olive, one recites over it "Who brings forth bread from the earth." Rava said: And this is because there is a supporting verse for it in the Torah of Nahama.

hebrew_text: טְרוֹקְנִין, חַיָּיבִין בַּחַלָּה. וְכִי אֲתָא רָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: טְרוֹקְנִין פְּטוּרִין מִן הַחַלָּה. מַאי טְרוֹקְנִין? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כּוּבָּא דְאַרְעָא.
human_translation: terokanin , they are obligated in ḥalla , And, when Ravin came he said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Terokanin are exempt from ḥalla . What are terokanin ? Abaye said: cavity in the ground
llm_translation: Tractate: Tractate Challa Talmudic text: "Trok'nin, chayavin bachalla. Ve'chi ata Ravin amar Rabbi Yochanan: Trok'nin peturin min hachalla. Mai trok'nin? Amar Abbaye: Kuba d'ar'a." English translation: "Trok'nin, obligated in Challa. And when Ravin came, Rabbi Yochanan said: Trok'nin are exempt from Challa. What are Trok'nin? Abbaye said: A pit in the ground."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר אַבָּיֵי: טְרִיתָא פְּטוּרָה מִן הַחַלָּה. מַאי טְרִיתָא? אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי גְּבִיל מְרַתַּח, וְאִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי נַהֲמָא דְהִנְדְּקָא, וְאִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי לֶחֶם הֶעָשׂוּי לְכוּתָּח.
human_translation: And Abaye said: Terita is exempt from ḥalla . What terita ? Some say, kneaded boiling And some say, bread from India, And some say, bread made for kutaḥ ,
llm_translation: And Abaye said: A mixture is exempt from challah. What is a mixture? Some say it is thick porridge, and some say it is sifted flour, and some say it is bread made for dogs.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא: לֶחֶם הֶעָשׂוּי לְכוּתָּח פָּטוּר מִן הַחַלָּה. וְהָא תַּנְיָא חַיָּיב בַּחַלָּה! הָתָם כִּדְקָתָנֵי טַעְמָא — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מַעֲשֶׂיהָ מוֹכִיחִין עָלֶיהָ. עֲשָׂאָן
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: Bread made for kutaḥ ; is exempt from ḥalla . Wasn’t it taught is obligated in ḥalla There, as the reason was taught Rabbi Yehuda says: the actions its prove it If he made them
llm_translation: It was taught by Rabbi Chiya: Bread made for kuttach is exempt from challah. But isn't it taught that it is obligated in challah! There, as it was taught the reason — Rabbi Yehuda says: Its actions testify about it.

hebrew_text: כְּעָבִין — חַיָּיבִין, כְּלִמּוּדִין — פְּטוּרִים. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי לְרַב יוֹסֵף: הַאי כּוּבָּא דְאַרְעָא מַאי מְבָרְכִין עִלָּוֵיהּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי סָבְרַתְּ נַהֲמָא הוּא?! גּוּבְלָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא וּמְבָרְכִין עִלָּוֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: thick [ ke’avin ], they are obligated like boards [ kelimmudin ], they are exempt, Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What blessing is recited over the dough of the ground? said to him: Do you think that it is bread? It is merely kneaded and one recites over it the blessing: Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.
llm_translation: Like fruits - obligated, like learned ones - exempt. Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What blessing do we recite over this kuba of the land? He said to him: Do you think it is a mere heap of earth?! It is a border of the world, and we recite over it "Who creates various kinds of sustenance."

hebrew_text: מָר זוּטְרָא קְבַע סְעוֹדְתֵּיהּ עִלָּוֵיהּ, וּבָרֵךְ עִלָּוֵיהּ ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״, וְשָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת.
human_translation: Mar Zutra based his meal on this he recited: Who brings forth bread from the earth, three blessings
llm_translation: Mar Zutra established his meal on it, and he recited over it "Who brings forth bread from the earth," and three blessings.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי: וְאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח, מַאי טַעְמָא — ״לֶחֶם עוֹנִי״ קָרֵינַן בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi said: a person fulfills his obligation on Passover. What is the reason? we call it bread of affliction,
llm_translation: Master Bar Rav Ashi said: And a person fulfills his obligation with them on Passover, what is the reason - "bread of affliction" we read in it.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי: הַאי דּוּבְשָׁא דְתַמְרֵי מְבָרְכִין עִלָּוֵיהּ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. מַאי טַעְמָא? — זֵיעָה בְּעָלְמָא הוּא.
human_translation: And Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Over this date honey one recites: By Whose word all things came to be. What is the reason merely moisture
llm_translation: And said Mar son of Rav Ashi: This honey of dates, they bless upon it "that everything was created by His word." What is the reason? — It is a flowing world.

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן? — כִּי הַאי תַּנָּא דִּתְנַן דְּבַשׁ תְּמָרִים, וְיֵין תַּפּוּחִים, וְחוֹמֶץ סִפְוָנִיּוֹת, וּשְׁאָר מֵי פֵירוֹת שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מְחַיֵּיב קֶרֶן וָחוֹמֶשׁ, וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ פּוֹטֵר.
human_translation: In accordance with whose In accordance with this tanna , as we learned date honey, apple wine or vinegar made from grapes of autumn or other juice from fruits of teruma , Rabbi Eliezer obligates the principal and fifth And Rabbi Yehoshua exempts
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "K'man? — Ki hai tana ditanan d'vash temarim, v'yayin tapuchim, v'chometz sifvaniyot, u'shear mei peirot shel terumah — Rabbi Eliezer mechayev keren vachomesh, v'Rabbi Yehoshua poter." English translation: "As whom? — For this Mishnah that we learned: honey of dates, and wine of apples, and vinegar of sycamore figs, and the remainder of fruit juices of terumah — Rabbi Eliezer obligates principal and fifth, and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ הָהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן לְרָבָא: טְרִימָא מַהוּ? לָא הֲוָה אַדַּעְתֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא מַאי קָאָמַר לֵיהּ. יְתֵיב רָבִינָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: דְּשׁוּמְשְׁמֵי קָא אָמְרַתְּ, אוֹ דְּקוּרְטְמֵי קָא אָמְרַתְּ, אוֹ דְּפוּרְצָנֵי קָא אָמְרַתְּ?
human_translation: One of the Sages said to Rava: What is terima ? Rava did not understand what he was saying to him. Ravina sat before Rava said to you speaking of sesame or you speaking of safflower or you speaking of grape-pits
llm_translation: He said to him that certain Sage to Rava: "What is Trima?" I did not know what Rava was saying to him. Ravina was sitting before Rava, he said to him: "Are you saying 'sesame seeds,' or are you saying 'cucumbers,' or are you saying 'pumpkins'?"

hebrew_text: אַדְּהָכִי וְהָכִי אַסְּקֵיהּ רָבָא לְדַעְתֵּיהּ, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חֲשִׁילְתָּא וַדַּאי קָא אָמְרַתְּ, וְאַדְכַּרְתַּן מִלְּתָא הָא דְּאָמַר רַב אַסִּי: הַאי תַּמְרֵי שֶׁל תְּרוּמָה מוּתָּר לַעֲשׂוֹת מֵהֶן טְרִימָא, וְאָסוּר לַעֲשׂוֹת מֵהֶן שֵׁכָר. וְהִלְכְתָא תַּמְרֵי וְעַבְדִינְהוּ טְרִימָא — מְבָרְכִין עִלָּוַיְיהוּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״. מַאי טַעְמָא? — בְּמִלְּתַיְיהוּ קָיְימִי כִּדְמֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: Meanwhile, Rava comprehended and said to Certainly, you are speaking of pressed and you reminded me of a matter that Rav Asi said: Those dates of teruma ; one is permitted to make terima , and one is forbidden to make beer over dates made into terima , one recites: Who creates fruit of the tree. What is the reason? they remain in their original state.
llm_translation: So thus and thus Rava asked him according to his opinion, he said to him: You have certainly thought well, and remember the matter that Rav Assi said: These dates of Terumah are permitted to make Trima from them, and it is forbidden to make beer from them. And the halacha is that the dates and their pits are Trima - one recites the blessing "Borei Pri Ha'etz" over them. What is the reason? - Because they maintain their original form.

hebrew_text: שְׁתִיתָא, רַב אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: roasted barley to which honey or vinegar was added [ shetita ]. Rav said By Whose word all things came to be; and Shmuel said Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Shetita, Rav said 'Shehakol Nihyeh Bidvaro,' and Shmuel said 'Borei Minei Mezonot.'" English translation: "The first cup, Rav said 'Who brings about everything through His word,' and Shmuel said 'Who creates various types of sustenance.'"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא, וְלָא פְּלִיגִי: הָא בְּעָבָה, הָא בְּרַכָּה. עָבָה לַאֲכִילָה עָבְדִי לַהּ, רַכָּה לִרְפוּאָה קָא עָבְדִי לַהּ.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: And they do not disagree, This, is in thick, this, is in thin. thick, he made it as food; thin, he made it as medicine,
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said, and they do not disagree: this one in thickness, this one in thinness. Thick for eating they made it, thin for healing they made it.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב יוֹסֵף: וְשָׁוִין שֶׁבּוֹחֲשִׁין אֶת הַשַּׁתּוּת בְּשַׁבָּת וְשׁוֹתִין זֵיתוֹם הַמִּצְרִי. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ לִרְפוּאָה קָא מְכַוֵּין, רְפוּאָה בְּשַׁבָּת מִי שְׁרֵי?!
human_translation: Rav Yosef raised a challenge And they agree that one may mix shetita on Shabbat and drink Egyptian beer [ zitom haMitzri ], And if it enters your mind his intention is for medicinal is medicine permitted on Shabbat?
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Yosef asked: And is it equal that they inspect the wound on Shabbat and then drink Egyptian zitom? And if it enters your mind that they are preparing for healing, is healing permitted on Shabbat?!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְאַתְּ לָא תִּסְבְּרָא? וְהָא תְּנַן: כׇּל הָאוֹכָלִין אוֹכֵל אָדָם לִרְפוּאָה בְּשַׁבָּת, וְכׇל הַמַּשְׁקִין שׁוֹתֶה. אֶלָּא מָה אִית לָךְ לְמֵימַר — גַּבְרָא לַאֲכִילָה קָא מְכַוֵּין, הָכִי נָמֵי גַּבְרָא לַאֲכִילָה קָא מְכַוֵּין.
human_translation: Abaye said to Do you not hold Didn’t we learn All foods a person may eat for medicinal on Shabbat, and all drinks drink But what can you say The man’s intention is eating; too, the man’s intention is eating.
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: And you do not agree? But we learned: All foods a person may eat for healing on Shabbat, and all drinks he may drink. Rather, what do you have to say? A man is designated for eating, so too a man is designated for eating.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא: אֶלָּא מָה אִית לָךְ לְמֵימַר — גַּבְרָא לַאֲכִילָה קָא מְכַוֵּין, וּרְפוּאָה מִמֵּילָא קָא הָוְיָא? הָכִי נָמֵי לַאֲכִילָה קָא מְכַוֵּין, וּרְפוּאָה מִמֵּילָא קָא הָוְיָא.
human_translation: another version But what can you say The man’s intention is for eating and the cure comes about on its own; too, the man’s intention is for eating and the cure comes about on its own.
llm_translation: Another interpretation: Rather, what do you have to say? A man is preparing for eating, and healing comes automatically? So too, he is preparing for eating, and healing comes automatically.

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל. דְּאִי מֵהַאי, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא לַאֲכִילָה קָא מְכַוֵּין וּרְפוּאָה מִמֵּילָא קָא הָוְיָא, אֲבָל הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דִּלְכַתְּחִילָּה לִרְפוּאָה קָא מְכַוֵּין — לָא לְבָרֵיךְ עִלָּוֵיהּ כְּלָל. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כֵּיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ הֲנָאָה מִינֵּיהּ בָּעֵי בָּרוֹכֵי.
human_translation: And of Rav and Shmuel is necessary, as if from this I would have said: one’s intention is for eating and the cure comes about on its own. Here, however, since from the outset, his intention is for medicine; let him recite no blessing over at all. taught us since he derives pleasure from it, is required to recite a blessing.
llm_translation: The matter of Rav and Shmuel. For if from this, I would have said that for eating they are preparing, and for healing from the word they are, but here, since initially for healing they are preparing - not for a blessing at all. It is evident to us since he has benefit from it, he requires a blessing.

hebrew_text: שֶׁעַל הַפַּת הוּא אוֹמֵר ״הַמּוֹצִיא״ וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מָה הוּא אוֹמֵר? — ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. רַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. אָמַר רָבָא: בְּ״מוֹצִיא״ כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאַפֵּיק מַשְׁמַע, דִּכְתִיב: ״אֵל מוֹצִיאָם מִמִּצְרָיִם״. כִּי פְּלִיגִי בְּ״הַמּוֹצִיא״, רַבָּנַן סָבְרִי הַמּוֹצִיא דְּאַפֵּיק מַשְׁמַע, דִּכְתִיב: ״הַמּוֹצִיא לְךָ מַיִם מִצּוּר הַחַלָּמִישׁ״. וְרַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה סָבַר הַמּוֹצִיא דְּמַפֵּיק מַשְׁמַע, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הַמּוֹצִיא אֶתְכֶם מִתַּחַת סִבְלוֹת מִצְרָיִם״.
human_translation: that over bread one recites: Who brings forth bread from the earth. The Sages taught What does recite Who brings forth [ hamotzi ] bread from the earth. Rabbi Neḥemya says Who brought forth [ motzi ] bread from the earth. Rava said: Everyone agrees that motzi means brought, as it is written: “God who brought them forth [ motziam ] from Egypt When do they disagree? With regard to hamotzi , as the Rabbis hold hamotzi means brought forth, as it is written: “Who brought forth [ hamotzi ] for you water from a rock of flint” Rabbi Neḥemya holds hamotzi means brings forth as it is stated who is bringing you forth [ hamotzi ] from under the burdens of Egypt”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: On the bread he says "Who brings forth" etc. The Rabbis taught: What does he say? — "Who brings forth bread from the earth." Rabbi Nechemiah says: "Brings forth bread from the earth." Rava said: With "brings forth," everyone agrees that it implies taking out, as it is written: "God who brought them out of Egypt." When they argue about "Who brings forth," the Rabbis hold that "brings forth" implies taking out, as it is written: "Who brings forth water for you from the rock of flint." And Rabbi Nechemiah holds that "brings forth" implies producing, as it is said: "Who brought you out from under the burdens of Egypt."

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן? — הָהוּא הָכִי קָאָמַר לְהוּ קוּדְשָׁא בְּרִיךְ הוּא לְיִשְׂרָאֵל: כַּד מַפֵּיקְנָא לְכוּ, עָבֵידְנָא לְכוּ מִלְּתָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּיָדְעִיתוּ דַּאֲנָא הוּא דְּאַפֵּיקִית יָתְכוֹן מִמִּצְרַיִם, דִּכְתִיב: ״וִידַעְתֶּם כִּי אֲנִי ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיכֶם הַמּוֹצִיא״.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, that the Holy one, Blessed be He, said to Israel as follows: When I bring you forth, I will perform something for you that you will know that I am the one who brought you forth from Egypt, as it is written: “And you will know that I am the Lord your God who brought you forth [ hamotzi ]”;
llm_translation: The sages? — That one thus said to them: The Holy One, blessed be He, is for Israel: As we were departing, we made known to you a matter, so that you would know that it was I who brought you out of Egypt, as it is written: "And you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out."

hebrew_text: מִשְׁתַּבְּחִין לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לְרַבִּי זֵירָא [אֶת] בַּר רַב זְבִיד אֲחוּהּ דְּרַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר רַב זְבִיד דְּאָדָם גָּדוֹל הוּא וּבָקִי בִּבְרָכוֹת הוּא. אָמַר לָהֶם: לִכְשֶׁיָּבֹא לְיֶדְכֶם הֲבִיאוּהוּ לְיָדִי. זִמְנָא חֲדָא אִיקְּלַע לְגַבֵּיהּ אַפִּיקוּ לֵיהּ רִיפְתָּא, פָּתַח וְאָמַר ״מוֹצִיא״. אָמַר: זֶה הוּא שֶׁאוֹמְרִים עָלָיו דְּאָדָם גָּדוֹל הוּא וּבָקִי בִּבְרָכוֹת הוּא?! בִּשְׁלָמָא אִי אֲמַר ״הַמּוֹצִיא״
human_translation: The Sages would praise son of Rav Zevid, brother of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Zevid to Rabbi Zeira, that he is a great man and he is expert in blessings. said to When he comes to you, bring him to me One day he happened before him. They brought out bread he began and recited: Who brought forth [ motzi ] bread from the earth. and said: This is he of whom they say that he is a great man and expert in blessings? Granted, had he recited: Hamotzi,
llm_translation: The sages praised Rabbi Zeira for his brother, Rav Zebid, the son of Rav Zebid, who was a great and knowledgeable man in blessings. He said to them: "When he comes to you, bring him to me." One time he encountered him, they brought him a loaf of bread, he opened it and said, "Who brings forth." He said: "Is this the man they say is great and knowledgeable in blessings?!" If he had said "Who brings forth"

hebrew_text: אַשְׁמְעִינַן טַעְמָא, וְאַשְׁמְעִינַן דְּהִלְכְתָא כְּרַבָּנַן. אֶלָּא דַּאֲמַר ״מוֹצִיא״ מַאי קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן? וְאִיהוּ דַּעֲבַד לְאַפּוֹקֵי נַפְשֵׁיהּ מִפְּלוּגְתָּא.
human_translation: he taught us the meaning and he taught us that the halakha is in accordance with the Rabbis. However, what did he teach us by reciting motzi ? did this to preclude himself from the dispute.
llm_translation: We hear the reason, and we hear that the halakha is like the Rabbis. Rather, when it says "one who brings out," what does it imply to us? It is he who makes himself liable to pay from his own portion.

hebrew_text: וְהִלְכְתָא ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״, דְּקַיְימָא לַן כְּרַבָּנַן, דְּאָמְרִי דְּאַפֵּיק מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: And the halakha Who brings forth [ hamotzi ] bread from the earth, as we hold in accordance with the Rabbis who say
llm_translation: The law of "one who takes out bread from the land," is in accordance with the Rabbis, who say that one fulfills his obligation by hearing.

hebrew_text: וְעַל הַיְּרָקוֹת אוֹמֵר וְכוּ׳. קָתָנֵי יְרָקוֹת דּוּמְיָא דְפַת — מָה פַּת שֶׁנִּשְׁתַּנָּה עַל יְדֵי הָאוּר, אַף יְרָקוֹת נָמֵי שֶׁנִּשְׁתַּנּוּ עַל יְדֵי הָאוּר. אָמַר רַבְנַאי מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּאַבָּיֵי: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. מִמַּאי? — מִדְּקָתָנֵי יְרָקוֹת דּוּמְיָא דְפַת.
human_translation: over vegetables one recites: taught vegetables similar to, bread, Just as bread that was transformed by fire, so too vegetables have been transformed by fire. Rabbenai said in the name Abaye: This means over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruits of the ground. From where taught vegetables similar to bread.
llm_translation: Regarding vegetables, it is stated, etc. The Mishnah teaches: Vegetables are similar to bread — just as bread changes through exposure to light, so too vegetables change through exposure to light. Rabnai said in the name of Abbaye: This teaches that we recite the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the earth" over cooked vegetables. From where? — From the Mishnah that states: Vegetables are similar to bread.

hebrew_text: דָּרַשׁ רַב חִסְדָּא מִשּׁוּם רַבֵּינוּ, וּמַנּוּ — רַב: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. וְרַבּוֹתֵינוּ הַיּוֹרְדִין מֵאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וּמַנּוּ — עוּלָּא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. וַאֲנִי אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁתְּחִלָּתוֹ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, שְׁלָקוֹ — ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. וְכֹל שֶׁתְּחִלָּתוֹ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, שְׁלָקוֹ — ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda taught in the name of Rabbeinu; and Who is Rav. Over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. And our Rabbis who descended from Eretz Yisrael, And who is Ulla said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Over boiled vegetables one recites: By whose word all things came to be, And I say Any in its original Who creates fruit of the ground, boiled it, By whose word all things came to be, And any in its original By whose word all things came to be, boiled it, Who creates fruit of the ground.
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah expounded in the name of our teacher, and they counted — Rav: For vegetables, one recites the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the earth." And our teachers who descend from the Land of Israel, and they counted — Ulla in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan said: For vegetables, one recites the blessing "by whose word everything came to be." And I say: Anything whose beginning is "Who creates the fruit of the earth," one recites "by whose word everything came to be." And anything whose beginning is "by whose word everything came to be," one recites "Who creates the fruit of the earth."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא כֹּל שֶׁתְּחִלָּתוֹ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״ שְׁלָקוֹ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״ — מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ בִּכְרָבָא וְסִלְקָא וְקָרָא, אֶלָּא כֹּל שֶׁתְּחִלָּתוֹ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״ שְׁלָקוֹ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״, הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ בְּתוּמֵי וְכַרָּתֵי.
human_translation: Granted, any in its original By whose word all things came to be, boiled it, Who creates fruit of the ground, you find cabbage, chard, and pumpkin However, what you find any in its original Who creates fruit of the ground, boiled it, By whose word all things came to be, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: You find it garlic and leeks.
llm_translation: In truth, everything whose beginning is "that everything is dependent on His word," its end is "Who creates the fruit of the earth." If one forgets it in the morning, afternoon, or evening, rather everything whose beginning is "Who creates the fruit of the earth," its end is "that everything." How does one forget it? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: One forgets it with dates and leeks.

hebrew_text: דָּרַשׁ רַב נַחְמָן מִשּׁוּם רַבֵּינוּ, וּמַנּוּ — שְׁמוּאֵל: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. וַחֲבֵרֵינוּ הַיּוֹרְדִים מֵאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וּמַנּוּ — עוּלָּא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman taught in the name of Rabbeinu; and who is Shmuel: Over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. And our colleagues who descended from Eretz Yisrael; and who is Ulla said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: By whose word all things came to be.
llm_translation: Rav Nahman expounded in the name of our master, and they counted — Shmuel: Those who gather sheaves bless over them "Who creates the fruit of the earth." And our colleagues who descend from the Land of Israel, and they counted — Ulla in the name of Rabbi Yochanan said: Those who gather sheaves bless over them "by whose word everything came into being."

hebrew_text: וַאֲנִי אוֹמֵר בְּמַחֲלוֹקֶת שְׁנוּיָה. דְּתַנְיָא: יוֹצְאִין בְּרָקִיק הַשָּׁרוּי וּבִמְבוּשָּׁל שֶׁלֹּא נִמּוֹחַ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר, וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: יוֹצְאִים בְּרָקִיק הַשָּׁרוּי, אֲבָל לֹא בַּמְבוּשָּׁל, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא נִמּוֹחַ.
human_translation: I say this taught as a dispute, as it was taught One fulfills the with a wafer soaked with boiled it did not dissolve; the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yosei says: One fulfills the with a soaked wafer but not with boiled even if it did not dissolve.
llm_translation: I say in a dispute that is repeated. For it was taught: One may go out with a roasted cake and with a cooked one that has not been wiped, the words of Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Yosei says: One may go out with a roasted cake, but not with a cooked one, even though it has not been wiped.

hebrew_text: וְלָא הִיא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְעַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הָתָם, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵינַן טַעַם מַצָּה, וְלֵיכָּא, אֲבָל הָכָא אֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי מוֹדֶה.
human_translation: That is not so; as everyone agrees that over boiled vegetables one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground. Rabbi Yosei only said there, because we require taste of matza , and it is lacking. However, here, even Rabbi Yosei agrees
llm_translation: And not so, for everyone in the world who eats vegetables blesses over them "Who creates the fruit of the earth," and until here Rabbi Yosei did not say there, but because we require the taste of matzah, and there is none, but here even Rabbi Yosei agrees.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְרַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין בַּר יֶפֶת אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שְׁלָקוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: קְבַע עוּלָּא לְשַׁבֶּשְׁתֵּיהּ כְּרַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין בַּר יֶפֶת.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: Who creates fruit of the ground, and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Over boiled vegetables, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Ulla established his error in accordance with Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet,
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Yochanan: For beets one recites "Blessed is the Creator of the fruit of the ground," and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet said Rabbi Yochanan: For beets one recites "by whose word everything came to be." Said Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: He established the principle to follow the opinion of Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet.

hebrew_text: תָּהֵי בַּהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא: וְכִי מָה עִנְיָן רַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין בַּר יֶפֶת אֵצֶל רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא? רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא דָּיֵיק וְגָמַר שְׁמַעְתָּא מֵרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן רַבֵּיהּ, וְרַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין בַּר יֶפֶת לָא דָּיֵיק. וְעוֹד, רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא כֹּל תְּלָתִין יוֹמִין מַהְדַּר תַּלְמוּדֵיהּ קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן רַבֵּיהּ, וְרַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין בַּר יֶפֶת לָא מַהְדַּר. וְעוֹד, בַּר מִן דֵּין וּבַר מִן דֵּין, דְּהָהוּא תּוּרְמְסָא דְּשָׁלְקִי לֵיהּ שְׁבַע זִמְנִין בִּקְדֵרָה וְאָכְלִי לֵיהּ בְּקִנּוּחַ סְעוּדָה, אֲתוֹ וּשְׁאִלוּ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, וְאָמַר לְהוּ: מְבָרְכִין עִלָּוֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira wondered What is the matter of Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet with Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was meticulous and learned the halakha from Rabbi Yoḥanan, his teacher; and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet was not meticulous. Furthermore, every thirty days, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba reviews his studies before Rabbi Yoḥanan, his teacher, while Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet does not review Furthermore, aside from these the lupin is boiled seven times in a pot and eaten as dessert meal. They came and asked Rabbi Yoḥanan and he said to them: One recites over it: Who creates fruit of the ground,
llm_translation: Let it be with Rabbi Zeira: And what is the matter of Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet with Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba? Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba was precise and learned the teaching from Rabbi Yochanan his teacher, and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet was not precise. Furthermore, Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba every thirty days would review his studies before Rabbi Yochanan his teacher, and Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet did not review. Furthermore, one is from judgment and one is from judgment, for that certain worm that was thrown to him seven times into a pot and he ate it with a reed at a meal, they came and asked Rabbi Yochanan, and he said to them: One blesses over it "Who creates the fruit of the earth."

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד, אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא: אֲנִי רָאִיתִי אֶת רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן שֶׁאָכַל זַיִת מָלִיחַ, וּבֵרַךְ עָלָיו תְּחִלָּה וָסוֹף. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא שְׁלָקוֹת בְּמִילְּתַיְיהוּ קָיְימִי — בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו בְּרָכָה אַחַת מֵעֵין שָׁלֹשׁ. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ שְׁלָקוֹת לָאו בְּמִילְּתַיְיהוּ קָיְימִי, בִּשְׁלָמָא בַּתְּחִלָּה מְבָרֵךְ עָלָיו ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״ — אֶלָּא לְבַסּוֹף מַאי מְבָרֵךְ?
human_translation: Furthermore, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: I saw Rabbi Yoḥanan eat a salted olive, and he recited a blessing over it both before and after. Granted, if you say boiled vegetables remain in their original state at the start one recites over it: Who creates fruit of the tree, and at the end one recites over it one blessing abridged from three However, if you say boiled vegetables do not remain in their original state, granted, at the start, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. However, at the end, what blessing does he recite?
llm_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said: I saw Rabbi Yochanan eat a salty olive, and he blessed over it both at the beginning and at the end. If you say that they are consistent in their words - at the beginning he blesses over it "Who creates the fruit of the tree," and at the end he blesses over it a blessing similar to three. But if you say that they are not consistent in their words, at the beginning he blesses over it "by whose word everything exists," but what does he bless at the end?

hebrew_text: דִּילְמָא ״בּוֹרֵא נְפָשׁוֹת רַבּוֹת וְחֶסְרוֹנָן עַל כׇּל מַה שֶּׁבָּרָא״.
human_translation: perhaps Who creates the many forms of life and their needs, for all that You have created.
llm_translation: Perhaps "He creates souls many and their deficiencies on all that He created."

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב יִצְחָק בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: יְרָקוֹת שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ בַּפֶּסַח — יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן וּבַקֶּלַח שֶׁלָּהֶן, אֲבָל לֹא כְּבוּשִׁין, וְלֹא שְׁלוּקִין, וְלֹא מְבוּשָּׁלִין. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בְּמִילְּתַיְיהוּ קָאֵי — שְׁלוּקִין אַמַּאי לָא?
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Shmuel raised an objection Vegetables with which one may fulfill his obligation on Passover, one fulfills with themselves as well as with their stalks. However, neither with pickled nor with boiled nor with cooked And if it would enter your mind they remain in their original state, why are boiled
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Yitzchak bar Shmuel asked: "Vegetables that one fulfills his obligation with on Pesach - one may fulfill his obligation with them and with their stalks, but not with their cooked leaves, nor with their boiled leaves, nor with their roasted leaves. And if you were to say that it is due to their leaves - why not with their boiled leaves?"

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּבָעֵינַן טַעַם מָרוֹר, וְלֵיכָּא.
human_translation: It is different there, as we require taste of bitter herbs, and it is lacking.
llm_translation: The matter there is different, as we require a bitter taste, and it is not present.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי זֵירָא: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הֵיכִי מְבָרֵךְ עַל זַיִת מָלִיחַ? כֵּיוָן דִּשְׁקִילָא לְגַרְעִינֵיהּ
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: How did Rabbi Yoḥanan recite a blessing over a salted olive Since the pit was removed,
llm_translation: He said to him, Rabbi Yirmeya to Rabbi Zeira: Rabbi Yochanan, how does he bless on a salted olive? Once he has taken out its pit.

hebrew_text: בָּצַר לֵיהּ שִׁיעוּרָא.
human_translation: it lacks the measure?
llm_translation: He was in distress of measurement.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לֵיהּ: מִי סָבְרַתְּ כְּזַיִת גָּדוֹל בָּעֵינַן? כְּזַיִת בֵּינוֹנִי בָּעֵינַן (וְהָא אִיכָּא), וְהַהוּא דְּאַיְיתוֹ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן זַיִת גָּדוֹל הֲוָה, דְּאַף עַל גַּב דְּשַׁקְלוּהָ לְגַרְעִינוּתֵיהּ פָּשׁ לֵיהּ שִׁיעוּרָא.
human_translation: He said to him: Do you hold that we require a large olive We require a medium-sized olive and that was that they brought before Rabbi Yoḥanan was a large olive. Even though they removed its pit, the measure remained.
llm_translation: He said to him: Who holds that we require an olive the size of a large olive? We require an average-sized olive (and there is a case), and that one that they brought before Rabbi Yochanan was a large olive, for even though they weighed it against its seeds, it still reached the measure.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: זַיִת שֶׁאָמְרוּ לֹא קָטָן וְלֹא גָּדוֹל, אֶלָּא בֵּינוֹנִי — וְזֶהוּ ״אֵגוֹרִי״. וְאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: לֹא ״אֵגוֹרִי״ שְׁמוֹ אֶלָּא ״אִבְרוֹטִי״ שְׁמוֹ, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ ״סִמְרוֹסִי״ שְׁמוֹ. וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ ״אֵגוֹרִי״ — שֶׁשַּׁמְנוֹ אָגוּר בְּתוֹכוֹ.
human_translation: as we learned The olive of which spoke neither small nor large, but medium, and that is aguri . And Rabbi Abbahu said: The name is not aguri , but its name is avruti , and some say its name is samrusi . And why, is it called aguri ? Because its oil is accumulated [ agur ] inside it.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: Olive oil that they said is neither small nor large, but medium - and this is called "Egori." And Rabbi Abbahu said: Its name is not "Egori" but "Ivroti," and some say its name is "Simrosi." And why is it called "Egori" - because it contains an egg's worth of oil within it.

hebrew_text: נֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: דְּהָנְהוּ תְּרֵי תַּלְמִידֵי דַּהֲווֹ יָתְבִי קַמֵּיהּ דְּבַר קַפָּרָא. הֵבִיאוּ לְפָנָיו כְּרוּב וְדוֹרְמַסְקִין וּפַרְגִּיּוֹת. נָתַן בַּר קַפָּרָא רְשׁוּת לְאֶחָד מֵהֶן לְבָרֵךְ, קָפַץ וּבֵרַךְ עַל הַפַּרְגִּיּוֹת. לִגְלֵג עָלָיו חֲבֵירוֹ. כָּעַס בַּר קַפָּרָא אָמַר: לֹא עַל הַמְבָרֵךְ אֲנִי כּוֹעֵס, אֶלָּא עַל הַמְלַגְלֵג אֲנִי כּוֹעֵס. אִם חֲבֵירְךָ דּוֹמֶה כְּמִי שֶׁלֹּא טָעַם טַעַם בָּשָׂר מֵעוֹלָם, אַתָּה עַל מָה לִגְלַגְתָּ עָלָיו? חָזַר וְאָמַר: לֹא עַל הַמְלַגְלֵג אֲנִי כּוֹעֵס, אֶלָּא עַל הַמְבָרֵךְ אֲנִי כּוֹעֵס. וְאָמַר: אִם חָכְמָה אֵין כָּאן, זִקְנָה אֵין כָּאן?!
human_translation: Let us say is parallel tanna’im , Two students were sitting before bar Kappara when cabbage, plums and pullets were set before him. Bar Kappara gave one of permission to recite a blessing. He hurried and recited a blessing over the pullets his counterpart ridiculed him Bar Kappara became angry he said: I am not angry with the one who recited the blessing, but at the one who ridiculed If your counterpart is like one who never tasted the flavor of meat why did you ridicule him? continued and said I am not upset at the one who ridiculed rather with the one who recited the blessing that I am angry. And he said: If there is no wisdom here, is there no elder here?
llm_translation: Said as the Tannaim: For there were two disciples who were sitting before Rabbi Kapara. They brought before him a cabbage, turnips, and mushrooms. Bar Kapara gave permission to one of them to bless, he jumped up and blessed over the mushrooms. His companion mocked him. Bar Kapara became angry and said: I am not angry at the one who blesses, but at the one who mocks. If your companion is like someone who has never tasted meat, why do you mock him? He reconsidered and said: I am not angry at the one who mocks, but at the one who blesses. And he said: If there is no wisdom here, is there no age here?!

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: וּשְׁנֵיהֶם לֹא הוֹצִיאוּ שְׁנָתָן.
human_translation: it was taught: And both of them did not out his year.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "And both of them did not bring out Sh'natan."

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָא מִיפַּלְגִי, דִּמְבָרֵךְ סָבַר שְׁלָקוֹת וּפַרְגִּיּוֹת ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, הִלְכָּךְ חַבִּיב עֲדִיף, וּמְלַגְלֵג סָבַר שְׁלָקוֹת ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, פַּרְגִּיּוֹת ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, הִלְכָּךְ פֵּירָא עֲדִיף.
human_translation: What? Is it not that they disagreed with regard to the following? one who recited the blessing held boiled vegetables and pullet By whose word all things came to be, and, therefore, he prefers precedence one who ridiculed held boiled vegetables Who creates fruit of the ground, pullet By whose word all things came to be, and, therefore, the fruit precedence,
llm_translation: What is the reason that he does not differentiate between them, for he who blesses, he holds that vegetables and fruits "by His word everything comes to be," therefore he holds vegetables dearer, and he who peels holds that vegetables "Who creates the fruit of the earth," fruits "by His word everything comes to be," therefore fruits are dearer.

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא שְׁלָקוֹת וּפַרְגִּיּוֹת ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיָה בִּדְבָרוֹ״, וְהָכָא בְּהַאי סְבָרָא קָא מִיפַּלְגִי: מָר סָבַר חַבִּיב עֲדִיף, וּמָר סָבַר כְּרוּב עֲדִיף, דְּזָיֵין.
human_translation: No, everyone agrees boiled vegetables and pullet By whose word all things came to be, and here they argue over this: Sage, held that preferred takes precedence and the Sage held: Cabbage takes precedence, as it nourishes.
llm_translation: Not, that, all, of, the, world, baskets, and, fruits, "that, everything, was, by, His, word", and, here, in, this, reasoning, is, differing: master, thinks, beloved, is, preferable, and, master, thinks, like, a cherub, is, preferable, for, they, are.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי רַב הוּנָא אֲמַר לַן: הָנֵי גַּרְגְּלִידֵי דְלִפְתָּא, פַּרְמִינְהוּ פְּרִימָא רַבָּא — ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, פְּרִימָא זוּטָא — ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. וְכִי אֲתָאן לְבֵי רַב יְהוּדָה אֲמַר לַן: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְהָא דְּפַרְמִינְהוּ טְפֵי, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּנִמְתִּיק טַעְמֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Huna he said to us: These turnip heads, one cut them large Who creates fruit of the ground, cut them small By whose word all things came to be. And when we came to the study hall of Rav Yehuda he said to us: these, and those, Who creates fruit of the ground, and the fact that he cut them extensively was in order to sweeten its flavor.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said, when we were in the study hall of Rav Huna, he said to us: "Those figs of Difta, separate them into large figs — 'Who creates the fruit of the earth,' small figs — 'that everything is by His word.' And when we came to the study hall of Rav Yehuda, he said to us: Both of them are 'Who creates the fruit of the earth,' and what we separate is the peel, so that its taste may sweeten."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי, כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי רַב כָּהֲנָא אֲמַר לַן: תַּבְשִׁילָא דְסִלְקָא, דְּלָא מַפְּשׁוּ בַּהּ קִמְחָא — ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. דְּלִפְתָּא, דְּמַפְּשׁוּ בַּהּ קִמְחָא טְפֵי — ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״. וַהֲדַר אָמַר: אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וְהַאי דְּשָׁדֵי בַּהּ קִמְחָא טְפֵי — לְדַבּוֹקֵי בְּעָלְמָא עָבְדִי לַהּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, he said to us: a cooked dish of beets to which they, do not add significant flour, Who creates fruit of the ground. a cooked dish of turnips to which they, add more significant flour, Who creates the various types of nourishment. And reconsidered these, and those, Who creates fruit of the ground, and the fact that they threw extra flour in they did so merely stick together.
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said, when we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, he said to us: A cooked dish made from peeled grain, in which flour is not kneaded - "Who creates the fruit of the earth." But a baked dish, in which flour is kneaded excessively - "Who creates various kinds of sustenance." And he further said: Both of them "Who creates the fruit of the earth," and this one in which flour is kneaded excessively - are done to adhere to the ways of the world.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תַּבְשִׁיל שֶׁל תְּרָדִין יָפֶה לַלֵּב, וְטוֹב לָעֵינַיִם, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן לִבְנֵי מֵעַיִם. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: וְהוּא דְּיָתֵיב אַבֵּי תָפֵי וְעָבֵיד ״תּוֹךְ תּוֹךְ״.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda and said: A cooked dish of beets is beneficial for the heart, good for the eyes and all the more so, for the intestines. Abaye said: That is sits on the stove and makes a tukh tukh
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: A dish of beets is good for the heart, and beneficial for the eyes, and all the more so for the children of Ma'ayim. Abbaye said: And this is when Abba the cook sits and prepares "inside, inside."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: פְּשִׁיטָא לִי מַיָּא דְסִלְקָא — כְּסִלְקָא, וּמַיָּא דְלִפְתָּא — כְּלִפְתָּא, וּמַיָּא דְּכוּלְּהוּ שִׁלְקֵי — כְּכוּלְּהוּ שִׁלְקֵי. בָּעֵי רַב פָּפָּא: מַיָּא דְשִׁיבְתָּא מַאי? לְמַתּוֹקֵי טַעְמָא עָבְדִי, אוֹ לְעַבּוֹרֵי זוּהֲמָא עָבְדִי לַהּ?
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: It is clear to me beet water, has as beets, and turnip water has turnips, and the water all boiled vegetables has as all boiled vegetables. Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What water dill Do they use to sweeten the taste, or do they use it to remove filth?
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: "The water of the upper chamber is like the upper chamber, and the water of the lower chamber is like the lower chamber, and the water of all the chambers is like all the chambers." Rav Papa asked: "What is the water of Shibta used for? Is it used to sweeten the taste, or is it used to remove impurities?"

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הַשֶּׁבֶת מִשֶּׁנָּתְנָה טַעַם בַּקְּדֵירָה אֵין בָּהּ מִשּׁוּם תְּרוּמָה, וְאֵינָהּ מְטַמְּאָה טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִים. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לְמַתּוֹקֵי טַעְמָא עָבְדִי לַהּ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Come and hear Dill, once it has given flavor in the pot, is no subject to teruma and it can no the ritual impurity of food. Learn from this they used to sweeten the taste. learn from this.
llm_translation: Come and hear: If the Sabbath was placed into the pot with a flavor, it does not have the status of terumah, and it does not impart impurity of food. Learn from this regarding those who prepare flavors for it. Learn from this.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי: פַּת צְנוּמָה בִּקְעָרָה מְבָרְכִין עָלֶיהָ ״הַמּוֹצִיא״. וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא: צָרִיךְ שֶׁתִּכְלֶה בְּרָכָה עִם הַפַּת.
human_translation: Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: Over dry bread in a bowl one recites: Who brings forth disagrees with Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya said: The blessing must conclude with the bread.
llm_translation: Rav Chiya bar Ashe said: A whole loaf of bread in a bowl, one recites "Hamotzi" over it. And it is in dispute with Rabbi Chiya, for Rabbi Chiya said: It is necessary that the blessing concludes with the bread.

hebrew_text: מַתְקִיף לַהּ רָבָא: מַאי שְׁנָא צְנוּמָה דְּלָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּכִי כָּלְיָא בְּרָכָה — אַפְּרוּסָה קָא כָּלְיָא? עַל הַפַּת נָמֵי, כִּי קָא גָמְרָה — אַפְּרוּסָה גָּמְרָה!
human_translation: Rava strongly objects to this What is different about dried bread, that not because when the blessing concludes, it concludes on a slice? on bread as well, when he completes he completes it on a slice,
llm_translation: Rava objects to her: What is the difference of a basket that is not covered, because when it is a vessel of blessing - it is a basket? On bread also, when it is finished - it is finished!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: מְבָרֵךְ וְאַחַר כָּךְ בּוֹצֵעַ.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: recites the blessing and afterwards, he breaks it.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: One recites the blessing and afterwards breaks the bread.

hebrew_text: נְהַרְדָּעֵי עָבְדִי כְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא וְרַבָּנַן עָבְדִי כְּרָבָא. אָמַר רָבִינָא: אָמְרָה לִי אֵם, אֲבוּךְ עָבֵיד כְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא: צָרִיךְ שֶׁתִּכְלֶה בְּרָכָה עִם הַפַּת. וְרַבָּנַן עָבְדִי כְּרָבָא. וְהִלְכְתָא כְּרָבָא, דְּאָמַר מְבָרֵךְ וְאַחַר כָּךְ בּוֹצֵעַ.
human_translation: of Neharde’a acted in accordance with Rabbi Ḥiyya And the Rabbis acted in accordance with Rava Ravina said: My mother told me: Your father acted in accordance with Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya said: The blessing must conclude with the bread. And the Rabbis acted in accordance with Rava. The halakha in accordance with Rava, said recites the blessing and afterwards he breaks it.
llm_translation: The Nehardea scholars followed the practice of Rabbi Chiya, and the Rabbanan followed the practice of Rava. Ravina said: My mother told me, your father acts like Rabbi Chiya, for Rabbi Chiya said: One must conclude the blessing together with the breaking of bread. And the Rabbanan followed the practice of Rava. And the halacha is like Rava, for he said one recites the blessing first and then breaks the bread.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הֵבִיאוּ לִפְנֵיהֶם פְּתִיתִין וּשְׁלֵמִין, אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַפְּתִיתִין וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַשְּׁלֵמִין. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: שְׁלֵמָה מִצְוָה מִן הַמּוּבְחָר. אֲבָל פְּרוּסָה שֶׁל חִטִּין וּשְׁלֵמָה מִן הַשְּׂעוֹרִין, דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַפְּרוּסָה שֶׁל חִטִּין, וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַשְּׁלֵמָה שֶׁל שְׂעוֹרִין.
human_translation: It was stated they brought pieces and whole before Rav Huna said: One recite the blessing over the pieces and exempts the whole Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The optimal manner the mitzva whole However, piece was of wheat and the whole was of barley everyone agrees one recites a blessing over the piece of wheat and one exempts the whole of barley
llm_translation: It was stated: They brought before them bread and vegetables. Rav Huna said: One recites a blessing over the vegetables and exempts the bread. But Rabbi Yochanan said: Bread is preferable to vegetables. However, regarding a slice of wheat bread and a whole barley loaf, everyone agrees that one recites a blessing over the slice of wheat bread and exempts the barley loaf.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בַּר אַבָּא כְּתַנָּאֵי: תּוֹרְמִין בָּצָל קָטָן שָׁלֵם, אֲבָל לֹא חֲצִי בָּצָל גָּדוֹל. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִי, אֶלָּא חֲצִי בָּצָל גָּדוֹל. מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, דְּמָר סָבַר חָשׁוּב עָדִיף, וּמָר סָבַר שָׁלֵם עָדִיף.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said parallel tannaitic one separates teruma from a whole small onion but not from half of a large onion. Rabbi Yehuda says: No, rather, half of a large onion. What, is it not that they disagree over this that Sage, held more significant takes precedence; and held whole takes precedence?
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba like the Tannaim: One may separate terumah from a small onion, but not from a large onion. Rabbi Yehuda says: Not so, rather one may separate terumah from a large onion. What is the reason they do not disagree? One Master holds that what is considered significant is preferable, and the other Master holds that what is whole is preferable.

hebrew_text: הֵיכָא דְּאִיכָּא כֹּהֵן, כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּחָשׁוּב עָדִיף. כִּי פְּלִיגִי דְּלֵיכָּא כֹּהֵן. דִּתְנַן: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁיֵּשׁ כֹּהֵן — תּוֹרֵם מִן הַיָּפֶה, וְכׇל מָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין כֹּהֵן — תּוֹרֵם מִן הַמִּתְקַיֵּים. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין תּוֹרֵם אֶלָּא מִן הַיָּפֶה.
human_translation: Where there is a priest everyone agrees more significant takes precedence. When they disagree where there is no priest as we learned Everywhere that there is a priest, one separates teruma from the best, and whenever there is no priest, one separates teruma from that which will endure, Rabbi Yehuda says: One separates teruma only from the best,
llm_translation: Here where there is a Kohen, everyone does not argue that esteemed is superior. When they argue that there is no Kohen. For it was taught: Any place where there is a Kohen - one contributes from the beautiful, and any place where there is no Kohen - one contributes from the available. Rabbi Yehuda says: One only contributes from the beautiful.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: וִירֵא שָׁמַיִם יוֹצֵא יְדֵי שְׁנֵיהֶן, וּמַנּוּ? — מָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא, דְּמָר בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא מַנִּיחַ פְּרוּסָה בְּתוֹךְ הַשְּׁלֵמָה וּבוֹצֵעַ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: A God-fearing individual fulfills both. And who is this Mar, son of Ravina, Mar, son of Ravina, place the piece inside the loaf and break
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: "One who fears Heaven, his two hands come out, and they count? — Mar the son of Ravina, for Mar the son of Ravina places a piece in the middle of the whole and cuts."

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי תַּנָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מַנִּיחַ הַפְּרוּסָה בְּתוֹךְ הַשְּׁלֵמָה וּבוֹצֵעַ וּמְבָרֵךְ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַה שִּׁמְךָ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שַׁלְמָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שָׁלוֹם אַתָּה וּשְׁלֵמָה מִשְׁנָתְךָ, שֶׁשַּׂמְתָּ שָׁלוֹם בֵּין הַתַּלְמִידִים.
human_translation: the tanna recited before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: One places the piece inside the whole breaks and recites a blessing. said to him: What is your name? He answered: Shalman. replied You are peace [ shalom ] and teaching you is complete [ shelema ] as you established peace among students.
llm_translation: The Tanna taught before Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: He places the slice within the whole and cuts, and recites a blessing. He said to him: What is your name? He said to him: Shalman. He said to him: Peace be upon you and upon your wholeness, for you have placed peace among the disciples.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הַכֹּל מוֹדִים בְּפֶסַח, שֶׁמַּנִּיחַ פְּרוּסָה בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֵמָה וּבוֹצֵעַ. מַאי טַעְמָא? — ״לֶחֶם עֹנִי״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: Everyone agrees that on Passover, one places the piece inside the whole and breaks. What is the reason? “Bread of affliction” is written,
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Everyone agrees regarding Pesach, that one must place a piece within a whole and break it. What is the reason? — "Bread of affliction" is written.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא וּבְשַׁבָּת חַיָּיב אָדָם לִבְצוֹעַ עַל שְׁתֵּי כִכָּרוֹת. מַאי טַעְמָא? — ״לֶחֶם מִשְׁנֶה״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said: And on Shabbat one is obligated to break over two loaves. What is the reason? “Twice as much bread” is written.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Abba, "And on Shabbat, a person is obligated to cut from two loaves. What is the reason? - 'Double bread' is written."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: חֲזֵינָא לֵיהּ לְרַב כָּהֲנָא דְּנָקֵיט תַּרְתֵּי וּבָצַע חֲדָא. רַבִּי זֵירָא הֲוָה בָּצַע אַכּוֹלָּא שֵׁירוּתָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְהָא קָא מִתְחֲזֵי כְּרַעַבְתָנוּתָא. אֲמַר [לֵיהּ]: כֵּיוָן דְּכָל יוֹמָא לָא קָעָבֵיד הָכִי, וְהָאִידָּנָא קָא עָבֵיד — לָא מִתְחֲזֵי כְּרַעַבְתָנוּתָא.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: I saw Rav Kahana who would take two and break one. Rabbi Zeira would break for the entire meal. Ravina said to Rav Ashi Doesn’t it appear gluttonous said to him: Since every day does not do so, and today he does, it does not appear gluttonous,
llm_translation: Rav Ashei said: I saw Rav Kahana who would take two and eat one. Rabbi Zeira would eat a portion of food. Ravina said to Rav Ashei: But he appears as one who is fasting. He replied to him: Since every day he did not act in this way, and now he is doing so, it does not appear as fasting.

hebrew_text: רַב אַמֵּי וְרַב אַסִּי כִּי הֲוָה מִתְרְמֵי לְהוּ רִיפְתָּא דְעֵרוּבָא מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהּ ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״. אָמְרִי: הוֹאִיל וְאִתְעֲבִיד בֵּיהּ מִצְוָה חֲדָא, נַעֲבֵיד בֵּיהּ מִצְוָה אַחֲרִיתִי.
human_translation: Rav Ami and Rav Asi, when the the bread of the eiruv would present itself, recite: Who brings forth bread from the earth over it. They said Since one mitzva was performed with it, we will perform another mitzva with it.
llm_translation: Rav Ammi and Rav Assi, when they would prepare the dish of Eruv, would recite over it "Who brings forth bread from the earth." They said: Since we are engaged in one commandment with it, let us engage in another commandment with it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: ״טוֹל בָּרוּךְ, טוֹל בָּרוּךְ״ — אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ. ״הָבֵא מֶלַח״ ״הָבֵא לִפְתָּן״ — צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ ״הָבִיאוּ מֶלַח״ ״הָבִיאוּ לִפְתָּן״ נָמֵי אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, ״גַּבֵּיל לְתוֹרֵי, גַּבֵּיל לְתוֹרֵי״ צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ. וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ ״גַּבֵּיל לְתוֹרֵי״ נָמֵי אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אָסוּר לָאָדָם שֶׁיֹּאכַל קוֹדֶם שֶׁיִּתֵּן מַאֲכָל לִבְהֶמְתּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְנָתַתִּי עֵשֶׂב בְּשָׂדְךָ לִבְהֶמְתֶּךָ״ וַהֲדַר ״וְאָכַלְתָּ וְשָׂבָעְתָּ״.
human_translation: Rav said: Take recite a blessing, take recite a blessing, need not recite the blessing Bring salt or bring relish, he must recite the blessing And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even Bring salt bring relish, and he need not recite the blessing Mix for the oxen, mix for the oxen, and he is required to recite the blessing And Rav Sheshet said: Even Mix for the oxen, he need not recite a blessing as Rav Yehuda said Rav said: One is prohibited from eating before feeding his animals, as it is stated: “And I will give grass in your fields for your animals” and then: “And you shall eat and be satisfied”
llm_translation: Rav said: "Tol Baruch, Tol Baruch" — one does not need to bless. "Habe Melech" "Habe Lifton" — one needs to bless. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even "Haivi'u Melech" "Haivi'u Lifton" also does not need to bless, "Gavil Letorei, Gavil Letorei" one needs to bless. And Rav Sheshet said: Even "Gavil Letorei" also does not need to bless, as Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: It is forbidden for a person to eat before giving food to his animal, as it is stated: "And I will give grass in your field for your animals" and afterwards "And you shall eat and be satisfied."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי חִיָּיא: אֵין הַבּוֹצֵעַ רַשַּׁאי לִבְצוֹעַ עַד שֶׁיָּבִיאוּ מֶלַח אוֹ לִפְתָּן לִפְנֵי כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד. רָבָא בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל אִקְּלַע לְבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא, אַפִּיקוּ לֵיהּ רִיפְתָּא, וּבְצַע לְהֶדְיָא. אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: הֲדַר מָר מִשְּׁמַעְתֵּיהּ? אֲמַר לְהוּ: לֵית דֵּין צְרִיךְ בְּשַׁשׁ.
human_translation: Rava bar Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One who breaks is not permitted to break until they bring salt or relish before each and every one Rava bar Shmuel happened to the House of the Exilarch. They brought him bread, which he immediately broke, They said to him: Did the Master reconsider his halakhic He said to them: this does not require waiting.
llm_translation: Rava son of Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Chiya: The butcher is not permitted to slaughter until they bring salt or a sponge before each and every one. Rava son of Shmuel entered the house of the head of the exile, they brought him a sponge, and he slaughtered a bird. They said to him: Has the master changed his mind? He said to them: There is no need for a judge in a six.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי חִיָּיא: אֵין מֵי רַגְלַיִם כָּלִים אֶלָּא בִּישִׁיבָה. אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: וּבְעָפָר תִּיחוּחַ, אֲפִילּוּ בַּעֲמִידָה. וְאִי לֵיכָּא עָפָר תִּיחוּחַ, יַעֲמוֹד בְּמָקוֹם גָּבוֹהַּ וְיַשְׁתִּין לִמְקוֹם מִדְרוֹן.
human_translation: And Rava bar Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: Urine only completely seated, Rav Kahana said: Over loose soil even when standing And if there is no loose soil Stand on an elevated place and urinate down an inclined plane.
llm_translation: And Rava son of Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Chiya: The waters of the feet are utensils only when sitting. Rav Kahana said: And with dust they are rinsed, even when standing. And if there is no dust for rinsing, one should stand in a high place and urinate downward.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא אַחַר כׇּל אֲכִילָתְךָ אֱכוֹל מֶלַח, וְאַחַר כׇּל שְׁתִיָּיתְךָ שְׁתֵה מַיִם, וְאִי אַתָּה נִזּוֹק. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: אַחַר כׇּל אֲכִילָתְךָ אֱכוֹל מֶלַח, וְאַחַר כׇּל שְׁתִיָּיתְךָ שְׁתֵה מַיִם, וְאִי אַתָּה נִזּוֹק. תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: אָכַל כׇּל מַאֲכָל וְלֹא אָכַל מֶלַח, שָׁתָה כׇּל מַשְׁקִין וְלֹא שָׁתָה מַיִם, בַּיּוֹם — יִדְאַג מִן רֵיחַ הַפֶּה, וּבַלַּיְלָה  — יִדְאַג מִפְּנֵי אַסְכָּרָה.
human_translation: And Rava bar Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: After all eating, eat salt and after all drinking, drink water and you will not be harmed. That was also taught After all eating, eat salt and after all drinking, drink water and you will not be harmed. It was taught another If one ate any food and did not eat salt if he drank any liquid and did not drink water during the day, he should be concerned about bad breath, and at night he should be concerned about diphtheria.
llm_translation: And Rava son of Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Chiya: After all your eating, eat salt, and after all your drinking, drink water, and you will not be harmed. It was also taught similarly: After all your eating, eat salt, and after all your drinking, drink water, and you will not be harmed. Another teaching: If one ate all kinds of food but did not eat salt, and drank all kinds of beverages but did not drink water, during the day — he should worry about bad breath, and at night — he should worry about dizziness.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמַּקְפֶּה אֲכִילָתוֹ בְּמַיִם, אֵינוֹ בָּא לִידֵי חוֹלִי מֵעַיִם. וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: קִיתוֹן לְפַת.
human_translation: the Sages taught One who inundates his food with water, will not come to suffer intestinal illness. And how much Rav Ḥisda said: One jug [ kiton ] per loaf.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who washes his food in water does not come to stomach illness. And how much? Rav Ḥisda said: A loaf for a dish.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב מָרִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הָרָגִיל בַּעֲדָשִׁים אַחַת לִשְׁלשִׁים יוֹם מוֹנֵעַ אַסְכָּרָה מִתּוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ. אֲבָל כׇּל יוֹמָא — לָא. מַאי טַעְמָא? — מִשּׁוּם דְּקָשֶׁה לְרֵיחַ הַפֶּה.
human_translation: Rav Mari said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who is accustomed lentils once in thirty days prevents diphtheria from his house. However, not every day. What is the reason? Because it is deleterious bad breath.
llm_translation: Rav Mari said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who is accustomed to lentils, if he refrains for thirty days, prevents ascaris from his household. But every day - no. What is the reason? - Because it is difficult for the breath of the mouth.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב מָרִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הָרָגִיל בְּחַרְדָּל אַחַת לִשְׁלשִׁים יוֹם — מוֹנֵעַ חֳלָאִים מִתּוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ. אֲבָל כׇּל יוֹמָא — לָא, מַאי טַעְמָא? — מִשּׁוּם דְּקָשֵׁה לְחוּלְשָׁא דְלִבָּא.
