human_translation: And Rav Mari said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who is accustomed mustard once in thirty days prevents illnesses from his house. However, not every day. What is the reason? Because it is deleterious weakness of the heart.
llm_translation: And Rav Mari said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who regularly consumes one type of mustard for thirty days - prevents illnesses from entering his home. But every day - no, what is the reason? - Because it is hard on the stomach.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: הָרָגִיל בְּדָגִים קְטַנִּים — אֵינוֹ בָּא לִידֵי חוֹלִי מֵעַיִם. וְלֹא עוֹד, אֶלָּא שֶׁדָּגִים קְטַנִּים מַפְרִין וּמַרְבִּין וּמַבְרִין כׇּל גּוּפוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said Rav said: One who is accustomed small fish will not come to suffer intestinal illness. Moreover, small fish causes one’s entire body to flourish, to grow, and to be healthy.
llm_translation: Rav Chiya bar Ashe said in the name of Rav: One who regularly consumes small fish - does not come to intestinal illness. Moreover, small fish multiply, increase, and cleanse the entire body of a person.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: הָרָגִיל בְּקֶצַח אֵינוֹ בָּא לִידֵי כְּאֵב לֵב. מֵיתִיבִי: רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: קֶצַח — אֶחָד מִשִּׁשִּׁים סַמָּנֵי הַמָּוֶת הוּא, וְהַיָּשֵׁן לְמִזְרַח גׇּרְנוֹ — דָּמוֹ בְּרֹאשׁוֹ. לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּרֵיחוֹ, הָא בְּטַעְמוֹ. אִימֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה אָפְיָא לֵיהּ רִיפְתָּא, וּמְדַבְּקָא לֵיהּ וּמְקַלְּפָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: One who is accustomed black cumin, will not come to suffer heart pain. The Gemara raises an objection: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Black cumin is one of sixty deadly drugs, and one who sleeps to the east of its storage his blood is on his head. not difficult, as this, its odor, this, its taste. The mother Rabbi Yirmeya would bake him bread and would stick to it and she would peel it
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina: One who is accustomed to eat leek does not come to heartache. The Gemara raises an objection: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Leek is one of the sixty deadly poisons, and one who sleeps with the eastern side of his head—his blood is upon his head. This is not difficult: here it is referring to its smell, and here it is referring to its taste. In the days of Rabbi Yirmeya, they would bake it, apply it to him, and peel it off.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי דְשָׁאִים״. אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. וְאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה — אָמַר קְרָא ״בָּרוּךְ ה׳ יוֹם יוֹם״. וְכִי בַּיּוֹם מְבָרְכִין אוֹתוֹ, וּבַלַּיְלָה אֵין מְבָרְכִין אוֹתוֹ? אֶלָּא לוֹמַר לָךְ: כׇּל יוֹם וָיוֹם תֵּן לוֹ מֵעֵין בִּרְכוֹתָיו, הָכָא נָמֵי כׇּל מִין וּמִין תֵּן לוֹ מֵעֵין בִּרְכוֹתָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says Who creates various kinds of herbs. Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: The halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s The verse says: “Blessed is the Lord, day by day” Is it so that one blesses Him by day and does not bless Him at night? Rather, to tell you: Each and every day, give the Lord blessings Here too, each and every type give the
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says, "Creator of various types of vegetation." Rabbi Zeira said, and some say it was Rabbi Chinena bar Papa: The halacha is not like Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Zeira said, and some say it was Rabbi Chinena bar Papa: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda's statement? The verse says, "Blessed be the Lord day by day." Do we only bless Him during the day and not at night? Rather, to tell you: Every day, give Him blessings akin to His own blessings; here, give Him blessings of every type.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי חִינָּנָא בַּר פָּפָּא: בּוֹא וּרְאֵה שֶׁלֹּא כְּמִדַּת הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מִדַּת בָּשָׂר וָדָם. מִדַּת בָּשָׂר וָדָם — כְּלִי רֵיקָן מַחֲזִיק, מָלֵא אֵינוֹ מַחֲזִיק. אֲבָל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אֵינוֹ כֵן, מָלֵא מַחֲזִיק, רֵיקָן אֵינוֹ מַחֲזִיק. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אִם שָׁמוֹעַ תִּשְׁמַע״, אִם שָׁמוֹעַ — תִּשְׁמַע, וְאִם לָאו — לֹא תִשְׁמָע. דָּבָר אַחֵר: אִם שָׁמוֹעַ — בַּיָּשָׁן, תִּשְׁמַע — בֶּחָדָשׁ. וְאִם יִפְנֶה לְבָבְךָ — שׁוּב לֹא תִשְׁמָע.
human_translation: And Rabbi Zeira, and some say Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa, said: Come and see that the attribute of flesh and blood is unlike the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He. The attribute of flesh and blood is an empty vessel holds a full does not hold The attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not so, a full vessel hold an empty will not hold it is said: “And He said, if you will surely listen [ shamo’a tishma ] If you listen [ shamo’a ] you will listen [ tishma ] and if not, you will not listen. Alternatively: If you listened [ shamo’a ] to the old, you will listen [ tishma ] to the new if you turn your heart away, you will no longer be able to hear.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Zeira said, and some say it was Rabbi Chinena bar Papa: Come and see that the measure of the Holy One, blessed be He, is not like the measure of flesh and blood. The measure of flesh and blood - a vessel that is full holds, but one that is empty does not hold. But the Holy One, blessed be He, is not so; a full one holds, an empty one does not hold. As it is stated: "And He said, 'If you will diligently listen.'" If you will diligently listen - you will listen, but if not - you will not listen. Another interpretation: If you will diligently listen - in the old, you will listen - in the new. And if your heart turns away - return, you will not listen.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ בֵּירַךְ עַל פֵּירוֹת הָאִילָן ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״ — יָצָא. וְעַל פֵּירוֹת הָאָרֶץ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״ — לֹא יָצָא. וְעַל כּוּלָּם, אִם אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״ — יָצָא.
human_translation: One who recited: Who creates fruit of the ground, over fruit of the tree, fulfilled Who creates fruit of the tree, over fruits of the earth, did not fulfill And over all one who recited: By whose word all things came to be, fulfilled
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who blesses over the fruits of the tree saying "Blessed is the Creator of the fruit of the ground" - has fulfilled his obligation. But if one blesses over the fruits of the earth saying "Blessed is the Creator of the fruit of the tree" - he has not fulfilled his obligation. And if one blesses over all of them, saying "by whose word all things came to be" - he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאן תַּנָּא דְּעִיקַּר אִילָן אַרְעָא הִיא?! אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דִּתְנַן: יָבֵשׁ הַמַּעְיָן וְנִקְצַץ הָאִילָן — מֵבִיא וְאֵינוֹ קוֹרֵא. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מֵבִיא וְקוֹרֵא.
human_translation: Who is the tanna the primary of a tree is the earth, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: That Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned the spring dried up and the tree was chopped he brings does not read Rabbi Yehuda says: He brings and reads
llm_translation: Gemara: Who is the Tanna that maintains that the primary source of water is the land of the tree?! Rav Nahman son of Yitzchak said: It is Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned in a Mishnah: "If the spring dried up and the tree was cut down - one may bring the first fruits but does not recite the declaration. Rabbi Yehuda says: One may bring and recite."

hebrew_text: עַל פֵּירוֹת הָאָרֶץ וְכוּ׳. פְּשִׁיטָא! אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: לֹא נִצְרְכָה אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר חִטָּה מִין אִילָן הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: אִילָן שֶׁאָכַל מִמֶּנּוּ אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: גֶּפֶן הָיָה, שֶׁאֵין לְךָ דָּבָר שֶׁמֵּבִיא יְלָלָה עַל הָאָדָם אֶלָּא יַיִן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֵּשְׁתְּ מִן הַיַּיִן וַיִּשְׁכָּר״. רַבִּי נְחֶמְיָה אוֹמֵר: תְּאֵנָה הָיְתָה, שֶׁבַּדָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְקַלְקְלוּ בּוֹ נִתַּקְּנוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּתְפְּרוּ עֲלֵה תְאֵנָה״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: חִטָּה הָיְתָה, שֶׁאֵין הַתִּינוֹק יוֹדֵעַ לִקְרוֹת ״אַבָּא״ וְ״אִמָּא״ עַד שֶׁיִּטְעוֹם טַעַם דָּגָן.
human_translation: over fruits of the earth, That is obvious, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: is only necessary according to Rabbi Yehuda, said wheat is a type of tree, as we learned The tree from which Adam, the first ate, Rabbi Meir says: It was a vine, as nothing brings wailing upon man other than wine, it is stated “And he drank from the wine and became drunk” Rabbi Neḥemya says: It was a fig as with the object with which they were corrupted they were rehabilitated, as it is stated: “And they sewed together fig leaves Rabbi Yehuda says: It was wheat, as, the child does not know how to call father and mother until he tastes the taste of grain.
llm_translation: On the fruits of the land, etc. It is obvious! Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: It was only necessary for Rabbi Yehuda, for he said wheat is a type of tree. As it was taught: The tree from which the first man ate, Rabbi Meir says it was a vine, for there is nothing that brings wailing upon man except wine, as it is said: "And he drank of the wine and was drunk." Rabbi Nechemyah says: It was a fig tree, for with the thing with which they were disgraced, they were rectified, as it is said: "And they sewed fig leaves." Rabbi Yehuda says: It was wheat, for a child does not know how to say "father" and "mother" until he tastes the taste of grain.

hebrew_text: סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא, הוֹאִיל וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה חִטָּה מִין אִילָן הִיא, לִיבָרֵךְ עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, הֵיכָא מְבָרְכִינַן בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ — הֵיכָא דְּכִי שָׁקְלַתְּ לֵיהּ לְפֵירֵי אִיתֵיהּ לִגְווֹזָא, וַהֲדַר מַפֵּיק,
human_translation: it might have entered your mind to say, since Rabbi Yehuda said wheat is a type of tree, one should recite over it: Who creates fruit of the tree. taught us Where does one recite: Who creates fruit of the tree? where, when you take the fruit, the branch remains and again produces
llm_translation: I will ascend to your opinion, I say, since Rabbi Yehuda said: Wheat is a type of tree, one should bless "Who creates the fruit of the tree" over it. It is implied to us, where do we bless "Who creates the fruit of the tree" - where when you take it for its fruit to thresh it, and then it produces.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל הֵיכָא דְּכִי שָׁקְלַתְּ לֵיהּ לְפֵירֵי לֵיתֵיהּ לִגְווֹזָא דַּהֲדַר מַפֵּיק, לָא מְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״ אֶלָּא ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.
human_translation: However, where, when you take the fruit, the branch does not remain and again produce we do not recite the blessing: Who creates fruit of the tree, but rather: Who creates fruit of the ground.
llm_translation: But here, when she took it for fruits, if she did not leave it for the owner of the vineyard, we do not recite the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the tree" over it, but rather "Who creates the fruit of the ground."

hebrew_text: וְעַל כּוּלָּן אִם אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״ וְכוּ׳. אִתְּמַר. רַב הוּנָא אָמַר: חוּץ מִן הַפַּת וּמִן הַיַּיִן. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ פַּת וְיַיִן.
human_translation: And on all if he recited: all things It was stated Rav Huna said: except for bread and wine. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: even bread and wine.
llm_translation: And on all of them if he said "that all" etc. It was stated: Rav Huna said: Except for bread and wine. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even bread and wine.

hebrew_text: נֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: רָאָה פַּת וְאָמַר: ״כַּמָּה נָאָה פַּת זוֹ, בָּרוּךְ הַמָּקוֹם שֶׁבְּרָאָהּ״ — יָצָא. רָאָה תְּאֵנָה וְאָמַר ״כַּמָּה נָאָה תְּאֵנָה זוֹ, בָּרוּךְ הַמָּקוֹם שֶׁבְּרָאָהּ״ — יָצָא, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: כׇּל הַמְשַׁנֶּה מִמַּטְבֵּעַ שֶׁטָּבְעוּ חֲכָמִים בִּבְרָכוֹת — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ. נֵימָא רַב הוּנָא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר?!
human_translation: Let us say parallel to a tannaitic saw bread and said: How pleasant is this bread, blessed is the Omnipresent Who created it, fulfilled One who saw a fig and said: How pleasant is this fig, blessed is the Omnipresent Who created it, fulfilled the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One who deviates from the formula coined by the Sages in blessings, did not fulfill his obligation. let us say Rav Huna, said in accordance with Rabbi Yosei; and Rabbi Yoḥanan, said in accordance with Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: Said as the Tannaim: Saw bread and said: "How beautiful is this bread, blessed is the One who created it" - he fulfilled his obligation. Saw a fig and said, "How beautiful is this fig, blessed is the One who created it" - he fulfilled his obligation, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: Anyone who deviates from the natural blessing that the sages instituted - has not fulfilled his obligation. Said as Rav Huna in the name of Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Meir?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רַב הוּנָא: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר הָתָם, אֶלָּא הֵיכָא דְּקָא מַדְכַּר שְׁמֵיהּ דְּפַת, אֲבָל הֵיכָא דְּלָא קָא מַדְכַּר שְׁמֵיהּ דְּפַת אֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי מֵאִיר מוֹדֶה.
human_translation: Rav Huna said to you: I said even Rabbi Meir, Rabbi Meir only stated there, where mentions the term bread but where he does not mention term bread, even Rabbi Meir agrees
llm_translation: Rav Huna said to you: I, who say even according to Rabbi Meir, until here Rabbi Meir did not say there, but where he mentions the name of Pot, but where he does not mention the name of Pot, even Rabbi Meir agrees.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר לָךְ: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הָתָם אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָאָמַר בְּרָכָה דְּלָא תַּקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן, אֲבָל אָמַר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״ דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן, אֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי מוֹדֶה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said to you: I said even Rabbi Yosei, Rabbi Yosei only stated there, because he recited a blessing that was not instituted by the Sages; however, he recited: By whose word all things came to be, which was instituted by the Sages, even Rabbi Yosei agrees
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said to you: I, who said even to Rabbi Yosei, until here Rabbi Yosei did not say, rather because he said a blessing that the Rabbis did not establish, but he said "that everything is dependent on His word" that the Rabbis did establish, even Rabbi Yosei agrees.

hebrew_text: בִּנְיָמִין רָעֲיָא כְּרַךְ רִיפְתָּא, וַאֲמַר: ״בְּרִיךְ מָרֵיהּ דְּהַאי פִּיתָּא״. אָמַר רַב: יָצָא. וְהָאָמַר רַב: כׇּל בְּרָכָה שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם אֵינָהּ בְּרָכָה! דְּאָמַר: ״בְּרִיךְ רַחֲמָנָא מָרֵיהּ דְּהַאי פִּיתָּא״.
human_translation: Binyamin the shepherd ate bread and recited Blessed is the Master of this bread. Rav said, fulfilled But didn’t Rav say: Any blessing that does not contain mention of God’s name is not blessing? He said: Blessed is the All-Merciful, Master of this bread.
llm_translation: Benjamin saw a loaf of bread, and he said: "Blessed be the Master of this bread." Rav said: He fulfilled his obligation. But didn't Rav say: Any blessing that does not include mention of the Name is not a blessing! As it says: "Blessed be the Merciful One, Master of this bread."

hebrew_text: וְהָא בָּעֵינַן שָׁלֹשׁ בְּרָכוֹת? מַאי ״יָצָא״ דְּקָאָמַר רַב — נָמֵי יָצָא יְדֵי בְּרָכָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: But don’t we require three blessings What is: Fulfills his obligation, that Rav also said? He fulfills of the first blessings,
llm_translation: And this, we require three blessings? What is "he has fulfilled" that Rav is saying - also he has fulfilled the obligation of the first blessing.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָמַשְׁמַע לַן? אַף עַל גַּב דַּאֲמָרָהּ בִּלְשׁוֹן חוֹל.
human_translation: What is he teaching us? Although he recited in a secular language,
llm_translation: What is the implication for us? Even though it was stated in the vernacular language.

hebrew_text: תְּנֵינָא: וְאֵלּוּ נֶאֱמָרִים בְּכָל לְשׁוֹן: פָּרָשַׁת סוֹטָה, וִידּוּי מַעֲשֵׂר, קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, וּתְפִלָּה, וּבִרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן. אִצְטְרִיךְ: סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא, הָנֵי מִילֵּי דַּאֲמָרָהּ בִּלְשׁוֹן חוֹל כִּי הֵיכִי דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן בִּלְשׁוֹן קֹדֶשׁ, אֲבָל לֹא אֲמָרָהּ בִּלְשׁוֹן חוֹל כִּי הֵיכִי דְּתַקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן בִּלְשׁוֹן קֹדֶשׁ, אֵימָא לָא. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: we learned And these are recited in any language The portion of sota , confession tithes the recitation of Shema , and prayer and Grace after Meals. is necessary, as it might have entered your mind to say: This, applies only recited it in a secular language, just as it was instituted by the Sages in the holy tongue. However, where did not recite in a secular language, just as it was instituted by the Sages in the holy tongue, say no, not teaches us
llm_translation: We have learned: And these are the matters that are said in every language: the portion of the suspected adulteress, confession of tithes, recitation of the Shema, prayer, and grace after meals. It was necessary: Since your mind was raised, I say, those matters that were said in secular language, how did the Rabbis establish them in the holy language, but they did not say them in secular language, how did the Rabbis establish them in the holy language, say perhaps not. This is what we have heard.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. אָמַר רַב: כׇּל בְּרָכָה שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ הַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם — אֵינָהּ בְּרָכָה. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: כׇּל בְּרָכָה שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ מַלְכוּת אֵינָהּ בְּרָכָה. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּתַנְיָא: ״לֹא עָבַרְתִּי מִמִּצְוֹתֶיךָ וְלֹא שָׁכָחְתִּי״: לֹא עָבַרְתִּי — מִלְּבָרֶכְךָ, וְלֹא שָׁכָחְתִּי — מִלְּהַזְכִּיר שִׁמְךָ עָלָיו. וְאִילּוּ מַלְכוּת לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: the matter itself Rav said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of God’s name is not blessing. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of sovereignty is not blessing. Abaye said: It stands to reason in accordance with Rav, as it was taught “I did not transgress your mitzvot and I did not forget” I did not transgress, from blessing You and I did not forget, to mention Your name in over it. However, this did not teach sovereignty
llm_translation: Body. Rav said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of the Name - is not a blessing. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Any blessing that does not contain mention of Kingship - is not a blessing. Abaye said: The reasoning of Rav is logical, as it was taught: "I have not transgressed Your commandments, nor have I forgotten." - "I have not transgressed" - from not blessing You, "nor have I forgotten" - from not mentioning Your name upon it. And if it does not contain Kingship, it is not taught.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן תָּנֵי: ״וְלֹא שָׁכָחְתִּי״ — מִלְּהַזְכִּיר שִׁמְךָ וּמַלְכוּתְךָ עָלָיו.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan Emend And I did not forget to mention Your name and Your sovereignty in over it;
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan teaches: "And I have not forgotten" — to mention Your name and Your kingdom upon him.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וְעַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין גִּדּוּלוֹ מִן הָאָרֶץ אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. עַל הַחוֹמֶץ וְעַל הַנּוֹבְלוֹת וְעַל הַגּוֹבַאי, אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מִין קְלָלָה אֵין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: And over item whose growth is not from the ground, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. over vinegar, and over novelot , and over locusts, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. Rabbi Yehuda says: any that is a type curse, one does not recite a blessing over it
llm_translation: It was taught: And regarding something whose growth is not from the earth, one says, "that everything is created by His word." Regarding leaven, and regarding dried figs, and regarding raisins, one says, "that everything is created by His word." Rabbi Yehuda says: Anything that is a type of curse, one does not recite a blessing over it.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ לְפָנָיו מִינִין הַרְבֵּה, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אִם יֵשׁ בֵּינֵיהֶן מִין שִׁבְעָה — עָלָיו הוּא מְבָרֵךְ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: מְבָרֵךְ עַל אֵיזֶה מֵהֶן שֶׁיִּרְצֶה.
human_translation: many types before him, Rabbi Yehuda says: If there is one of the seven species among them, he recites blessing over it. And the Rabbis say: He recites a blessing over whichever of them he wants.
llm_translation: They were before him different kinds many, Rabbi Yehuda says: if there is among them a kind seven — upon it he blesses. And the sages say: he blesses on whichever of them he desires.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין גִּדּוּלוֹ מִן הָאָרֶץ, כְּגוֹן בְּשַׂר בְּהֵמוֹת חַיּוֹת וְעוֹפוֹת וְדָגִים אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. עַל הֶחָלָב וְעַל הַבֵּיצִים וְעַל הַגְּבִינָה אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״. עַל הַפַּת שֶׁעִפְּשָׁה, וְעַל הַיַּיִן שֶׁהִקְרִים, וְעַל הַתַּבְשִׁיל שֶׁעִבֵּר צוּרָתוֹ אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״. עַל הַמֶּלַח וְעַל הַזָּמִית וְעַל כְּמֵהִין וּפִטְרִיּוֹת אוֹמֵר ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״. לְמֵימְרָא דִּכְמֵהִין וּפִטְרִיּוֹת לָאו גִּדּוּלֵי קַרְקַע נִינְהוּ? וְהָתַנְיָא הַנּוֹדֵר מִפֵּירוֹת הָאָרֶץ — אָסוּר בְּפֵירוֹת הָאָרֶץ, וּמוּתָּר בִּכְמֵהִין וּפִטְרִיּוֹת, וְאִם אָמַר ״כׇּל גִּדּוּלֵי קַרְקַע עָלַי״ — אָסוּר אַף בִּכְמֵהִין וּפִטְרִיּוֹת.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Over a item whose growth is not from the earth, for example, meat from domesticated animals, non-domesticated animals, and fowl and fish, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. over milk, and over eggs, and over cheese, one recites: all things over moldy bread, and over wine that fermented slightly, and over a cooked dish that spoiled, one recites: By whose word all things came to be, over salt and over brine, and over truffles and mushrooms, one recites: By whose word all things came to be. Is this to say truffles and mushrooms are not that grow from the ground? Wasn’t it taught One who vows from the fruit of the earth is forbidden fruit of the earth; is permitted truffles and mushrooms. if he said: All that grow from the ground to me, he is forbidden even truffles and mushrooms.
llm_translation: The sages taught: Regarding something whose growth is not from the earth, such as the flesh of living animals, birds, and fish, one says "that everything comes from His word." Regarding milk, eggs, and cheese, one says "that everything." Regarding bread that became moldy, wine that turned sour, and a dish that spoiled its form, one says "that everything." Regarding salt, pitch, lye, and alum, one says "that everything." Is it not the case that lye and alum are not products of the ground? And it was taught: One who vows from the fruits of the earth - is prohibited from the fruits of the earth, but permitted with lye and alum. And if he says "all products of the ground are forbidden to me" - he is also prohibited from lye and alum.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מִירְבָּא רָבוּ מֵאַרְעָא, מֵינָק לָא יָנְקִי מֵאַרְעָא.
human_translation: Abaye said: to growth, they grow from the earth, to sustenance, they do not draw sustenance from the earth.
llm_translation: Abbaye said: From the abundance of the land, a child does not suckle.

hebrew_text: וְהָא ״עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין גִּדּוּלוֹ מִן הָאָרֶץ״ קָתָנֵי! תְּנִי: עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין יוֹנֵק מִן הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: Wasn’t it taught: Over item whose growth is not from the ground Emend Over item that does not draw sustenance from the ground,
llm_translation: "And here, 'Regarding something whose growth is not from the earth,' it is taught! Teach: 'Regarding something that does not suckle from the earth.'"

hebrew_text: וְעַל הַנּוֹבְלוֹת: מַאי נוֹבְלוֹת? רַבִּי זֵירָא וְרַבִּי אִילְעָא. חַד אָמַר: בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא. וְחַד אָמַר: תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא.
human_translation: over novelot What novelot ? Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Il’a One said burned by the heat And one said dates of the wind.
llm_translation: Regarding the "novlots": What are novlots? Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Ilai. One said: boiled like mara. And one said: dates of zika.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מִין קְלָלָה אֵין מְבָרְכִין עָלָיו. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא, הַיְינוּ דְּקָרֵי לֵיהּ ״מִין קְלָלָה״, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא — מַאי מִין קְלָלָה?
human_translation: We learned Rabbi Yehuda says: any that is a type curse, one does not recite a blessing over it Granted, according to the one who said burned by the heat that is that considers them a type of curse; however, according to the one who said dates that of the wind, what type of curse?
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Yehuda says: Anything that is a type of curse, we do not recite a blessing over it. It is understandable according to the one who said it is like bitter herbs, that is why it is called "a type of curse." But according to the one who said it is dates of a palm tree - what is "a type of curse"?

hebrew_text: אַשְּׁאָרָא.
human_translation: about the rest,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text "אַשְּׁאָרָא" translates to "The remainder."

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא, הַיְינוּ דִּמְבָרְכִינַן עֲלַיְיהוּ ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא, ״שֶׁהַכֹּל״?! ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָעֵץ״ מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְבָרוֹכֵי!
human_translation: Some say Granted, according to the one who said burned by the heat that is that we recite over them: By whose word all things came to be, However, to the one who said dates that of the wind, We should recite: Who creates fruit of the tree.
llm_translation: There are those who say: According to the one who says that dates are like bitter herbs, that is why we bless "Who creates all." But according to the one who says that dates are like the fruit of the tree, "Who creates the fruit of the tree" should be said over them!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, בְּנוֹבְלוֹת סְתָמָא כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּבוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא נִינְהוּ. כִּי פְּלִיגִי בְּנוֹבְלוֹת תְּמָרָה. דִּתְנַן: הַקַּלִּין שֶׁבַּדְּמַאי: הַשִּׁיתִין, וְהָרִימִּין, וְהָעוּזְרָדִין, בְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ, וּבְנוֹת שִׁקְמָה, וְגוּפְנִין, וְנִצְפָּה, וְנוֹבְלוֹת תְּמָרָה.
human_translation: Rather, with regard to novelot unmodified, everyone agrees that they are burned by the heat When they argue, it with regard to novelot temara , as we learned lenient with regard to demai Shittin , rimin , uzradin , benot shuaḥ , benot shikma , gufnin , nitzpa , and novelot temara .
llm_translation: Rather, with regard to dried figs, everyone agrees that they are considered like the bitter herbs. For they disagree regarding dried dates. As we learned in a Mishnah: The light ones of Demai: the Shitin, and the Rimmin, and the Uzradin, the daughters of Shuach, and the daughters of Shikmah, and the Gufnin, and the Nitzpah, and the dried dates.

hebrew_text: שִׁיתִין, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִין תְּאֵנִים. רִימִּין — כַּנְדֵי. הָעוּזְרָדִין — טוּלְשֵׁי. בְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: תְּאֵינֵי חִיוָּרָתָא. בְּנוֹת שִׁקְמָה, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: דּוּבְלֵי. גּוּפְנִין — שִׁילְהֵי גּוּפְנֵי. נִצְפָּה — פִּרְחָה. נוֹבְלוֹת תְּמָרָה — רַבִּי אִילְעָא וְרַבִּי זֵירָא, חַד אָמַר: בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא, וְחַד אָמַר: תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא.
human_translation: Shittin , Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: a type figs. Rimin lote. Uzradin crabapples. Benot shuaḥ , Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: white figs. Benot shikma , Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: the fruit of the sycamore tree. Gufnin the last grapes Nitzpa fruit of the caper-bush. Novelot temara , Rabbi Il’a and Rabbi Zeira One said burned by the heat and one said dates of the wind.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Shitin," Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: figs. "Rimmin" - baskets. "Ha'uzerdin" - baskets. "Benot Shuḥa," Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: the figs of the courtyard. "Benot Shikmah," Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: gourds. "Gufnin" - the branches of the gourds. "Nitzpa" - it blossomed. "Noblot Tamra" - Rabbi Il'a and Rabbi Zeira, one said: ripe dates, and one said: fresh dates.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא — הַיְינוּ דְּקָתָנֵי הַקַּלִּין שֶׁבַּדְּמַאי סְפֵיקָן הוּא דְּפָטוּר, הָא וַדָּאָן — חַיָּיב. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא — וַדָּאָן חַיָּיב?! הֶפְקֵרָא נִינְהוּ!
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said burned by the heat that is that it was taught lenient with regard to demai , those uncertainty that are exempt Those certainty one is obligated However, according to the one who said dates of the wind, Those certainty one is obligated? They are ownerless,
llm_translation: In peace, according to the one who says "cooked like a mirror" — that is, the Mishnah teaches that the lightest of the Demai produce is exempt, but here it is obligated. Rather, according to the one who says "dates of Zikah" — here too it is obligated?! They are ownerless!

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן גּוֹרֶן. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב: הַלֶּקֶט וְהַשִּׁכְחָה וְהַפֵּאָה שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן גּוֹרֶן — הוּקְבְּעוּ לְמַעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: With what are we dealing here? made them a pile of threshed grain, As Rabbi Yitzḥak said Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov: gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners, made them into a pile of threshed grain, they were rendered tithes.
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? — That he made them into a heap. For Rabbi Yitzchak said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov: The gleanings, the forgotten sheaves, and the corner that he made into a heap — they are established for tithing.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי:
human_translation: Some say
llm_translation: There are those who say:

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תַּמְרֵי דְזִיקָא, הַיְינוּ דְּהָכָא קָרֵי לַהּ ״נוֹבְלוֹת״ סְתָמָא, וְהָתָם קָרֵי לַהּ ״תְּמָרָה״, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בּוּשְׁלֵי כַמְרָא, נִיתְנֵי אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי ״נוֹבְלוֹת תְּמָרָה״, אוֹ אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי ״נוֹבְלוֹת״ סְתָמָא. קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said that dates by the wind, that is why here, it calls them novelot , unmodified and there, it calls them temara . However, according to the one who said that burned by the heat it should have taught this and that, novelot temara ; or this and that novelot , unmodified. it is difficult.
llm_translation: In truth, according to the one who says that dates of the palm tree are sharp, that is why it is called here "novlots" simply, and there it is called "t'marah." Rather, according to the one who says that dates are like a mirror, both "novlots t'marah" are given, or both "novlots" simply. This is difficult.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ לְפָנָיו מִינִין הַרְבֵּה וְכוּ׳. אָמַר עוּלָּא: מַחֲלוֹקֶת בְּשֶׁבִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת, דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר מִין שִׁבְעָה עָדִיף, וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי מִין חָבִיב עָדִיף. אֲבָל בְּשֶׁאֵין בִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה, וְחוֹזֵר וּמְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה.
human_translation: there were many types before him. Ulla said: dispute where the blessings are the same, Rabbi Yehuda holds: The type of the seven takes precedence, and the Rabbis hold: The preferred type takes precedence, However, their blessings are not the same, everyone agrees that one must recite a blessing over this and then recite another blessing over that,
llm_translation: They were before him various types and so forth. Ulla said: The dispute is when their blessings are equal, for Rabbi Yehuda holds that a species of seven is superior, while the Rabbis hold that a beloved species is superior. But when their blessings are not equal, everyone agrees that one blesses on this and then goes back and blesses on that.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הָיוּ לְפָנָיו צְנוֹן וְזַיִת — מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַצְּנוֹן וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַזַּיִת! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּשֶׁהַצְּנוֹן עִקָּר.
human_translation: The Gemara raises an objection a radish and an olive were before him, he recites a blessing over the radish and exempts the olive With what are we dealing here? where the radish is primary
llm_translation: Challenger: If before him there were figs and olives - he blesses on the figs and exempts the olives! Here, what are we dealing with - when the figs are primary.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַזַּיִת, שֶׁהַזַּיִת מִמִּין שִׁבְעָה. לֵית לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָא דִּתְנַן: כׇּל שֶׁהוּא עִיקָּר וְעִמּוֹ טְפֵלָה — מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָעִיקָּר וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַטְּפֵלָה? וְכִי תֵּימָא: הָכִי נָמֵי דְּלֵית לֵיהּ, וְהָתַנְיָא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אִם מֵחֲמַת צְנוֹן בָּא הַזַּיִת — מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַצְּנוֹן וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַזַּיִת.
human_translation: If so, say the latter clause Rabbi Yehuda says: One recites a blessing over the olive, as the olive is a type of the seven Rabbi Yehuda not accept that which we learned Any that is primary, and with secondary, one recites a blessing over the primary exempts the secondary And if you say: Indeed, he does not hold wasn’t it taught Rabbi Yehuda says: If due to the radish the olive comes, one recites a blessing over the radish and exempts the olive.
llm_translation: If so, why not say the latter part: Rabbi Yehuda says one blesses on the olive, for the olive is of the species of seven. It is not according to Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned: Anything that is primary with a secondary accompanying it—one blesses on the primary and exempts the secondary? And if you will say: So too where it is not primary, and it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: If due to the cold the olive comes—one blesses on the cold and exempts the olive.

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם בִּצְנוֹן עִיקָּר עָסְקִינַן, וְכִי פְּלִיגִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבָּנַן — בְּמִילְּתָא אַחֲרִיתִי פְּלִיגִי, וְחַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: הָיוּ לְפָנָיו צְנוֹן וְזַיִת — מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַצְּנוֹן וּפוֹטֵר אֶת הַזַּיִת. בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — כְּשֶׁהַצְּנוֹן עִיקָּר, אֲבָל אֵין הַצְּנוֹן עִיקָּר — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה וְחוֹזֵר וּמְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה. וּשְׁנֵי מִינִין בְּעָלְמָא שֶׁבִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת — מְבָרֵךְ עַל אֵיזֶה מֵהֶן שֶׁיִּרְצֶה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מְבָרֵךְ עַל הַזַּיִת, שֶׁהַזַּיִת מִמִּין שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: Actually, we are dealing with radish is primary and when Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis disagree, it is with regard to a different case that they disagree, and is incomplete and it teaches the following: a radish and an olive were before him, he recites a blessing over the radish and exempts the olive. In what does this apply? when the radish is primary, but when the radish is not primary, everyone agrees that one recites blessing over this and then he again recites blessing over that in general, two types of food whose blessings are identical he recites a blessing over whichever of them that he wants. Rabbi Yehuda says: He recites a blessing over the olive, as the olive is a type of the seven
llm_translation: Always in the north primarily we are dealing, and when do Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis disagree — in a different matter they disagree, and lacking is lacking, and thus it is taught: If before him there are figs and olives — he blesses on the figs and exempts the olives. In what circumstances are these words said — when the figs are primary, but if the olives are primary — the words of everyone are he blesses on this and then goes back and blesses on that. And two kinds in the world whose blessings are equal — he blesses on whichever he desires. Rabbi Yehuda says: He blesses on the olive, for the olive is of the species of seven.

hebrew_text: פְּלִיגִי בַּהּ רַבִּי אַמֵּי וְרַבִּי יִצְחָק נַפָּחָא. חַד אָמַר: מַחֲלוֹקֶת בְּשֶׁבִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת, דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר מִין שִׁבְעָה עָדִיף, וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי מִין חָבִיב עָדִיף. אֲבָל בְּשֶׁאֵין בִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה וְחוֹזֵר וּמְבָרֵךְ עַל זֶה. וְחַד אָמַר: אַף בְּשֶׁאֵין בִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת נָמֵי מַחֲלוֹקֶת.
human_translation: Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa disagreed with regard to One said: dispute in where their blessings are identical, as Rabbi Yehuda held: type of the seven species takes precedence And the Rabbis held: The preferred type takes precedence, however, when their blessings are not identical, everyone agrees that one recites blessing over this and then he again recites blessing over that And one said: Even when their blessings are not identical, also a dispute.
llm_translation: They disputed it, Rabbi Ammi and Rabbi Yitzchak Napacha. One said: The disagreement is when their blessings are equal, for Rabbi Yehuda holds that the species is superior, and the Rabbis hold that the individual is superior. But when their blessings are not equal, everyone agrees that one blesses on this and then goes back and blesses on that. And one said: Even when their blessings are not equal, indeed there is a disagreement.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בְּשֶׁבִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת מַחֲלוֹקֶת — שַׁפִּיר, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר בְּשֶׁאֵין בִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶן שָׁווֹת פְּלִיגִי, בְּמַאי פְּלִיגִי! אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: לְהַקְדִּים.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said dispute in where their blessings are identical, it well. However, according to the one who says they disagree in where their blessings are not identical, about what do they disagree? Rabbi Yirmeya said: precedes
llm_translation: In peace, according to the one who says that when their blessings are equal, there is a dispute - it is fine. However, according to the one who says that when their blessings are not equal, they disagree, what do they disagree about? Rabbi Yirmeya said: To prioritize.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יִצְחָק: כׇּל הַמּוּקְדָּם בְּפָסוּק זֶה, מוּקְדָּם לִבְרָכָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֶרֶץ חִטָּה וּשְׂעֹרָה וְגֶפֶן וּתְאֵנָה וְרִמּוֹן אֶרֶץ זֵית שֶׁמֶן וּדְבָשׁ״.
human_translation: As Rav Yosef, and some say Rabbi Yitzḥak, said: Each precedes in this verse, takes precedence in terms of blessing as well, as it is stated: “A land of wheat and barley, vines, figs and pomegranates, a land of olive oil and honey”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Yosef said, and it was stated by Rabbi Yitzchak: Anyone who is early in this verse, is early for a blessing, as it says: "A land of wheat and barley, and vines, and fig trees, and pomegranates; a land of olive oil and honey."

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי חָנָן. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חָנָן: כׇּל הַפָּסוּק כּוּלּוֹ לְשִׁיעוּרִין נֶאֱמַר.
human_translation: disagrees of Rabbi Ḥanan. As Rabbi Ḥanan said: The entire verse was stated for measures
llm_translation: Disagreement of Rabbi Hanan. For Rabbi Hanan said: Every verse in its entirety was stated for the purpose of measurements.

hebrew_text: ״חִטָּה״, דִּתְנַן: הַנִּכְנָס לַבַּיִת הַמְנוּגָּע, וְכֵלָיו עַל כְּתֵפָיו, וְסַנְדָּלָיו וְטַבְּעוֹתָיו בְּיָדָיו — הוּא וָהֵן טְמֵאִין מִיָּד. הָיָה לָבוּשׁ כֵּלָיו, וְסַנְדָּלָיו בְּרַגְלָיו, וְטַבְּעוֹתָיו בְּאֶצְבְּעוֹתָיו — הוּא טָמֵא מִיָּד, וְהֵן טְהוֹרִין עַד שֶׁיִּשְׁהֶא בִּכְדֵי אֲכִילַת פְּרָס. פַּת חִטִּין וְלֹא פַּת שְׂעוֹרִין, מֵיסֵב וְאוֹכְלָן בְּלִפְתָּן.
human_translation: Wheat as we learned One who enters a house afflicted with his clothes on his shoulders, and his sandals and his rings are in his hands, he and they, immediately ritually impure. he was dressed in his clothes, and his sandals were on his feet and his rings on his fingers, he immediately becomes ritually impure but they, remain pure until he stays long enough to eat half a loaf wheat bread, and not barley bread, reclining and eating with a relish,
llm_translation: "Wheat," as we learned: One who enters a house afflicted with tzara'at, and his garments are on his shoulders, and his sandals and rings in his hands — he and they are immediately impure. If he was wearing his garments, and his sandals on his feet, and his rings on his fingers — he is impure immediately, and they are pure until the time it takes to eat half a loaf of bread. Bread made from wheat and not from barley, one sits and eats them with their crusts.

hebrew_text: ״שְׂעֹרָה״, דִּתְנַן: עֶצֶם כִּשְׂעוֹרָה מְטַמֵּא בְּמַגָּע וּבְמַשָּׂא, וְאֵינוֹ מְטַמֵּא בְּאֹהֶל.
human_translation: Barley as we learned A bone of barley imparts ritual impurity through contact and by being carried, it does not impart impurity of a tent,
llm_translation: "Se'orah," as we learned: A bone the size of a barley grain imparts impurity through contact and carrying, but does not impart impurity in a tent.

hebrew_text: ״גֶּפֶן״, כְּדֵי רְבִיעִית יַיִן לְנָזִיר. ״תְּאֵנָה״, כִּגְרוֹגֶרֶת לְהוֹצָאַת שַׁבָּת. ״רִמּוֹן״, כְּדִתְנַן: כׇּל כְּלֵי בַּעֲלֵי בָתִּים
human_translation: vines the quantity of a quarter log of wine for a Nazirite Figs a dried fig-bulk, for carrying out on Shabbat Pomegranates as we learned All utensils belonging to homeowners
llm_translation: "Vine," the size of a quarter log of wine for a Nazirite. "Fig," like a dried fig for Shabbat. "Pomegranate," as it was taught: all vessels of homeowners.

hebrew_text: שִׁיעוּרָן כְּרִמּוֹנִים.
human_translation: the size of pomegranates.
llm_translation: Their measurement is like pomegranates.

hebrew_text: ״אֶרֶץ זֵית שֶׁמֶן״, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: אֶרֶץ שֶׁכָּל שִׁיעוּרֶיהָ כְּזֵיתִים. כׇּל שִׁיעוּרֶיהָ סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ?! וְהָא אִיכָּא הָנָךְ דַּאֲמַרַן! אֶלָּא אֶרֶץ שֶׁרוֹב שִׁיעוּרֶיהָ כְּזֵיתִים.
human_translation: A land of olive oil: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said A land, all of whose measures are olives. Can it enter your mind all of whose measures Aren’t there those that we mentioned Rather, say: A land, most of whose measures are olives,
llm_translation: "The land of olive oil," said Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina: a land where all its measurements are like olives. Is it possible that all its measurements are as olives? But there are those that we have mentioned! Rather, a land where most of its measurements are like olives."

hebrew_text: ״דְּבָשׁ״, כְּכוֹתֶבֶת הַגַּסָּה בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים. וְאִידָךְ — הָנֵי שִׁיעוּרִין בְּהֶדְיָא מִי כְּתִיבִי? אֶלָּא מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וּקְרָא אַסְמַכְתָּא בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: Honey, of a large date on Yom Kippur. And the other Are these measures written explicitly Rather, by rabbinic and the verse a mere support,
llm_translation: "Debash", as the Gasah writes on Yom Kippur. And the other - those measurements in Hadya, who wrote them? Rather, from the Rabbis, and the verse is a mere support.

hebrew_text: רַב חִסְדָּא וְרַב הַמְנוּנָא הֲווֹ יָתְבִי בִּסְעוֹדְתָּא. אַיְיתוֹ לְקַמַּיְיהוּ תַּמְרֵי וְרִמּוֹנֵי. שְׁקַל רַב הַמְנוּנָא, בָּרֵיךְ אַתַּמְרֵי בְּרֵישָׁא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חִסְדָּא: לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר לְהָא דְּאָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יִצְחָק: כׇּל הַמּוּקְדָּם בְּפָסוּק זֶה קוֹדֵם לִבְרָכָה?
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda and Rav Hamnuna were sitting at a meal. They brought dates and pomegranates before them. Rav Hamnuna took and recited a blessing over the dates first. Rav Ḥisda said to him: the Master not hold that which Rav Yosef, and some say Rabbi Yitzḥak, said: Each precedes in this verse, precedes in terms of blessing as well?
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda and Rav Hamnuna were sitting at a meal. They brought before them dates and pomegranates. Rav Hamnuna took the dates first. Rav Ḥisda said to him: The Master does not hold in accordance with what Rav Yosef said, and some say it was Rabbi Yitzḥak: Anyone who is early in reciting this verse precedes the blessing?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זֶה שֵׁנִי לְ״אֶרֶץ״, וְזֶה חֲמִישִׁי לְ״אֶרֶץ״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאן יָהֵיב לַן נִגְרֵי דְפַרְזְלָא וּנְשַׁמְּעִינָּךְ.
human_translation: said to him: This, is second to land, and this, fifth to land. said to him Who will give us iron legs that we may serve you
llm_translation: He said to him: This is second for "land," and this is fifth for "land." He said to him: Who will give us a carpenter of iron and we will hear you.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הֵבִיאוּ לִפְנֵיהֶם תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים בְּתוֹךְ הַסְּעוּדָה, אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לִפְנֵיהֶם וְאֵין טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. וְכֵן אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לִפְנֵיהֶם וְאֵין טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: טְעוּנִין בְּרָכָה בֵּין לִפְנֵיהֶם בֵּין לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. שֶׁאֵין לְךָ דָּבָר שֶׁטָּעוּן בְּרָכָה לְפָנָיו וְאֵין טָעוּן בְּרָכָה לְאַחֲרָיו אֶלָּא פַּת הַבָּאָה בְּכִסָנִין בִּלְבַד. וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא: פַּת פּוֹטֶרֶת כׇּל מִינֵי מַאֲכָל, וְיַיִן פּוֹטֵר כׇּל מִינֵי מַשְׁקִים.
human_translation: It was stated: they brought figs and grapes before them during a meal, Rav Huna said: They require a blessing before them, and do not require a blessing after them, And so too, Rav Naḥman said: They require a blessing before them, and do not require a blessing after them. And Rav Sheshet said: They require a blessing both before them and after them, as you have nothing which requires a blessing before it and does not require a blessing after it, except bread, that comes as dessert, disagree with of Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya said: Bread exempts all the types of food and wine exempts all types of drinks
llm_translation: It was stated: They brought before them figs and grapes in the midst of the meal. Rav Huna said: Blessings are required before them but not required after them. And so said Rav Nahman: Blessings are required before them but not required after them. And Rav Sheshet said: Blessings are required, whether before them or after them. For there is nothing that requires a blessing before it and does not require a blessing after it, except for bread that comes with condiments alone. And this is in dispute with the opinion of Rabbi Chiya, as Rabbi Chiya said: Bread exempts all kinds of food, and wine exempts all kinds of drinks.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הִלְכְתָא דְּבָרִים הַבָּאִים מֵחֲמַת הַסְּעוּדָה בְּתוֹךְ הַסְּעוּדָה — אֵין טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לֹא לִפְנֵיהֶם וְלֹא לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. וְשֶׁלֹּא מֵחֲמַת הַסְּעוּדָה בְּתוֹךְ הַסְּעוּדָה — טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לִפְנֵיהֶם וְאֵין טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם. לְאַחַר הַסְּעוּדָה — טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה בֵּין לִפְנֵיהֶם בֵּין לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said the halakha items that come due to the meal, during the meal, neither require a blessing before them nor after them, And that do not come due to the meal, during the meal, require a blessing before them and do not require a blessing after them. after the meal, they require a blessing both before them and after them.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: The halacha regarding matters that arise during the meal within the meal - they do not require a blessing neither before them nor after them. And if it is not due to the meal within the meal - they require a blessing before them, and they do not require a blessing after them. After the meal - they require a blessing, whether before them or after them.

hebrew_text: שָׁאֲלוּ אֶת בֶּן זוֹמָא: מִפְּנֵי מָה אָמְרוּ דְּבָרִים הַבָּאִים מֵחֲמַת הַסְּעוּדָה בְּתוֹךְ הַסְּעוּדָה אֵינָם טְעוּנִים בְּרָכָה לֹא לִפְנֵיהֶם וְלֹא לְאַחֲרֵיהֶם? אָמַר לָהֶם: הוֹאִיל וּפַת פּוֹטַרְתָּן. אִי הָכִי, יַיִן נָמֵי נִפְטְרֵיהּ פַּת! שָׁאנֵי יַיִן
human_translation: asked Ben Zoma: Why did say items that come due to the meal during the meal, neither require a blessing before them nor after them? He said to them: Because bread exempts them. If so, bread should also exempt wine. Wine is different,
llm_translation: They asked Ben Zoma: Why did they say that words that come because of the meal during the meal do not require a blessing, neither before them nor after them? He said to them: Since bread exempts them. If so, wine should exempt bread! Wine is different.

hebrew_text: דְּגוֹרֵם בְּרָכָה לְעַצְמוֹ.
human_translation: as it causes a blessing itself.
llm_translation: The fisherman causes a blessing for himself.

hebrew_text: רַב הוּנָא אֲכַל תְּלֵיסַר רִיפְתֵי בְּנֵי תְּלָתָא תְּלָתָא בְּקַבָּא וְלָא בָּרֵיךְ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן: עָדֵי כַּפְנָא! אֶלָּא כֹּל שֶׁאֲחֵרִים קוֹבְעִים עָלָיו סְעוּדָה, צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: Rav Huna ate thirteen loaves, three per kav and he did not recite Rav Naḥman said to him: That is hunger. Rather, over anything which others base a meal one must recite
llm_translation: Rav Huna ate thirteen loaves of bread, three by three in a kab, and did not make a blessing. Rav Nachman said to him: "It is as clear as the palm of the hand! Rather, if others establish a meal over it, one must make a blessing."

hebrew_text: רַב יְהוּדָה הֲוָה עָסֵיק לֵיהּ לִבְרֵיהּ בֵּי רַב יְהוּדָה בַּר חֲבִיבָא. אַיְיתוֹ לְקַמַּיְיהוּ פַּת הַבָּאָה בְּכִסָנִין. כִּי אֲתָא, שַׁמְעִינְהוּ דְּקָא מְבָרְכִי ״הַמּוֹצִיא״. אָמַר לְהוּ: מַאי ״צִיצִי״ דְּקָא שָׁמַעְנָא? דִּילְמָא ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״ קָא מְבָרְכִיתוּ? אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: אִין. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי מוּנָא אָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: פַּת הַבָּאָה בְּכִסָנִין מְבָרְכִין עָלֶיהָ ״הַמּוֹצִיא״, וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda was engaged his son’s at the house of Rav Yehuda bar Ḥaviva when they brought bread that comes as dessert before them. When it arrived, he heard them reciting: Who brings forth He said to them: What is this tzitzi that I hear? Perhaps you are reciting: Who brings forth bread from the earth? They said to him: Yes, as it was taught Rabbi Mona said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda: Over bread that comes as dessert, one recites: Who brings forth And Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Mona.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah was engaged with his son, the house of Rav Yehudah bar Chaviva. They brought before them bread that came from Kisnin. When it came, they heard him blessing "Who brings forth." He said to them: What "tzitzit" did I hear? Perhaps you are blessing "Who brings forth bread from the earth"? They said to him: No. As it was taught, Rabbi Muna said in the name of Rabbi Yehudah: Bread that comes from Kisnin, one blesses "Who brings forth" over it, and Shmuel said: The halakha is according to Rabbi Muna.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְהוּ: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא אִתְּמַר. אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: וְהָא מָר הוּא דְּאָמַר מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל לַחְמָנִיּוֹת מְעָרְבִין בָּהֶן, וּמְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״הַמּוֹצִיא״? שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּקָבַע סְעוֹדְתֵּיהּ עֲלַיְיהוּ, אֲבָל הֵיכָא דְּלָא קָבַע סְעוֹדְתֵּיהּ עֲלַיְיהוּ — לָא.
human_translation: said to them: it was stated The halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Mona. They said to him: But aren’t Master, the one who said in the name Shmuel wafers: One may establish an eiruv , with them and recite over them: Who brings forth It is different there as he based his meal upon them, but here, where one did not base his meal upon them, no,
llm_translation: He said to them: The halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Munah. They said to him: But isn't it the Master who said in the name of Shmuel that one may use lentils to fulfill the obligation of eruv and recite the blessing of "hamotzi" over them? The case there is different, as he established his meals with them, but here, where he did not establish his meals with them - no.

hebrew_text: רַב פָּפָּא אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב נָתָן. בָּתַר דְּגָמְרִי סְעוֹדְתַּיְיהוּ אַיְיתוֹ לְקַמַּיְיהוּ מִידֵּי לְמֵיכַל שָׁקֵל רַב פָּפָּא וְקָא אָכֵיל. אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר גָּמַר אָסוּר מִלֶּאֱכוֹל? אָמַר לְהוּ: ״סִלֵּק״ אִתְּמַר.
human_translation: Rav Pappa happened to the house of Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan. After they finished their meal, they brought before them something to eat. Rav Pappa took and ate They said to him: Master, not hold one finished he is forbidden to eat He said to them it is stated: Removed.
llm_translation: Rav Papa entered the house of Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan. After they finished their meal, they brought before them a dish. Rav Papa took it and ate. They said to him: Does the master not hold that once one has finished eating, it is forbidden to eat again? He said to them: "Remove" was stated.

hebrew_text: רָבָא וְרַבִּי זֵירָא אִיקְּלַעוּ לְבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא. לְבָתַר דְּסַלִּיקוּ תַּכָּא מִקַּמַּיְיהוּ שַׁדַּרוּ לְהוּ רִיסְתָּנָא מִבֵּי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא. רָבָא אָכֵיל וְרַבִּי זֵירָא לָא אָכֵיל. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר סִלֵּק אָסוּר מִלֶּאֱכוֹל? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֲנַן אַתַּכָּא דְּרֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא סָמְכִינַן.
human_translation: Rava and Rabbi Zeira happened to the house of the Exilarch. After they removed the table from before them, a portion [ ristena ] was sent to them from the house of the Exilarch. Rava ate and Rabbi Zeira did not eat said to Master, not hold removed, he is forbidden to eat? said to him: We are dependent upon the table of the Exilarch,
llm_translation: Rava and Rabbi Zeira entered the house of the head of the exile. After they left, a cup was taken from before them, and a head of cabbage was sent to them from the house of the head of the exile. Rava ate, but Rabbi Zeira did not eat. He said to him: Does the master not hold that a removed cup is prohibited to eat from? He said to him: We rely on the head of the exile.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: הָרָגִיל בְּשֶׁמֶן — שֶׁמֶן מְעַכְּבוֹ. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: כִּי הָוֵינַן בֵּי רַב כָּהֲנָא, אָמַר לַן: כְּגוֹן אֲנַן דִּרְגִילִינַן בְּמִשְׁחָא — מִשְׁחָא מְעַכְּבָא לַן. וְלֵית הִלְכְתָא כְּכׇל הָנֵי שְׁמַעְתָּתָא, אֶלָּא כִּי הָא דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: שָׁלֹשׁ תְּכִיפוֹת הֵן: תֵּכֶף לִסְמִיכָה שְׁחִיטָה, תֵּכֶף לִגְאוּלָּה תְּפִלָּה, תֵּכֶף לִנְטִילַת יָדַיִם בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: Rav said: One who is accustomed to oil oil delays his Rav Ashi said: When we were in the house of Rav Kahana, he said to us: We, for example, who are accustomed to oil, oil delays for us. And the halakha is not in accordance with all of these statements Rather, it is that which Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said Rav said: There are three immediately Immediately placing hands slaughter; immediately redemption prayer; immediately washing of the hands the blessing of
llm_translation: Rav said: One who is accustomed to oil - oil hinders him. Rav Ashe said: When we were in the house of Rav Kahana, he said to us: Just as we who are accustomed to oil, oil hinders us. And the halakha is not like all those opinions, but rather like that which Rabbi Hiyya bar Ashe said in the name of Rav: There are three knocks: a knock for leaning, slaughter, a knock for redemption, prayer, a knock for washing hands, blessing.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אַף אָנוּ נֹאמַר: תֵּכֶף לְתַלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים בְּרָכָה. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְבָרְכֵנִי ה׳ בִּגְלָלֶךָ״. אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא מֵהָכָא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְבָרֶךְ ה׳ אֶת בֵּית הַמִּצְרִי בִּגְלַל יוֹסֵף״.
human_translation: Abaye said we too will say: Immediately Torah scholars blessing as it is stated “The Lord has blessed me because of you” If you wish, say from here, as it is stated: the Lord blessed the house of the Egyptian on account of Joseph”
llm_translation: Abaye said, we also say: Immediately to the students of the sages a blessing. As it is stated: "And the Lord blessed me for your sake." If you wish, say it is derived from here, as it is stated: "And the Lord blessed the house of the Egyptian for Joseph's sake."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ בֵּרַךְ עַל הַיַּיִן שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמָּזוֹן — פָּטַר אֶת הַיַּיִן שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן. בֵּרַךְ עַל הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמָּזוֹן — פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן. בֵּרַךְ עַל הַפַּת — פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת. עַל הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת — לֹא פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּת. בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: אַף לֹא מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה.
human_translation: One who recited a blessing over the wine that before the meal, he exempted the wine that after the meal. one who recited a blessing over the appetizers that before the meal, he exempted the appetizers that after the meal. One who recited a blessing over the bread exempted the appetizers, over the appetizers did not exempt the bread. Beit Shammai say: did not exempt even a cooked dish
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who blesses over the wine before the meal - exempts the wine after the meal. One who blesses over the fruit before the meal - exempts the fruit after the meal. One who blesses over the bread - exempts the fruit. But if one blesses over the fruit, he does not exempt the bread. Beit Shammai says: Not even the making of a pot.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ יוֹשְׁבִין — כׇּל אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ. הֵסַבּוּ — אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּן.
human_translation: were sitting each recites a blessing for himself. If they were reclined one recites a blessing on behalf of them all.
llm_translation: They were sitting - each one blesses for himself. They reclined - one blesses for all of them.

hebrew_text: בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ. אַחַר הַמָּזוֹן — אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם. וְהוּא אוֹמֵר עַל הַמּוּגְמָר, וְאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין מְבִיאִין אֶת הַמּוּגְמָר אֶלָּא לְאַחַר סְעוּדָה.
human_translation: wine came before them during the meal, each and every recites a blessing for himself. after the meal, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all. And he, says over the incense mugmar although they only bring the incense after the meal.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ba lahem yayin betoch hamazon — kol echad ve'echad mevarech le'atzmo. Achar hamazon — echad mevarech le'kulam. Ve'hu omer al hamugmar, ve'af al pi she'ein meviin et hamugmar ela le'achar se'udah." English translation: "Wine is brought to them during the meal — each individual blesses for himself. After the meal — one blesses for all of them. And he says regarding the dessert, even though they only bring the dessert after the meal."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים, הוֹאִיל וְאָדָם קוֹבֵעַ סְעוּדָּתוֹ עַל הַיַּיִן. אֲבָל בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה, מְבָרֵךְ עַל כׇּל כּוֹס וָכוֹס.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This was only taught with regard to Shabbat and Festivals, since, one bases his meal on the wine. However, during the rest of the days of the year, recites a blessing over each and every cup,
llm_translation: Gemara: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: They only instituted the blessing on Shabbatot and festivals, since a person establishes his meal on wine. But on other days of the year, one recites a blessing over each cup.

hebrew_text: אִתְּמַר נָמֵי: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר מָרִי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים, וּבְשָׁעָה שֶׁאָדָם יוֹצֵא מִבֵּית הַמֶּרְחָץ, וּבִשְׁעַת הַקָּזַת דָּם, הוֹאִיל וְאָדָם קוֹבֵעַ סְעוּדָּתוֹ עַל הַיַּיִן. אֲבָל בִּשְׁאָר יְמוֹת הַשָּׁנָה — מְבָרֵךְ עַל כׇּל כּוֹס וָכוֹס.
human_translation: It was also stated: Rabba bar Mari said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: This was only taught with regard to Shabbat and Festivals, and when a person emerges from the bathhouse, and during bloodletting, since one bases his meal on wine. However, during the rest of the days of the year, recites a blessing over each and every cup.
llm_translation: It was stated: Rabba bar Mari said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: They only instituted the blessing on Shabbatot and festivals, and at the time when a person leaves the bathhouse, and at the time of bloodletting, since a person establishes his meal on wine. But on other days of the year, one blesses after each cup.

hebrew_text: רַבָּה בַּר מָרִי אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי רָבָא בְּחוֹל. חַזְיֵיהּ דְּבָרֵיךְ לִפְנֵי הַמָּזוֹן, וַהֲדַר בָּרֵיךְ לְאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: יִישַׁר. וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי.
human_translation: Rabba bar Mari happened to the house of Rava during the week. He saw him recite a blessing before the meal, and again recite a blessing after the meal. He said to him: Well done. And so too, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said
llm_translation: Rabba bar Mari entered the house of Rava on a weekday. He saw that your words are before the food, and afterwards your blessing. He said to him: "Yishar." And so said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.

hebrew_text: רַב יִצְחָק בַּר יוֹסֵף אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי אַבָּיֵי בְּיוֹם טוֹב. חַזְיֵיהּ דְּבָרֵיךְ אַכֹּל כָּסָא וְכָסָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר לְהָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי?! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נִמְלָךְ אֲנָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef happened to the house of Abaye on a Festival. He saw that he recited a blessing over each and every cup said to him: Master not hold that of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, said to him: I change my mind
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak, son of Yosef, entered the house of Abaye on a festival day. He saw that your words are like a bowl and a bowl. He said to him: Does the Master not hold like that of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi?! He said to him: I have been anointed.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן מַהוּ שֶׁיִּפְטוֹר אֶת הַיַּיִן שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן? אִם תִּימְצֵי לוֹמַר בֵּרַךְ עַל הַיַּיִן שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמָּזוֹן פּוֹטֵר אֶת הַיַּיִן שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן — מִשּׁוּם דְּזֶה לִשְׁתּוֹת וְזֶה לִשְׁתּוֹת. אֲבָל הָכָא — דְּזֶה לִשְׁתּוֹת, וְזֶה לִשְׁרוֹת — לָא. אוֹ דִילְמָא לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before wine came out to them during the meal, what is exempting the wine after the meal If you say: One who recited a blessing over the wine that before the meal, he exempted the wine that after the meal, is because this, is to drink, and that, is to drink However, here, where this, is to drink and that, is to moisten no. Or perhaps there is no difference,
llm_translation: He asked them: If wine came to them amidst the meal, what should they do to exempt the wine that comes after the meal? If you want to say that by blessing over the wine before the meal, one exempts the wine that comes after the meal - because this one is for drinking and that one is for drinking. But here - this one is for drinking, and that one is for soaking - it is not the same. Or perhaps it is not different.

hebrew_text: רַב אָמַר: פּוֹטֵר, וְרַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר: אֵינוֹ פּוֹטֵר. רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: פּוֹטֵר, וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: אֵינוֹ פּוֹטֵר. רַב הוּנָא וְרַב יְהוּדָה וְכׇל תַּלְמִידֵי דְּרַב אָמְרִי: אֵינוֹ פּוֹטֵר. אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רָבָא לְרַב נַחְמָן: בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ. לְאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן — אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם. אֲמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי קָאָמַר: אִם לֹא בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן אֶלָּא לְאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן, אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם.
human_translation: Rav said: It exempts, and Rav Kahana said: It does not exempt. Rav Naḥman said: It exempts, and Rav Sheshet said: It does not exempt. Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda and all the students of Rav said: It does not exempt. Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman wine came before them during the meal, each and every recites a blessing for himself. after the meal, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all. said to him: says as follows: If wine did not come before them during the meal, but only after the meal, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all.
llm_translation: Rav said: he is exempt, and Rav Kahana said: he is not exempt. Rav Nachman said: he is exempt, and Rav Sheshet said: he is not exempt. Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda and all the disciples of Rav said: he is not exempt. Rava raised an objection to Rav Nachman: if wine comes to them during the meal - each one blesses for himself. After the meal - one blesses for all of them. He said to him, this is what he meant to say: if wine comes to them during the meal but after the meal, one blesses for all of them.

hebrew_text: בֵּרַךְ עַל הַפַּת, פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת. עַל הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת, לֹא פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּת. בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: אַף לֹא מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה.
human_translation: One who recited a blessing over the bread exempted the appetizers, over the appetizers did not exempt the bread. Beit Shammai say: did not exempt even a cooked dish
llm_translation: Blessing on the bread, exempted the pastry. On the pastry, did not exempt the bread. Beit Shammai says: Also not the making of a pot.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אַרֵישָׁא פְּלִיגִי, אוֹ דִילְמָא אַסֵּיפָא פְּלִיגִי? דְּקָאָמַר תַּנָּא קַמָּא בֵּרַךְ עַל הַפַּת — פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה. וְאָתֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי לְמֵימַר לָא מִיבַּעְיָא פַּרְפֶּרֶת דְּלָא פָּטְרָה לְהוּ פַּת, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה נָמֵי לָא פָּטְרָה. אוֹ דִילְמָא אַסֵּיפָא פְּלִיגִי, דְּקָתָנֵי: בֵּרַךְ עַל הַפַּרְפֶּרֶת — לֹא פָּטַר אֶת הַפַּת. פַּת הוּא דְּלָא פָּטַר אֲבָל מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה — פָּטַר. וְאָתוּ בֵּית שַׁמַּאי לְמֵימַר וַאֲפִילּוּ מַעֲשֵׂה קְדֵרָה נָמֵי לָא פָּטַר.
human_translation: a dilemma was raised before Beit Shammai disagree with the first clause or with the latter clause, the first tanna says: One who recited a blessing over the bread exempted the appetizers and all the more so a cooked dish. And Beit Shammai come to say: It goes without saying that bread does not exempt appetizers; as does not even exempt a cooked dish. Or perhaps they disagree with the latter clause, as it was taught: One who recited a blessing over the appetizers did not exempt the bread. did not exempt bread, but it did exempt a cooked dish. And Beit Shammai come to say did not exempt even a cooked dish.
llm_translation: He inquired of them: Beit Shammai, do they dispute the first part, or perhaps they dispute the latter part? For it was taught: If one recited a blessing over bread - he exempted the pastry, and all the more so the dish of food cooked in a pot. And Beit Shammai come to say: It is not necessary to inquire about the pastry, for if he did not exempt the bread, certainly he did not exempt the dish of food cooked in a pot. Or perhaps they dispute the latter part, for it was taught: If one recited a blessing over the pastry - he did not exempt the bread. Bread is that which he did not exempt, but the dish of food cooked in a pot - he exempted. And Beit Shammai come to say: And even the dish of food cooked in a pot, he did not exempt.

hebrew_text: תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Let it stand,
llm_translation: The case remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ יוֹשְׁבִין כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד כּוּ׳. הֵסַבּוּ — אִין, לֹא הֵסַבּוּ — לָא. וּרְמִינְהוּ: עֲשָׂרָה שֶׁהָיוּ הוֹלְכִים בַּדֶּרֶךְ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁכּוּלָּם אוֹכְלִים מִכִּכָּר אֶחָד — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ. יָשְׁבוּ לֶאֱכוֹל, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁכָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד אוֹכֵל מִכִּכָּרוֹ — אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם. קָתָנֵי ״יָשְׁבוּ״ אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵסַבּוּ!
human_translation: were sitting and each and every they reclined, yes, they did not recline, no. And raises a contradiction: Ten who were walking on the road, even if they are all eating from one loaf, each and every one recites a blessing for himself. they sat to eat, even if each and every one is eating from his loaf, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all it was taught: they sat even though they did not recline.
llm_translation: They were sitting, each and every one of them. They leaned - yes, they leaned; they did not lean - no. And they raised a dilemma: Ten who were walking on the road, even though all of them eat from one loaf - each and every one of them blesses for himself. They sat to eat, even though each and every one of them eats from his own loaf - one blesses for all of them. It teaches "they sat" even though they did not lean!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: כְּגוֹן דְּאָמְרִי ״נֵיזִיל וְנֵיכוֹל לַחְמָא בְּדוּךְ פְּלָן״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: in a case where they said: Let us go and eat in such-and-such a place.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: For example, as they say, "Let us go and eat bread in so-and-so's oven."

hebrew_text: כִּי נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּרַב, אֲזוּל תַּלְמִידֵיהּ בָּתְרֵיהּ. כִּי הָדְרִי, אָמְרִי: נֵיזִיל וְנֵיכוּל לַחְמָא אַנְּהַר דָּנָק. בָּתַר דְּכָרְכִי, יָתְבִי וְקָא מִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: ״הֵסַבּוּ״ דַּוְקָא תְּנַן, אֲבָל יָשְׁבוּ לָא, אוֹ דִילְמָא כֵּיוָן דְּאָמְרִי ״נֵיזִיל וְנֵיכוֹל רִיפְתָּא בְּדוּכְתָּא פְּלָנִיתָא״ — כִּי הֵסַבּוּ דָּמֵי? לָא הֲוָה בִּידַיְיהוּ.
human_translation: When Rav died, his students went after his When they returned, they said: Let us go and eat bread on the Dannak River. After they ate, they sat, and raised a dilemma: Did we learn specifically they reclined, however, sat no, Or perhaps, since they said: Let us go and eat in such-and-such a place, as if they reclined? It was not within their capability
llm_translation: When Rav passed away, his students went after him. When they returned, they said: "Let us go and eat bread at the inn of the river Danak." After they remembered, they sat down and he asked them: "Did you specifically learn that we should go and eat bread in such and such a place?" - "Did they set aside money?" - It was not in their possession.

hebrew_text: קָם רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava stood,
llm_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava arose.

hebrew_text: אַהְדַּר קִרְעֵיהּ לַאֲחוֹרֵיהּ, וּקְרַע קְרִיעָה אַחֲרִינָא. אֲמַר: נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּרַב, וּבִרְכַּת מְזוֹנָא לָא גָּמְרִינַן. עַד דַּאֲתָא הָהוּא סָבָא, רְמָא לְהוּ מַתְנִיתִין אַבָּרַיְיתָא, וְשַׁנִּי לְהוּ: כֵּיוָן דְּאָמְרִי ״נֵיזִיל וְנֵיכוֹל לַחְמָא בְּדוּךְ פְּלָן״ — כְּהֵסַבּוּ דָּמֵי.
human_translation: reversed his tear behind him, and he rent another tear He said: Rav is dead, and we have not learned Grace after Meals. Until, this elder came and raised a contradiction the mishna to the baraita , and he resolved it for them: Since they said: Let us go and eat in such-and-such a place, as if they reclined.
llm_translation: He adorned its edges behind it, and tore another tearing. He said: the soul of Rav is content, and we have not completed the grace after meals. Until that elder came, he raised a Baraita in the language of the Hebrews, and taught them: since they said, "Let us go and eat bread at so-and-so's house" — they have set aside money.

hebrew_text: הֵסַבּוּ, אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ. אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא פַּת דְּבָעֵי הֲסִבָּה, אֲבָל יַיִן לָא בָּעֵי הֲסִבָּה. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ יַיִן נָמֵי בָּעֵי הֲסִבָּה.
human_translation: If they were reclined, one recites a blessing Rav said: This was only taught bread that requires reclining However, wine does not require reclining. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even wine requires reclining as well.
llm_translation: They reclined, one blesses. Rav said: They only taught regarding bread that requires reclining, but wine does not require reclining. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even non-intoxicating wine requires reclining.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא פַּת — דְּמַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה. אֲבָל יַיִן — לָא מַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ יַיִן נָמֵי מַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה.
human_translation: Some say Rav said: only taught that reclining is effective bread. However, wine, reclining is ineffective And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even wine, reclining is effective.
llm_translation: There are some who say, Rav said: They only decreed regarding bread - because it is fitting for it to be accompanied. But wine - it is not fitting for it to be accompanied. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even wine, which is fitting to be accompanied.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: כֵּיצַד סֵדֶר הֲסִבָּה? — אוֹרְחִין נִכְנָסִין וְיוֹשְׁבִין עַל גַּבֵּי סַפְסָלִין וְעַל גַּבֵּי קָתֶדְרָאוֹת עַד שֶׁיִּכָּנְסוּ כּוּלָּם. הֵבִיאוּ לָהֶם מַיִם — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד נוֹטֵל יָדוֹ אַחַת. בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ. עָלוּ וְהֵסַבּוּ וּבָא לָהֶם מַיִם, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁכָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד נָטַל יָדוֹ אַחַת, חוֹזֵר וְנוֹטֵל שְׁתֵּי יָדָיו. בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן — אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁכָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד בֵּרַךְ לְעַצְמוֹ, אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם.
human_translation: raises an objection What is the order of reclining guests enter and sit upon benches and chairs [ katedraot ] until all are assembled. they brought them water and each and every one washes one hand wine came before them each and every one recites a blessing for himself. they entered and reclined and water came before them, despite that each and every one washed one hand, they wash both hands again wine came before them despite that each and every one recited a blessing for himself, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all.
llm_translation: Challenger: How is the order of hospitality conducted? — Guests enter and sit on benches and on chairs until they all enter. Water is brought to them — each and every one takes one hand. Wine is brought to them — each and every one blesses for himself. They rise and recline, and water is brought to them, even though each and every one took one hand, he goes back and takes both his hands. Wine is brought to them — even though each and every one blessed for himself, one blesses for all of them.

hebrew_text: לְהַאֵיךְ לִישָּׁנָא דְּאָמַר רַב לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא פַּת דְּבָעֵי הֲסִבָּה, אֲבָל יַיִן לָא בָּעֵי הֲסִבָּה — קַשְׁיָא רֵישָׁא!
human_translation: according to that version Rav said: This was only taught bread that requires reclining However, wine does not require reclining; the first clause is difficult.
llm_translation: To what case is this similar? As Rav said, they only taught regarding bread that requires dipping, but wine does not require dipping - the beginning is difficult!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי אוֹרְחִין דְּדַעְתַּיְיהוּ לְמִיעְקַר.
human_translation: Guests are different, as their intention is to leave
llm_translation: The ways of travelers are known to Him from the beginning.

hebrew_text: וּלְהַאֵיךְ לִישָּׁנָא דְּאָמַר רַב לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא פַּת, דְּמַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה, אֲבָל יַיִן לָא מַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה — קַשְׁיָא סֵיפָא!
human_translation: And according to the version Rav said: only taught that reclining is effective bread. However, wine, reclining is ineffective the latter clause is difficult.
llm_translation: And how so? For Rav said: They only taught regarding bread, for it is fitting for it to be turned over, but wine, it is not fitting for it to be turned over - the latter part is difficult!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּמִגּוֹ דְּקָא מַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה לְפַת — מַהְנְיָא לֵיהּ הֲסִבָּה לְיַיִן.
human_translation: There it is different, as since reclining is effective for bread, reclining is effective for wine
llm_translation: The matter there is different, for since he is benefiting from it for bread - he is benefiting from it for wine.

hebrew_text: בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן. שָׁאֲלוּ אֶת בֶּן זוֹמָא: מִפְּנֵי מָה אָמְרוּ בָּא לָהֶם יַיִן בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּזוֹן — כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְעַצְמוֹ, לְאַחַר הַמָּזוֹן — אֶחָד מְבָרֵךְ לְכוּלָּם? אָמַר לָהֶם: הוֹאִיל וְאֵין בֵּית הַבְּלִיעָה פָּנוּי.
human_translation: wine came before them during the meal, They asked Ben Zoma: Why did say: wine came before them during the meal, each and every recites a blessing for himself; after the meal, one recites a blessing on behalf of them all? He said to them: because the throat is not available.
llm_translation: They brought wine in the midst of the meal. They asked Ben Zoma: Why did they say that wine was brought in the midst of the meal - each and every one blesses for themselves, after the meal - one blesses for all of them? He said to them: Since the house of feasting is not vacant.

hebrew_text: וְהוּא אוֹמֵר עַל הַמּוּגְמָר כּוּ׳. מִדְּקָתָנֵי ״וְהוּא אוֹמֵר עַל הַמּוּגְמָר״, מִכְלָל דְּאִיכָּא עֲדִיף מִינֵּיהּ, וְאַמַּאי!
human_translation: And he, recites over the incense, From that   teaches: And he recites over the incense, it can be inferred there is take precedence over him, And why
llm_translation: He says regarding the one who is finished, etc. From where do we derive "He says regarding the one who is finished"? This implies that there is something more preferable than it, and why is that?

hebrew_text: הוֹאִיל וְהוּא נָטַל יָדָיו תְּחִלָּה בָּאַחֲרוֹנָה.
human_translation: Since he washed his hands first after
llm_translation: Since he took his hands first in the last.

hebrew_text: מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַב, דְּאָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: הַנּוֹטֵל יָדָיו תְּחִלָּה בָּאַחֲרוֹנָה — הוּא מְזוּמָּן לַבְּרָכָה. רַב וְרַבִּי חִיָּיא הֲווֹ יָתְבִי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי בִּסְעוֹדְתָּא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי לְרַב: קוּם מְשִׁי יְדָךְ. חַזְיֵיהּ דַּהֲוָה מְרַתֵּת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי חִיָּיא: בַּר פַּחֲתֵי, עַיֵּין בְּבִרְכַּת מְזוֹנָא קָאָמַר לָךְ.
human_translation: supports of Rav, as Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi says Rav says: He who washes his hands first after is designated to recite the blessing Rav and Rabbi Ḥiyya were seated before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi at a meal. Rabbi said to Rav: Stand and wash your hands. saw was trembling, Rabbi Ḥiyya said Son of noblemen, he is telling you   review Grace after Meals.
llm_translation: He assists him to Rav, for Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said in the name of Rav: One who first washes his hands and then eats is prepared for the blessing. Rav and Rabbi Ḥiyya were sitting before Rabbi at a meal. Rabbi said to Rav: Stand and wash your hands. He saw that he was delaying. Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: Son of officials, he is saying the grace after meals for you.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רָבָא בַּר יִרְמְיָה: מֵאֵימָתַי מְבָרְכִין עַל הָרֵיחַ — מִשֶּׁתַּעֲלֶה תִּמְרָתוֹ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא לְרָבָא בַּר יִרְמְיָה: וְהָא לָא אֲרַח? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וּלְטַעְמָיךְ, ״הַמּוֹצִיא לֶחֶם מִן הָאָרֶץ״ דִּמְבָרֵךְ וְהָא לָא אֲכַל! אֶלָּא דַּעְתֵּיהּ לְמֵיכַל, הָכָא נָמֵי דַּעְתֵּיהּ לְאוֹרוֹחֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said Rava bar Yirmeya said: From when does one recite the blessing over the scent From when its column rises Rabbi Zeira said to Rava bar Yirmeya: But he has not smelled it. said to him: And according to your reasoning, Who brings forth bread from the earth, that one recites he has not yet eaten Rather, he intends to eat; here too, he intends to smell.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said, Rava bar Yirmeya said: From when do we recite a blessing for the fragrance? - When its flavor emerges. Rabbi Zeira said to Rava bar Yirmeya: But is this not obvious? He said to him: And according to your reasoning, "Who brings forth bread from the earth" - one recites a blessing, yet he has not eaten! Rather, his intention is to eat, here too his intention is for the guests.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בְּרֵיהּ דְּאַבָּא בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר רַב, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר זְעֵירִי: כׇּל הַמּוּגְמָרוֹת מְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״בּוֹרֵא עֲצֵי בְּשָׂמִים״ חוּץ מִמּוּשְׁק, שֶׁמִּין חַיָּה הוּא, שֶׁמְּבָרְכִין עָלָיו ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי בְּשָׂמִים״.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Abba bar Naḥmani, said Rav Ḥisda said Rav said, and some say that Rav Ḥisda said Ze’iri said: Over all the incense one recites: Who creates fragrant trees, except for musk, is from a living creature, one recites: Who creates various spices.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Chiya, son of Abba bar Nachmani, said Rav Chisda said Rav, and some say Rav Chisda said Zeiri: All fragrant spices one blesses "Who creates trees of fragrance" except for musk, which is an animal species, for which one blesses "Who creates species of fragrance."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אֵין מְבָרְכִין ״בּוֹרֵא עֲצֵי בְּשָׂמִים״ אֶלָּא עַל אֲפַרְסְמוֹן שֶׁל בֵּית רַבִּי, וְעַל אֲפַרְסְמוֹן שֶׁל בֵּית קֵיסָר, וְעַל הַהֲדַס שֶׁבְּכָל מָקוֹם!
human_translation: The Gemara raises an objection One only recites: Who creates fragrant trees, over the balsam from the house of Rabbi and over balsam from the house of Caesar and over myrtle everywhere.
